editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

Apo≈øtacy is the lo≈øs of our fir≈øt love. Repentance is the recovery of it, and Reformation is the doing of our fir≈øt works. I have not time to enlarge as I de≈øire: I ≈øhall only offer a few things, that might help to quicken you to this great duty.
My Brethren, we have no great cau≈øe to boa≈øt of Englands fir≈øt love: Never ≈øo good as it ≈øhould be, yet many can remember when England hath been much better than it is.

Our fears be very great, and truly our provocations be greater: our dangers are great, but our ≈øins greater: yet here is a word, here is matter of encouragement, that yet there is Balm in Gilead, Phy≈øick of Chri≈øts own compo≈øition, for the reviving and healing of a back-≈øliding people, Chri≈øtians, Chri≈øt Je≈øus is become your Phy≈øician, he hath pre≈øcribed you a potion made up of the≈øe three ingredients, Self-reflection, Holy Contrition, Thorow Reformation. There is yet a means or two I find in Scripture for the preventing of threatned ruine that hath been very near, that God hath pre≈øcribed for a people or per≈øon in great danger, when ready to be cut off and de≈øtroyed.
Now that which I would commend to you in reference to what you would beg of God for England, is,

Fir≈øt, in your addre≈ø≈øing your ≈øelf to God for that mercy your ≈øouls are ≈øet upon, and you wre≈øtle with God for, that you would make ≈øome ≈øpecial vow to God. I find the Saints have done ≈øo, when reduced to great ≈øtraits, not knowing what to do: Thus Jacob vowed a vow, ≈øaying, If God will be with me, and will keep me on this way that I go, and will give me bread to eat, and rayment to put on, ≈øo that I come again to my Fathers hou≈øe in peace, then ≈øhall the Lord be my God. Certainly in times of great di≈øtre≈øs, 'tis nor improper or uncomely, but that which God may expect and take well, that you make ≈øome ≈øpecial vow, if God would prevent your fears, if God would continue forfeited mercies, dearer to you than your lives, you would ≈øet apart ≈øome ≈øpecial thing for God, ≈øomething for the propagation of the Go≈øpel abroad, for the maintenance of a godly Mini≈øtry at home, for ≈øetting up the preaching of the Go≈øpel in the dark corners of the Kingdom, &c. This mu≈øt have ≈øome cautions with it: As,
1. We mu≈øt be ≈øure our vow be of what is in our own power, we mu≈øt not make vows of that which is none of our own. I hate robbery for burnt-offerings.

3. It mu≈øt be of ≈øuch things that we are not bound to do, before vows, by the ≈øtanding obligation of Religion, and of our profe≈ø≈øion: but of ≈øomething that is in our own choice, that we will voluntarily make a free-will offering of it to God.

4. 2. Another thing I find, is, that in the mean time we ≈øhould do ≈øomething by way of extraordinary bounty and charity to the relief of Gods indigent ≈øervants. Thus the Prophet Daniel: Wherefore, O King, let my coun≈øel be acceptable to thee; break off thy ≈øins by righteou≈øne≈øs, and thine iniquities by ≈øhewing mercy to the poor, if it may be a lengthning of thy tranquility, Dan. 4.27.

The Prophet advi≈øes him to break off his ≈øins by Righteou≈øne≈øs, there's Reformation: and be≈øides Reformation, that he would do ≈øomething in an extraordinary way to the relief of the poor. Mercy to the poor, what's that?

Interpreters conceive, by the poor, here he under≈øtands Gods poor, i.e. the poor Jews that were now in the Babylonian Captivity: he advi≈øes, he would do ≈øomething by way of ≈øympathy to the Jews, to ea≈øe their yoaks and oppre≈ø≈øions: break off thine iniquities by pittying and ≈øhewing mercy to thy poor Captives, under thy power now at this time; take off their yoak; ea≈øe their burdens, and re≈øtore them to their liberties again. Thus do you, and tho≈øe that have been the in≈øtruments of your conver≈øation, or edification, ≈øet apart ≈øomething extraordinary for their relief and ≈øupply: The Prophet Daniel ≈øeems to advi≈øe this to the King, as it were by way of ≈øatisfaction.

There be two things in repentance; in wrongs we have done, there mu≈øt be confe≈ø≈øion, and ≈øatisfaction, or re≈øtoration: he ≈øeems to advi≈øe this to make up compleat repentance; namely, to make re≈øtoration and retribution of what he had injuriou≈øly taken from the Jews. 2. It will be re≈øtitution in another ≈øen≈øe, in reference to an unju≈øt withholding: ≈øome have injuriou≈øly, and I am afraid too too many have kept injuriou≈øly. div.p: THe Apo≈øtle in this excellent Chapter, (that by ≈øome is de≈øervedly called a little Book of Martyrs) di≈øcovers the tryumph of faith, or victory again≈øt all difficulty we meet with.
1. Faith it a≈ø≈øents to truths be they never ≈øo improbable.
2. It puts men upon duties, be they never ≈øo irrational, or again≈øt carnal intere≈øt.
3. It enables to ≈øufferings, be they never ≈øo afflictive. The≈øe Worthies went through all by the victory that overcame the world, the bitterne≈øs as well as the ≈øweetne≈øs thereof.
In the≈øe ver≈øes the Apo≈øtle doth two things: Fir≈øt, he ≈øets down the greatne≈øs and ≈ømartne≈øs of their ≈øufferings, which are by ≈øome learned men reduced to three heads.

Secondly, Tho≈øe ≈øufferings they underwent in dying.

There were all kind of per≈øecutions laid upon the≈øe Saints, through all which they waded, and never would be brought to for≈øake God and his truth, for any of them. 2. We have here the excellency of the ≈øufferers, and that is in that expre≈ø≈øion, The≈øe men, or, the≈øe per≈øons, when they were under all the≈øe di≈øtre≈ø≈øes from the world, yet they were ≈øuch of whom the world was not worthy.
Brethren, the excellency of the≈øe ≈øaints and ≈øervants of God is con≈øiderable two ways, that we may proceed di≈øtinctly and clearly.
Fir≈øt, in reference to the wicked; their excellency was ≈øo great that the wicked World was not worthy of them.

Secondly, their excellency is di≈øcovered from the e≈øtimate or judgment that the Apo≈øtle pa≈ø≈øes upon them, who tells us, that he accounted them
to be ≈øuch; though they were under ≈øuch di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, and troubles, yet they were a people of whom the world was not worthy.

I ≈øhall fall upon the due e≈øtimation the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle rai≈øes upon the≈øe per≈øecuted Saints, who was enlightened by the Spirit of God, and ≈øo was able to pa≈øs a right ≈øentence upon the≈øe per≈øecuted Saints; from this I rai≈øe this en≈øuing ob≈øervation.

Ob≈øerve. That a godly man doth ≈øee a very great worth and excellency in the people of God in the mid≈øt of all their troubles and di≈øtre≈ø≈øes; or, That a godly man; a gracious heart, one that hath ≈øpiritual ≈øpectacles, does ≈øee an excellency and worth in the people of God, in the mid≈øt of all trouble and per≈øecution that can befall them.

Here I ≈øhall handle it fir≈øt doctrinally, according to my con≈øtant method, then come to improve it by way of Application‚ñ™ For the doctrinal handling of it, there are two things mu≈øt be di≈øcovered.

Secondly, whence it is, and how it comes to pa≈øs, that Godly men have this high and honourable e≈øteem of the Saints and people of God in their troubles and di≈øtre≈ø≈øes which befall them.

div.p: For the fir≈øt, wherein the high e≈øtimation of a gracious heart does appear, I ≈øhall ≈øhew it in five or ≈øix following particulars.

list.item: Fir≈øt, it appears in this, in that they are not a≈øhamed of owning their per≈øons and faith, that they profe≈øs in their troubles and di≈øtre≈ø≈øes: the ≈øociety of the people of God, and the fellow≈øhip of the faith and profe≈ø≈øion, is highly re≈øpected by a gracious heart, let the Saints lie under never ≈øo great di≈øtre≈ø≈øes. This is manife≈øted in Mo≈øes, in the 25. and 26. ver≈øes of this Chapter; He cho≈øe rather to ≈øuffer affliction with the people of God, then to enjoy all the plea≈øures and preferments of Pharaohs Court. The I≈øraelites Religion, the profe≈ø≈øion of the truth of God, and owning the faith and tho≈øe truths the I≈øraelites ≈øtood up for, this was that which Mo≈øes would not de≈øert: and thence it was he did not de≈øert their company and ≈øociety, but went and vi≈øited them when they lay under tho≈øe burthens under which they lay.

Secondly, the ≈øecond thing wherein is di≈øcovered ≈øo high an e≈øtimation of the Saints and people of God in ≈øuffering, is, their ≈øympathizing and fellow-feeling with them in their ≈øuffering: If it goes ill with the Church and people of God, all the re≈øt ≈øympathize with them; if one member ≈øuffers, all the re≈øt ≈øuffers. In≈øtance Nehemiah (who had the greate≈øt favour of the greate≈øt Prince then on the earth) he looks with a ≈øad countenance

Then I was very ≈øore afraid, and an≈øwered the King, becau≈øe of the di≈øtre≈ø≈øes the people of God lye under. The plea≈øure of Mu≈øick ≈øhould never be with him ≈øays David in P≈øal. 137.6. As it is with two ≈øtrings in an in≈øtrument rightly tuned, if one be touched the other trembles: if one ≈øervant of Chri≈øt be in a ≈øuffering condition, the re≈øt ≈øuffers with him: this is the damp of all worldly delight, if it be ill with any of the people of God, the re≈øt ≈øuffers in the way of compa≈ø≈øion.

Thirdly, in that they can plead for them, and take their parts, when they are never ≈øo much out of favour, when they are never ≈øo much de≈øpi≈øed and abu≈øed: This was in the ca≈øe of Jonathan, how he pleaded for poor David before his cruel father Saul, though Saul called him a cur≈øed Son, and fell ≈øoul on his Mother becau≈øe of him. See this in the ca≈øe of E≈øther, though it was death to go into the King to plead for the Jews, yet for all this ≈øhe ≈øays, If I peri≈øh, I peri≈øh: re≈øolved I am, come what will come of it, in I will go, I can dye, but I cannot be ≈øilent.

Fourthly, in that they will relieve them, and help and ≈øupply them with all needful good things they can, if they cannot do what they would, they will do for them what they can: See this in the ca≈øe of Jeremiah, Chap. 28. v. 8 11, 12, 13. Ebedmelech went forth of the Kings hou≈øe and ≈øpake to the King‚Äî So Ebedmelech took the man with him, and went into the hou≈øe of the King under the Trea≈øury, and took thence old clouts, and old rotten rags and let them down by cords into the Dungeon to Jeremiah. And Ebedmelech the Ethiopian ≈øaid unto Jeremiah, Put now the≈øe old ca≈øt clouts, and rotten rags under thine arm-holes, under the cords. And Jeremiah did ≈øo, So they drew up Jeremiah with cords, and took him up out of the Dungeon, & Jeremiah remained in the court of the Pri≈øon. He would never be quiet till he got the Prophet out of the Dungeon, and though the cords were lined with rags, yet more with love and this favour of Ebedmelech, God remembered. 1 King. 18.4. Obediahs ma≈øter was not only an oppre≈ø≈øor of the Saints and Prophets of God, but a very great Per≈øecutor: This good man Obediah took and hid 400 Prophets of the Lord, and led them with bread and water: (I will not undertake to prophe≈øie to you this day, yet time may come when bread and water may be good food for a faithful Prophet.) Here note the gracious di≈øpo≈øition of good Obediah, as well as the providence of God in this act, 2 Tim. 1.16, 17, 18. The Lord give mercy unto the dou≈øe of One≈øiphorus, for be oft refre≈øhed me, and was not a≈øhamed of my chain.
But when he was in Rome, he ≈øought me out very gently, and found me. The Lord grant unto him, that he may finde mercy of the Lord in that day: and in how many things he mini≈øtred unto me at Ephe≈øus, thou knowe≈øt very well. A mo≈øt admirable Scripture to this purpo≈øe: ble≈ø≈øed Paul being thrown into pri≈øon; being in bonds, One≈øiphorus often refre≈øht him, and was not a≈øhamed of his chains: How did he ≈øhew this? When he was in Rome, he ≈øought him out diligently. By the way note, That Rome was the place where the cruel Nero was Emperour, it was the place where much bloud of the Martyrs was ≈øpilt, yet there this good man ≈øought out Paul diligenly: Mark what follows, which is the prayer of Paul, The Lord grant to him that he may find mercy of the Lord in that day. I profe≈øs Sirs, I had rather have the prayer of Paul, than the preferments of the greate≈øt Court on earth. Chri≈øtians, it is the greate≈øt trea≈øure in your hou≈øe, to have the prayers of good men to God for you: you that have ≈øhewn your great and abundant love to the Saints and ≈øervants of God in di≈øtre≈øs, I do from my ≈øoul beg the mercy for you, that whatever you have done for his, may be ten thou≈øand times made up by him, that you may finde mercy in that day; and truly Sirs, in that day mercy will be worth receiving.

Fifthly, They ≈øupplicate to God for them; they do not go to the throne of Grace for them≈øelves, but Sion is in their thoughts. I am confident it is ≈øo with ≈øome, and am per≈øwaded it is ≈øo with all; they never beg daily bread for them≈øelves, but they remember Sion. In the 51. P≈øalm David was under trouble of con≈øcience, ≈øoul-trouble, which is the ≈øoul of trouble; yet at the latter end of the 51. P≈øalm he breaks out into this earne≈øt ≈øupplication to God; Do good in thy good plea≈øure unto Sion, build thou up the walls of Jeru≈øalem. So long as it is ill with the people of God, ≈øo long they are earne≈øt with God: and though they cannot overcome men with their prayers (which by the way they are to endeavour) yet they will never leave ≈øupplicating the Almighty, till they have overcome. As the ≈øufferings of Gods people are precious in the ≈øight of God, ≈øo they are in the fight of the people of God.

div.p:
For the opening of the former, the Injunction, Put off thy ≈øhooes, I ≈øhall not give the divers glo≈ø≈øes, and divers interpretations, which men, with more wit than weight, have endeavoured to make of this Scripture; the plain meaning is this, which is given us by Theodoret, Put off thy ≈øhooes, Gods ≈øcope, and drift, and intent hereby was, to require of Mo≈øes reverence, when he was to receive a me≈ø≈øage of very great concernment and importance about his Church; the de≈øign of God was in this, to prepare him to obedience, therefore God required that of him then,

So that I take the meaning of this command to be ≈øo much; Shew by this thy reverence, thy humility, thy due ≈øubmi≈ø≈øivene≈øs, thy ≈øubjection of ≈øpirit, together with thy ≈øervile readine≈øs to do what≈øoever I ≈øhall command thee. 2. The rea≈øon by which this is backt, Becau≈øe the place whereon Mo≈øes did ≈øtand, was holy ground. The meaning I take to be this, it is holy in regard of that vi≈øible and miraculous token, ≈øymbol, and ≈øign of his pre≈øence, that is here di≈øcovered in this place; not becau≈øe the place was (as I do not under≈øtand how any place is) of its own nature holy, but God

Now I do not under≈øtand how I can di≈øcour≈øe of this ≈øo profitably unto you, concerning the holine≈øs of places, unle≈øs we take notice of the holine≈øs of places in the time of the Go≈øpel, and con≈øider, whether, and how in the≈øe times, one place may be ≈øaid to be holy, or holier then another. And truly I am not put on this employment willingly, nor the handling of this ≈øubject; and if it were not extorted from me by ≈øomething, I do not ≈øay that I have ≈øeen, but that I have read, that was written by men, and tho≈øe none of the meane≈øt neither, the learned≈øt of the Papi≈øts, I ≈øhould not now have cho≈øen to have entred upon this Task, concerning the holine≈øs of places; in oppo≈øition to whom, I have entred upon this Di≈øcour≈øe: I will give you expre≈ø≈øions, which one of the devoute≈øt, and the other of the learned≈øt of them hath: the learned≈øt of them, accounted ≈øo at lea≈øt, (though ble≈ø≈øed be God, his weapons have not been formidable to the Church) is Bellarmine, his words are the≈øe: Templum con≈øecrandum merito venerabile & divina virtute preaeditum e≈øt: The Temple con≈øecrated is de≈øervedly holy, and venerable in wor≈øhip, and endowed with divine vertue and efficacy; the Temple ought to be looked upon as honourable and venerable. And for the other, Durandus he tells us; So great is the Religion and holine≈øs of Churches, that tho≈øe things ≈øhould be, and may be forbidden to be done in them, (he means perpetually, or el≈øe he ≈øaid nothing, for we grant as much) which in other places may duly and lawfully be done.

In the handling of this que≈øtion, How are we to judge and conceive of the holine≈øs of places, in the time of the Go≈øpel? I ≈øhall endeavour, fir≈øt, to explain it, and then faithfully and truly endeavour to re≈øolve and determine the ≈øame.

Fir≈øt then, for explanation, I ≈øhall here endeavour to open the≈øe two things to you: fir≈øt, what it is for a place to be holy, or wherein the nature of the holine≈øs of the places con≈øi≈øts; ≈øecondly, what that is, that is foundation or cau≈øe of the holine≈øs of places; and both the≈øe mu≈øt in our di≈øcour≈øe, and likewi≈øe apprehen≈øion, be accurately di≈øtingui≈øht.

1. More generally, The holine≈øs of a place doth con≈øi≈øt in the ≈øeparation thereof, the ≈øetting it apart, the di≈øtinction and di≈øcrimination in the way of ≈øome excellent pre-eminence, or the exalting of it before and

I am the Lord your God, which have ≈øeparated you from other people; you ≈øhall therefore put a difference between clean bea≈øts, and unelean. And in Deut. 7.6. and 14.2. you have there the very ≈øame things de≈øcribed and di≈øcovered unto you. And now for this, I ≈øhall de≈øire you to take notice of comparing two places of Scripture, which di≈øcovers the holine≈øs of places; in Deut. 19.2, 3. Thou ≈øhalt ≈øeparate three cities for the in thee mid≈øt of thy land, which the Lord thy God giveth thee to po≈ø≈øe≈øs it. And at the ≈øeventh ver≈øe, Wherefore I command thee, ≈øaying, Thou ≈øhalt ≈øeparate three cities for thee. Now you ≈øhall have this again propounded to you in Jo≈øh. 20.7. And they ≈øanctified Kade≈øh in Galilee in Napthali, and Sichem in mount Ephraim, and Kiriath-arba (which is Hebron) in the mountain of Judah. 2. To an≈øwer it more particularly, this ≈øetting apart, or di≈øcrimination, or ≈øeparation of places for holy u≈øes, mu≈øt have the≈øe two properties.

More particularly, concerning this holine≈øs, I de≈øire to ≈øhew you what it is, by ≈øhewing you, it mu≈øt be ≈øuch a holine≈øs and ≈øeparation as that the ≈øervice done to God in tho≈øe places mu≈øt be accounted and looked upon as a better ≈øervice, and more acceptable, then if ≈øo be it had been el≈øewhere, more acceptable to God, and advantagious to our ≈øelves Now, as places are ≈øaid to be holy in regard they are onely to be for holy ≈øervices; ≈øo

More generally, That the cau≈øe and the foundation of a place, or any other thing's holine≈øs, it is its belonging to God, Gods peculiar relation to it, and propriety in it, declared as he ≈øhall plea≈øe, and therefore to be holy, & to be Gods, are the words of the like importance, or equivolence; its being Gods, and his having a relation to it, is the foundation and cau≈øe of its holine≈øs. Herein this place tipifi'd Chri≈øt, one that is onely able to make our ≈øervices acceptable. Hence it is ≈øaid, Exod. 23.17. Three times in the year all thy Males ≈øhall appear before the Lord. And Acts 27. the Eunuch there went unto that place that God had commanded.

5. He doth command, that he would have the≈øe places reverenced, and no civil employments u≈øed there when the holy ≈øervice was doing, and that after the ≈øervice was done, at that very time the place ≈øhould be only for God.

6. And la≈øtly, He annexed a promi≈øe unto that place, that he would
accept of a duty done there rather than in any other place, even becau≈øe it was done there; hence they prayed in the Temple, rather than in their private hou≈øes, Luke 2.27. and when they could not be pre≈øent, by rea≈øon of Gods providence, in the Temple, if they do but look to the City and the temple, God accepted of their duty, 1 Kings 8.48. So that God did promi≈øe that that place that he had in≈øtituted for his wor≈øhip and ≈øervice, that the ≈øervice performed there ≈øhould be more acceptable to him than el≈øe-where. This ≈øhews the rea≈øon and foundation of a places holine≈øs, the precept of God, and the promi≈øe and pre≈øence of God. And thus I have opened to you the ≈øecond thing. Now having thus explained and opened the Que≈øtion to you;
2. I come to re≈øolve the Que≈øtion, according to what I think in my con≈øcience to be the truth of God; and this I ≈øhall do two ways.

list.item: 1. By granting that which mu≈øt not be denyed.
2. By denying what mu≈øt not be granted.

div.p: 1. By granting what mu≈øt not be denyed: and here I grant willingly the≈øe four things.

1. That in the time of the Go≈øpel; it is not onely lawful, but it is often very commendable and nece≈ø≈øary, to de≈øign and dedicate places unto God. Now when I ≈øay, it is lawful to de≈øign them and to dedicate them; I pray you bear me witne≈øs, I do not ≈øay it is lawful to con≈øecrate them, or to ≈øanctifie them; but I ≈øay it is lawful to de≈øign and dedicate them. Now for this take notice, That between
1. The de≈øigning and appointing of a place;
2. the dedication of a place: and
3. the con≈øecrating of a place, there are the≈øe differences.

1. Concerning the de≈øignation of a place, then is a place de≈øigned, when it is appointed to be made u≈øe of for the mo≈øt convenience for ≈øuch a ≈øervice, as Tue≈øday and Wedne≈øday may be appointed for Lecture-days, not con≈øecrated. Now you mu≈øt know, that this de≈øignation of a day may be altered, and ≈øo may a place: if ≈øuch a place be de≈øigned, it is in our power to make u≈øe of it, ≈øo as to leave off the u≈øe of it when we plea≈øe.

2. As to dedication, I mean ≈øo lawfully to dedicate a place, which is of our own right to di≈øpo≈øe of; ≈øo to dedicate it, as not again to be able to revoke it, or call it back from ≈øuch a u≈øe and purpo≈øe. It is lawful and commendable for a rich man to dedicate ≈øo much ground, or money, for building a Hou≈øe for a Free-School, or for the poor, and to give it away from our ≈øelves, and from our own right and power: and if ≈øo be that a man hath power or propriety over a place or thing, it is lawful for a man to alienate ≈øuch a thing. And yet this you mu≈øt know by the way, that this Dedication that now is in the time of the Go≈øpel, doth very much differ
from that dedication of Free-will-offering unto God in the time of the Law; for they were dedicated to God in the time of the Law immediately, that is, to his immediate Wor≈øhip; it was part of Gods Wor≈øhip, it was a part of Religion to do that thing: whereas it is not now dedicated to the immediate Wor≈øhip of God, but it is dedicated immediately to ≈øuch a Prie≈øt, or Mini≈øter, or Place, or company of people, that we have a good will to gratifie; and ≈øo it more remotely redounds to Gods glory not immediately. For God hath not declared in his Word the ≈øame acceptation in the Go≈øpel of things done in an immediate way, as he had in the time of the Law, of which acceptation now we have no ≈øuch promi≈øe. And therefore it is ob≈øervable, as one ≈øpeaks concerning that Benefactor in the Go≈øpel to the Jews, He hath loved our Nation, and builded us a Synagogue; it is not ≈øaid, for God, but for us: This man out of love to us hath be≈øtowed the≈øe things to God; which though a giving our ≈øelves out of our own power, yet it doth differ from the Free-will-offering in the time of the Law. Ay, but now, Sirs, ye mu≈øt know, that ≈øanctification, or con≈øecration, that is a great deal more; when we ≈øanctifie a thing, or con≈øecrate a thing, this thing that is ≈øo con≈øecrated, it is ≈øo holy, that there mu≈øt nothing at all of unholine≈øs, or of a civil or ≈øecular employment and concernment be done in it. Now we do not dedicate a thing, but there may be ≈øecular things in an ordinary and civil way done in them; and our ≈øervices are not more acceptable for the place, nor the places le≈øs holy becau≈øe of tho≈øe civil employments. There is the fir≈øt conce≈ø≈øion, that in the time of the Go≈øpel there may be a de≈øignment and dedication of places, and it is not only lawful, but commendable.

2. I grant, that in times of the Go≈øpel, ≈øome places are to have Religious ≈øervices performed in them, rather than in other places; I mean places of natural conveniency, and fitne≈øs for the meeting of people together, whereby they may be free from di≈øturbance, from the violence of Enemies, and from tempe≈øtuous weather. As publick meetings, whereby we have the ≈øociety of Gods people, their examples to ≈øtir us up to zeal, and their joynt help in prayer and holy performances, to go along with us, that we may joyn our forces together, and with a great force wre≈øtle with God, and overcome him which is invincible. And therefore, my Brethren, I de≈øire you to bear me witne≈øs this day, that I plead for publick Ordinances, & for the purity of Gods Ordinances to be admini≈øtred in publick places, rather than other places; ≈øo that I do here profe≈øs, that I do avowedly and openly declare my judgement to be for publick meetings in publick places, and the purity of Gods Ordinances, if they may be enjoyed without humane mixture, which may hurt and pollute them.

3. I grant, that in the time of holy ≈øervice, we are not then to u≈øe ≈øecular employments at that time in tho≈øe places, as eating, drinking, and talking, it being un≈øuitable to the work in hand; and how≈øoever they may be lawful at another time, yet unlawful then, becau≈øe again≈øt the Apo≈øtles command, Let all things be done in decency, and in order; and that which is un≈øuitable to the commands of God, the taking his Name in vain. My Brethren, I will go further with you, we are to ab≈øtain from all other Religious Services, when not in ≈øea≈øon; and therefore when the Mini≈øter is in Preaching, we mu≈øt not run into our places and kneel down, as ≈øome people do, and fall a praying. And I cannot but wonder, that they that do ≈øo much cry up Uniformity and Sanctity of places, that yet they ≈øhould con≈øure their judgment by their practice, that they ≈øhould pray ≈øecretly, when the whole Congregation is a praying vocally; and it may be the Congregation is ≈øinging a P≈øalm, or the Mini≈øter Preaching, and then they go to their Prayers; I pray where is the Uniformity, Decency, and Order they ≈øo much ≈øtand for?

La≈øtly, I grant, that after the performances of holy duties, in places wherein we meet for the Wor≈øhip and Service of God, it is our duty to ab≈øtain, not only from filthy and indecent actions of a natural or moral filthine≈øs, un≈øeemly, as looked upon by men again≈øt Gods Laws; but from all tho≈øe civil, moral, lawful actions, at other times, they may reflect any di≈øhonour upon the work that hath been done, or upon the work that ≈øhall be done, or that may render the place unmeet for Religious Services afterwards: And this is that that one calls a Negative, or private reverence, a reverence or not doing ≈øomething, not becau≈øe the place is more holy, but for decency and order, con≈øidering the Religious Duties performed in that place. So that things ≈øub≈øervient to Religion, call for a Negative reverence, and are not ≈øo to be u≈øed, as that the Religious Services which are there performed and tran≈øacted, ≈øhould be made di≈øgraceful and di≈øhonourable; as the Bread of the Sacrament, after the Sacrament is done, is not lawful to be ca≈øt unto unrea≈øonable creatures, becau≈øe it reflects di≈øhonour upon the Religious Service which we were before doing; ≈øo, dirty water is not to be put into the Communion-Cup, not that the Cup is holy, but becau≈øe it is a reflection of di≈øgrace upon that holy Service wherein that Cup is made u≈øe of; and that Cup is not to be made u≈øe of to drunkenne≈øs. But in all this bear me witne≈øs that I ≈øay, all this is but a civil reverence, and ≈øo due to any place where there is any Honourable Convention, as in the Parliament-Hou≈øe, or Pre≈øence Chamber, or the like. Having yielded this:
2. I mu≈øt come now to deny what mu≈øt not be granted: and I likewi≈øe deny four thing.

1. It is not now in the times of the Go≈øpel in any mans power to ≈øet apart a place for Religious duties, ≈øo as that it ≈øhould be unlawful upon a due occa≈øion to u≈øe it for civil employments, or that it ≈øhould be always unlawful to alienate to other u≈øes, be≈øides tho≈øe u≈øes that are Divine; the Bread and Wine ≈øanctified by Gods own in≈øtitution, by the Mini≈øter, after the publick u≈øe and admini≈øtration of them in the Ordinance, are not now holy, but they may be eaten in a civil u≈øe and way as our ordinary and common food. The Synagogues among the Jews were as holy as our Churches, they were for Holy duties, as Prayer, Preaching, and the like, and dedicated to Gods Wor≈øhip, and yet you mu≈øt know there were Civil employments u≈øed in tho≈øe places after the Religious Wor≈øhip was done; and therefore in Mat. 23.34. ≈øaith our Saviour, Some of them you ≈øhall ≈øcourge in your Synagogues. Hence we u≈øe to keep Courts and Con≈øi≈øtories in Churches among≈øt us, and ≈øome of them none of the be≈øt, and we u≈øe here among us in this City con≈øtantly in our Churches, (and I doubt not but it is lawful) for an Alderman in his Ward to meet about ≈øecular bu≈øine≈øs, as to chu≈øe Common-Council-men, or the like. But where there hath been a dedication of a place to Gods Wor≈øhip, it is onely God that can make it ≈øo holy, as that it ≈øhould be ≈øinful to imploy it to other u≈øes, and if the Governours of the Church upon due occa≈øion and rea≈øon ≈øhall ≈øub≈øtitute other places more fit than the former for Divine Wor≈øhip, then the former places may return to their former proper u≈øes; but it is not ≈øo in things con≈øecrated by God: If the Font, Table, or Pulpit wax old, they may be layed a≈øide and looked upon as common things, and may be u≈øed for other employments; and ≈øuppo≈øe the Surplice be a lawful Garment in Gods Wor≈øhip, (which yet I am per≈øwaded none of you believe) doubtle≈øs it is not to be burned, when it is old and pa≈øt wearing, and the a≈øhes put into a pot or ≈øome ≈øuch like thing, and be buried under the Altar, but it may be u≈øed as other linnen may. And ≈øo the common Uten≈øils, as the Cup, and the like, when they are come to be old, they may be u≈øed for other employments, without fear of ≈øin. And therefore it is an excellent ≈øpeech of one, ≈øaith he; So to Con≈øecrate moveable or immoveable goods, as that it ≈øhould be a ≈øin for the Church to u≈øe them in any ≈øecular employments, it is an execrable and abominable ≈øuper≈øtition: God hath not con≈øecrated any thing in the Go≈øpel ≈øo, as that it is a ≈øin to u≈øe it otherwi≈øe. It was a ≈øin in them to make u≈øe of the Cups, in the Temple, in any ≈øecular way, but it is not ≈øo for us: the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe tho≈øe things were ≈øet apart by Gods own in≈øtitution:
but there can be nothing ≈øo con≈øecrated by men, as that it may not be made u≈øe of in ≈øecular things without ≈øin.

2. A ≈øecond thing I deny is, That no place now in the time of the Go≈øpel hath ≈øuch an holine≈øs either from In≈øtitution or U≈øe, as to ≈øanctifie or make more acceptable or effectual the Services therein performed: This is not in the time of the Go≈øpel; God is pre≈øent at places of Religious performances, not with re≈øpect unto the place, but the performance by him in≈øtituted and enjoyned; and therefore he doth not ≈øay, Where two or three are met together, I will be in the mid≈øt of that place, but among them. God will be pre≈øent in the place for the Duties ≈øake, not among them for the Places ≈øake, but the Duties ≈øake in the place, to ble≈øs the Ordinance for his own In≈øtitution ≈øake. Prayers and other Duties in the Ceremonial Law were regarded for the Places ≈øake, but now we mu≈øt abhor this piece of Judai≈øm: For a man to ≈øet a place apart by Con≈øecration, that this place makes the Duty any thing the more excellent, or acceptable to God, this is to make the Traditions of men equal to the In≈øtitution of God. The Temple ≈øanctified the Duty, but not the Synagogue; and the Altar did ≈øanctifie the Gift, and the Per≈øon and Service, becau≈øe it was by Gods In≈øtitution, and ≈øo the Temple and Altar did add efficacy and worth to the work; but for men to Con≈øecrate the Church, it is to make the appointment of men equal with the In≈øtitution of God. Our Churches and Meeting-places, are not holy (if they be holy at all) without relation to the Duties performed, but our Duties are holy without relation to the Church or the Place. None but God can Con≈øecrate a place to be an effectual means of Wor≈øhip. The Jews wor≈øhipped God by the Temple, but we wor≈øhip God in the Church, as the place doth afford a natural conveniency for our meeting together; the place then hath no influence at all upon our duties, and if any of you ≈øhould think ≈øo, you do erre exceedingly: It is but only a Phy≈øical act of Duty, or a natural Adjunct of duty, which is but at the mo≈øt helpful to the bodies conveniency.

3. The third thing I deny is this, That there is no place ≈øo holy as to exclude another place from being as holy in a way of proper ≈øanctity and holine≈øs, which we have been now opening. God now makes not one place properly more holy than another; there is not now properly any Religious difference of places. We have not now the precept of God to ≈øanctifie and ≈øeparate one place from another, to preferre one place before another; we have not now the miraculous Pre≈øence of God, his appearing as at the Bu≈øh. God hath not given us under the Go≈øpel tho≈øe Symboles of his ≈øtanding Pre≈øence and Re≈øidency, as by the Ark, and
Mercy-Seat, and Altar of old, he gave unto his People. And as for his Ordinances, if they make a place holy in regard of performance of Duty to God there, and his ≈øpiritual pre≈øence in that place, then my Parlour, Chamber, or Clo≈øet are holy where I u≈øe to pray; and where God doth afford his a≈ø≈øi≈øting ble≈ø≈øing, and comforting pre≈øence: So that if you make the ≈øpiritual pre≈øence of God to make a thing holy, in regard of Gods ≈øpiritual pre≈øence going along with tho≈øe ≈øervices, then your Hou≈øes are holy, and the Field is holy where you walk when you meditate, and praying by the River ≈øide makes it holy: Humane Con≈øecration makes no place truly holy. If the ≈øpiritual pre≈øence of Chri≈øt makes one place more holy than another, then the Communion-Table and Font are more holy than any other place in the Temple. And ≈øo when Gods pre≈øence hath been enjoyed at the Font, that is more holy than the Communion-Table; and ≈øo when the pre≈øence of God hath been enjoyed at the Communion-Table, that is more holy than the Font, and ≈øo you mu≈øt bring in Judai≈øm. If the pre≈øence of God makes a thing holy, a new Communion-Table, upon which the Sacraments was never admini≈øtred, cannot be ≈øo holy as the old Table. Nay, by this the mouths of the Communicants are holy, having eaten the Bread, and drank the Wine which was dedicated to an holy u≈øe, and ≈øo it will be ≈øinful for you to eat any other food. I conclude all with this, That the difference and holine≈øs of Religious places in the times of the Go≈øpel, is not given, but taken away by the Go≈øpel, 1 Tim. 2.8. I will therefore that men pray every where, lifting up holy hands without wrath and doubting. You may pray, and that with as much acceptablene≈øs to God in one place as in another, John 4.21. Chri≈øt ≈øaith, The time comes when you ≈øhall neither in this Mountain, nor yet at Jeru≈øalem, wor≈øhip the Father: That is, Gods Wor≈øhip and Service ≈øhall not be confined and limited to tho≈øe places, as if others were not as good and holy as they. 1 Cor. 1.2. To them that are ≈øanctified in Chri≈øt Je≈øus, called to be Saints, with all that in every place call upon the Name of Je≈øus Chri≈øt our Lord, both theirs and ours. One place for the calling upon Chri≈øt is as good as another; and therefore, Where two or three are gathered together, I will be in the mid≈øt of them. And this is fore-told in Zeph. 2.11. and in Mal. 1.11. So that this is the ≈øum of all, Gods In≈øtitution makes the Sabbath holy; and the Bread and the Wine ≈øet apart by Gods own In≈øtitution, after the duty, may be u≈øed in ≈øecular u≈øes

But fourthly and la≈øtly, to name no more, No place is ≈øo ≈øanctified by God, as that after the cea≈øing of that pre≈øence of God, any holine≈øs ≈øhould belong unto it; as now when the ≈øigns and tokens of Gods pre≈øence
cea≈øed and was gone, the holine≈øs of that place was gone, and then it was lawful for Mo≈øes to put on his ≈øhooes. And ≈øo when Gods pre≈øence cea≈øed in the Ark, the Altar, and Mercy-≈øeat, the places became no other than ≈øecular, and civil. And now for us to go about (as the Papi≈øts do) a Pilgrimage to Jeru≈øalem, as if that place had any more holine≈øs than others, is a fooli≈øh and abominable thing: How many bloody Battels have been fought, to the di≈øgrace, as well as the lo≈øs of Chri≈øtianity, for the regaining of the Holy Land.

Nay, let me add, tho≈øe places where the pre≈øence of God hath been formerly, when it hath taken away, and tho≈øe places have been u≈øed to Idolatry, they are the wor≈øe, and the more unholy; for this is turning the Hou≈øe of God into vanity.

The conclu≈øion of all is this: whatever places are in holy duties, out of them they lo≈øe and leave all their holine≈øs; and therefore I ≈øay it is boldne≈øs for us to go about to tie Gods pre≈øence to a place where God hath never tied it: I cannot but wonder how it is po≈ø≈øible for men of rea≈øon and learning to be ≈øo blind, as to hold that the Lords day (which was ≈øet apart by God for the Sabbath, as you may ≈øee in the fourth Commandment, and afterwards by Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles, which doth amount to no le≈øs than an In≈øtitution) is not holy after the Service or Sermon is ended, but then you may go play at Foot-ball, and Cudgels, and Drinking, and what not; and yet they ≈øhould ≈øay that the place of performing Religious duties in, is ≈øo holy after Religious performances, as that you cannot come into it without bowing the knee, and putting off the hat, and bowing to the Altar and Communion-Table, and the like; this I cannot apprehend how it ≈øhould be, and I wi≈øh any of you that are of this mind, would privately give me your rea≈øons for it, why it ≈øhould be ≈øo.
Now having explained the Point, and given you a re≈øolution of the que≈øtion, in the≈øe particulars, give me leave to winde up all with ≈øome U≈øes.

Fir≈øt, We infer the great difference that is between ≈øanctity of places under the Old Te≈øtament, and ≈øanctity and holine≈øs of places under the New Te≈øtament: they under the Old Te≈øtament had the immediate pre≈øence of God, the ≈øtanding Symbols, and vi≈øible ≈øigns of his pre≈øence, ≈øo long as the≈øe la≈øted: which was ≈øet apart by Gods ≈øpecial Commandment, and ≈øo they were holy, though they were not employed in a way of wor≈øhip; but you cannot ≈øay ≈øo now, our places for performance of holy duties have no ≈øuch holine≈øs; places now differ from places then.

Secondly, by way of inference, I note the great goodne≈øs of God to give us ≈øuch a ≈øweet and gracious indulgent di≈øpen≈øation in the time of the Go≈øpel under the New Te≈øtament, as that he doth not tye us to Ceremonies or places; he doth not bind us as he did the Jews to go three times in the year to the furthermo≈øt part of the Nation to wor≈øhip: No my Brethren, no Land, no ground is now unholy, as famous old Doctor Reynolds ≈øaid, every place is now a Judea, no Coa≈øt but is a Judea, every hou≈øe is a Jeru≈øalem, every Congregation is now a Sion: See here the goodne≈øs of God in indulging of us ≈øo far as to take any ≈øervice done by us in a ≈øolemn and real manner, as if it had been done in tho≈øe places which were formerly appointed for it to be done in.
Thirdly, I infer hence, there are ≈øeveral per≈øons to be reproved.

list.item: 1. We find hereby that all the holine≈øs of Relicks of Saints doth fall to the ground, and we ≈øee the folly of tho≈øe that make Pilgrimages unto Saints and Reliques as the Papi≈øts do: there was a time (≈øay they) when ≈øuch a Saints Relicks were laid up in ≈øuch a place, and the≈øe are more holy then other places: ≈øo that this you ≈øee falls to the ground in its ≈øelf: I might tell you concerning their lying about their Relicks, as one ≈øaid, that there were as many Reliques as would fill an hundred Carts: but ≈øuppo≈øing ≈øo, all that would not make that place the more holy.

2. Hence the ≈øuper≈øtition of tho≈øe is to be reproved, which put holine≈øs in place of Burial, and make it more holy to be buried in one place then in another: it is more holy (≈øay they) to be buried in the Church then in the Church-yard; and more holy under the Communion-Table then in any other part of the Church.

3. This reproves them which cannot pray any where but in the Temple, and they that u≈øe private prayers in Churches: if you have hou≈øes and Rooms at home, what is the rea≈øon that if Pauls or any other Church ≈øtand open you mu≈øt run in thither, and drop down behind a Pillar to ≈øay your Prayers.

4. This reproves them that have reverence towards any place more then another, as if they did de≈øerve more holine≈øs in one part then another, as bowing to the Altar, or Communion-Table, or the like.

5. It reproves tho≈øe that have reverence for ≈øcituation of the≈øe places, they mu≈øt ≈øtand Ea≈øt and We≈øt, and why not North and South? All the≈øe things fall off, like Fig-leaves: if what I have ≈øaid be true, that there is no holine≈øs in places; and this I have made known to you not only as my judgment, but as my duty.

div.p:
Now for exhortation, I ≈øhall de≈øire you to take notice of four things, and I have done, and ≈øhall leave you to God, and commit you to the
word of his grace. If this be ≈øo, that there is no holine≈øs in places, then fir≈øt of all, bee the more encouraged to ≈øerve God in your Families, in tho≈øe places where God hath ≈øet you, where God is as well plea≈øed with your ≈øervice as in publick places, ≈øerve God upon your knees with devotion, humility and reverence. And therefore, though I am again≈øt Super≈øtition, and Popi≈øh practices, and tho≈øe wicked cur≈øed traps of innovations, that the men of the World have di≈øturbed the Church of God with; yet I am again≈øt putting on your Hats in prayer; and ≈øitting in Prayer. Tho≈øe that are for holine≈øs of places, do not, with Abraham, in every place they come build God an Altar. But let us in every clo≈øet and room build God an Altar; let no morning nor evening go without a Prayer in thy Family, pray often, and pray continually, let your hou≈øes be as ≈øo many Churches, as you read in Rom. 16.5. Likewi≈øe greet the Church that is in their Hou≈øe: and in the ≈øecond ver≈øe of Philemons Epi≈øtle, To the Church that is in thy Hov≈øe; There the Hou≈øes of the Saints are called Churches. This will bring a ble≈ø≈øing upon your Families: And if you be not willing to have that cur≈øe denounced again≈øt you, (in Jer. 10.25. Pour out fury upon the Heathen that know thee not, and upon the families that call not upon thy Name) then neglect not Family-Prayers, be much in Prayer, and pray with frequency and encouragement, becau≈øe God binds you to no place.

For the Application of this Point;

Fir≈øt, Let us begin with tho≈øe that our bu≈øine≈øs at pre≈øent doth not mainly lye on. Mu≈øt men walk in Chri≈øt as they have received him? epigraph.q: And he that ≈øent me, is with me: the Father hat not left me alone: for I do alwaies tho≈øe things that plea≈øe him.

div.p:
THe≈øe are the words of our ble≈ø≈øed Lord and Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt, they are ≈øpoken by him≈øelf: and they are ≈øpoken of him≈øelf; though yet in a ≈øober and mode≈øt ≈øence they are applicable to all his Members: that which Chri≈øt here affirms, is that the pre≈øence of God was always with him, and this is fir≈øt propounded, He that ≈øent me is with me, and then it is amplified, and the Father hath not
left me alone; and then thirdly, the rea≈øon of this is annexed, for I always do tho≈øe things that plea≈øe him.

I ≈øhall ≈øpeak but very little of the words as they do refer to Chri≈øt: he tells us where his Father was with him, he did not leave him alone in all the troubles and difficulties that he met withal in the fini≈øhing the great work of mans Redemption; ≈øtill God was with him: It is true, there was a time when Chri≈øt was without the ≈øen≈øible manife≈øtation of his Fathers pre≈øence, when he cryed out, My God, my God, why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken me? Why, but yet even then in truth and in reality his Father did not leave him; for though he had not the evidences of his Fathers pre≈øence, yet he had the influences of his Fathers pre≈øence. It would take up much time to ≈øhew you how in all particulars the Father was pre≈øent with Chri≈øt; I will onely ≈øpeak this one word, and in≈øtance in this one thing, Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øting pre≈øence was always with him, both in his active, and al≈øo in his pa≈ø≈øive obedience; and indeed he had that work to do, and tho≈øe mi≈øeries to ≈øuffer, that if God had left him, if he had not been mightily a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Divine Nature, Chri≈øt as meer man, could neither have done, nor have ≈øuffered what he did; but the Father was with him, and to ≈øupport him, I≈øa. 42.1. Behold my ≈øervant whom I uphold. You ≈øhall find that Chri≈øt did act faith upon this, in I≈øai. 50.7. The Lord God will help me, therefore ≈øhall I not be confounded, ver≈ø 9. The Lord will help me. So to the ≈øame effect is P≈øal. 16.9. And you ≈øhall find this made good to him in Scripture, in his greate≈øt nece≈ø≈øities.
Take a double in≈øtance.

In the fir≈øt place, after he bad been engaged in the combat with Satan, you read in Mat. 4. the ≈øtronge≈øt combate or duel that ever was fought; wherein you have the Prince of Peace and the Prince of darkne≈øs; the Lion of the Tribe of Judah, and the roaring Lion that ≈øeeks how to devour; both of them putting forth their utmo≈øt ≈øtrength, and endeavouring to overcome each other: Now I ≈øay in this combate, the Father did not leave Chri≈øt, but he helps him; for he ≈øends an Angel to mini≈øter unto him, Mat. 4.11.

So in Chri≈øts bitter Agony in the Garden, ju≈øt before his bitter Pa≈ø≈øion and death upon the Cro≈øs, the Father did not leave him alone, for he ≈øent an Angel unto him to ≈øtrengthen him, Luk. 22.43. and ≈øo in ≈øeveral other places, and in ≈øeveral other things I might in≈øtance; but I ≈øhall pa≈øs this by. I but now why did the Father thus ≈øtand by Chri≈øt? he gives you the rea≈øon of it in the Text, becau≈øe he always did the things that plea≈øed him: This I ≈øhall open in a double re≈øpect.

Fir≈øt, Chri≈øts undertaking of the work of our Redemption; it was
very well plea≈øing unto his Father, that poor lo≈øt undone ≈øinners ≈øhould be brought back again unto God, and re≈øtored unto his love and favour: I ≈øay the Father was infinitely well plea≈øed with Chri≈øt in this undertaking. I≈øa. 35.10. The plea≈øure of the Lord ≈øhall pro≈øper in his hand; the plea≈øure of the Lord, that is the work of our Redemption; wherein God the Father took great plea≈øure or delight; therefore when Chri≈øt was publickly in the eye of the world to enter upon this great work, the Father ≈øends him out with this witne≈øs. Secondly, as the work it ≈øelf was well plea≈øing unto God, ≈øo Chri≈øt managing of this work, was all along plea≈øing unto his Father; & that doth appear in this, that Chri≈øt in all things kept to his Fathers Commi≈ø≈øion, and to his Fathers Command: I ≈øay in all things he kept to his Fathers Commi≈ø≈øion: he did nothing here upon earth, but what was within the compa≈øs of his Commi≈ø≈øion; for ≈øaith he in the ver≈øe before the Text, I do nothing of my ≈øelf, but as my Father bids me: So al≈øo he acted in conformity to his Fathers will; that was the rule and ≈øquare by which Chri≈øt ordered all his actions; his eye was ≈øtill upon his Fathers will; whatever he willed him to do, that he did; whatever he willed him to ≈øuffer, that he ≈øuffered; and thus he always did the things that were plea≈øing to his Father: but I do not intend further upon the words in this reference; for my de≈øign is to bring down the words unto our ≈øelves, to tho≈øe that are the Members of Chri≈øt; for there is the ≈øame di≈øpo≈øition of heart in all Believers to plea≈øe God: In all things to plea≈øe God; this was the frame and temper and carriage of Chri≈øt; ≈øo it is the frame & temper of every true believer: and this is a part of our likene≈øs unto Chri≈øt; as you know there is a ble≈ø≈øed re≈øemblance & ≈øimilitude between Chri≈øt and his Members; they have the ≈øame Spirit that Chri≈øt had, only in a different proportion; for he had it without mea≈øure; they have the ≈øame Grace as Chri≈øt had for ≈øub≈øtance, though not for degree; Of his fulne≈øs we all have received grace for grace; that is, as many interpret it, Grace an≈øwerable unto grace: As the print in the wax an≈øwers to the print in the Seal, & as face an≈øwers to face; ≈øo grace in believers an≈øwers unto that grace that was in Chri≈øt; they are to ≈øhew forth the vertues of Chri≈øt, 1 Pet. 2.11. Now this was the grace and vertue and holine≈øs of Chri≈øt, that he always did the things that plea≈øed his Father. Why this is in all believers, only with this difference; it was actual performance in the one, it is but endeavour in the other; it was perfect in the one, it is ≈øincere, but imperfect in the other.

Chri≈øt always did things that plea≈øed God, a Believer endeavours always
to do the things that plea≈øe God, he doth not always do ≈øo; witne≈øs David in the ca≈øe of his uncleanne≈øs, when he di≈øplea≈øed the Lord, as it is in 2 Sam. 11.
The Ob≈øervation I intend to ≈øpeak to, ≈øhall be this:

p.hi: They that plea≈øe God, and endeavour always to do the things that plea≈øe God, ≈øuch God will be with; ≈øuch the Father will not leave alone; e≈øpecially in times of ≈øuffering and trouble, for I will bring it that at ca≈øe.

div.p: Indeed God will not leave ≈øuch at any time; for that promi≈øe is exceeding full, Heb. 13.5. I will never leave thee, nor for≈øake thee. I do not know any one promi≈øe in all the Bible, that is expre≈øt with ≈øuch an Empha≈øis as that promi≈øe is; ≈øuch a multiplication of Negatives in the Original. But e≈øpecially God will not leave ≈øuch in an afflicted and ≈øuffering condition.
In the pro≈øecution of this, I will ≈øpeak to four things:

Fir≈øt, I will ≈øhew you when a man may be ≈øaid to do the things that plea≈øe God.
2. I will confirm the truth of the doctrine.
3. I will ≈øhew you in what re≈øpects God will be with them that de≈øire to plea≈øe him in a ≈øuffering condition.
4. I will give you the grounds and rea≈øons of it; and then I ≈øhall come to an Application.

For the fir≈øt, We plea≈øe God in what we do, when we act. 1. In a ≈øuitablene≈øs to Gods nature. And 2. In ≈øubjection to Gods Law: For plea≈øing of God lies in the≈øe two things. As that plea≈øes a man which is ≈øuitable to his di≈øpo≈øition, and is corre≈øpondent with his command: We do the things that plea≈øe God, when we do the things that God doth; and when we do that which God commands: when we hate ≈øin, as God hates ≈øin; when we are holy as God is holy. You ≈øhall find it in Col. 1.10. That you may walk worthy of God, unto all well plea≈øing. Ob≈øerve, This walking worthy of God, is walking ≈øuitably, or walking an≈øwerably to God, Mat. 3.8. Bring forth fruit worthy of Repentance, or bring forth fruit an≈øwerable to Repentance; So to walk worthy of God, is to walk ≈øuitable to God, to his nature: Now then ob≈øerve what follows, that you might walk worthy of God to all well-plea≈øing, then we plea≈øe God when we walk ≈øuitably unto God: So al≈øo when we act in a ble≈ø≈øed conformity to God, to his law; for nothing can plea≈øe the good God, but what is good: Now the Law being the mea≈øure, and ≈øtandard of all goodne≈øs, nothing can be good, but what bears conformity to this Law, which is the will of God. God is wel-plea≈øed, when his will is ob≈øerved: As you know, you that are Ma≈øters, your ≈øervants plea≈øe you when they do your will. That inference of the Apo≈øtle, for this is very oppo≈øite, Rom. 8.8. So then they that are in the fle≈øh cannot plea≈øe God. What is this ≈øame inference

Why? becau≈øe there is that principle in them, as carries out a real enmity to the Law and Will of God; it is as if the Apo≈øtle had ≈øaid, They will not be ≈øubject to Gods will, not obedient to Gods command; there is a principle of enmity in them again≈øt the≈øe things, & ≈øo cannot plea≈øe God: God is plea≈øed when his will is fulfilled, & his commands ob≈øerved; to plea≈øe God, is in all things ≈øo to act, that whatever we do, we may expre≈øs a likene≈øs to Gods na ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and a ble≈ø≈øed ≈øubjection to Gods revealed will, and this is the fir≈øt thing.

A ≈øecond thing is the proof of the Doctrine; they that thus plea≈øe God, he will be with them, he will not leave them alone; e≈øpecially in an hour of tryal: For, my Brethren, a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelves of this, that which the Father did for Chri≈øt, he will do for all his Members, 'tis true, Chri≈øts ≈øufferings being greater then ours po≈ø≈øibly can be, and ≈øo his relation to God being higher then ours is; he a Son by eternal Generation, we onely by adoption; he had the pre≈øence of God in a more glorious manner then we can expect; but yet in our Sphere according to the mea≈øure of our tryals, and according to our capacity, we ≈øhall as really have the pre≈øence of God with us, as Chri≈øt had with him; that as we are partakers of Chri≈øts ≈øufferings, ≈øo we al≈øo ≈øhall be partakers of Chri≈øts ≈øupport; he that will be pre≈øent with believers in heaven, as he is with Chri≈øt, he will be pre≈øent with believers here on earth, as he is with Chri≈øt in all his ≈øorrows and ≈øufferings.

Now for the confirming of this comfortable truth, I need not ≈øpeak much: Many promi≈øes you have in Scripture for it, and what ever God hath promi≈øed, he will certainly make good: Turn to that one promi≈øe in ≈øtead of many, I≈øa. 43.2. When thou pa≈ø≈øe≈øt through the water, I will be with thee; through the Rivers, they ≈øhall not overflow thee; when thou walke≈øt through the fire, thou ≈øhalt not be burnt, neither ≈øhall the flame kindle upon thee. Jacob was a man that met with many ≈øharp tryals, God exerci≈øed him with many troubles, you ≈øhall find that when he was going to Padan-Aram, and was in a very afflicted condition, Gen. 28 15. God hath abundantly made out this, and doth ≈øo ≈øtill that he will never leave tho≈øe alone in a time of ≈øuffering, who de≈øire u ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ignedly in all things to plea≈øe God.

N ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the third thing is to ≈øhew you in what re≈øpect God is with ≈øuch: why this pre≈øence of God is an active pre≈øence: God is not meerly with his people, but he is with them in an active way: for this is a certain truth, God is working when the Saints are ≈øuffering, I will open this in ≈øeveral particulars.

Secondly, God is with ≈øuch in his guiding pre≈øence, P≈øal. 73.24. Thou wilt guide me with thy coun≈øel, and afterwards receive me unto glory. Thirdly, God is with them in his pre≈øerving and hiding pre≈øence. God is the Saints hiding place, their ≈øhield, their buckler, their rock, their defence; the Scripture expre≈ø≈øions are many to hold out Gods protection as to his people: God hath a con≈øtant care over them to pre≈øerve them and ≈øave them; oh but e≈øpecially in a time of trouble: as the Marriner is never ≈øo careful of the Ship, as under a ≈øtorm; and God is never ≈øo careful of his Church and people, as under affliction. Fourthly, God is with them in his comforting Pre≈øence, 2 Cor. 4.1. Fifthly, God is with ≈øuch in his ≈øtrengthening pre≈øence, to enable them and to ≈øupport them to undergoe what ever he is plea≈øed to call them unto; this is the way of our good and gracious God; he always gives out ≈øtrength, as he layes on affliction, he never leaves his children alone in this re≈øpect, he will be with them to ≈øupport them: though it may be not to deliver, yet he will certainly be with them to ≈øupport: the Rod and the ≈øtaff they go together, P≈øal. 23.4. the afflicting Rod and the ≈øupporting ≈øtaff: when one is upon the Saint to afflict, then the other hand is underneath the Saint to ≈øupport: I≈øa. 41 10. 2. Such as plea≈øe God, ≈øhall have his pre≈øence under ≈øufferings, becau≈øe now they need God mo≈øt: if God will not leave his people as to temporal ≈øupplies, becau≈øe they need ≈øuch and ≈øuch things: they need meat, and they need cloathing: ≈øurely much more God will not leave his children, as to ≈øpiritual ≈øupplies, under times of di≈øtre≈øs, becau≈øe then they need God. Thus he in≈øinuates him≈øelf, by repre≈øenting what they had done, to encourage them to per≈øeverance: and partly he fortifies them again≈øt Back-≈øliding, by tho≈øe terrible judgements which he threatned again≈øt Revolters, as you read Chap. 6.7.

2. As they were liable to this Apo≈øtacy upon the account of Per≈øecution, ≈øo upon the account of the un≈øettledne≈øs and in≈øtability of their own ≈øpirits. div.p:
The De≈øcription of God, that he amplifies by the≈øe two things:
1. From the Attributes and Qualities of God, (if I may ≈øo expre≈øs it) Now (≈øaith he) the God of Peace.
2. From the effects of his power and love; That brought again from the dead our Lord Je≈øus, that great Shepherd of the Sheep.
And the≈øe Titles, they are not here ≈øet down by the Apo≈øtle to adorn his di≈øcour≈øe, meerly as an ornament, but they have all a peculiar efficacy, as to the obtaining of the reque≈øt which here he makes for them.

I ≈øhall begin with the fir≈øt, the De≈øcription of God from that Attribute. (Now the God of Peace) the Title that is u≈øed in the Old Te≈øtament frequently is this, (The Lord of Ho≈øts) but in the New he is called, The God of peace. There were darker repre≈øentations of the mercy and love of God than, the more full di≈øcoveries of his grace were re≈øerved till the coming of Chri≈øt. Their di≈øcoveries under the Old Te≈øtament were but as the Day-≈øtar, which u≈øhered in the Sun of Righteou≈øne≈øs. Now this title of the God of Peace imparts two things.

list.item: 1. That he is the Author of Peace, and works it.
2. That he loves and delights in peace.

div.p:
Fir≈øt, That he s the Author of it: And if you con≈øider Peace in all its notions and kinds, it is a fruit of God: and that which de≈øcends from him.
1. Peace in Nature is the harmony that is between all the parts of the World, the union that is between the di≈øagreeing Elements that is from God: for without him, the whole Creation would pre≈øently disband, and return to its fir≈øt Chaos of confu≈øion.
2. Civil Peace, which is among the Societies of men, that which is ≈øo amiable and lovely, and which needs no other foil to commend it, and ≈øet off its lu≈øtre, than the mi≈øeries and cruelties of war; this peace comes from God likewi≈øe. Every ra≈øh hand is able to make a wound, or to ca≈øt a Fire-brand, but it is only the God of Peace that is able to heal breaches, and to allay tho≈øe ≈øtorms that are in a Nation. You know tho≈øe ≈øhowers which render the Earth fruitful de≈øcend from Heaven, from God; ≈øo all the coun≈øels of peace de≈øcend from above. The fiery Exaltations a≈øcend from the Earth, Coun≈øels of War & di≈øturbance, proceeded from the devili≈øh hearts of men. Or,
3. If you con≈øider that Rational Peace, which is in the ≈øpirits of men: that is, when the under≈øtanding exerci≈øes a coertion and re≈øtraint over our licentious appetites, when all our inferior Faculties are under the empire and conduct of Rea≈øon; this proceeds al≈øo from God: For, ≈øince the fall, there is a great deal of tumult, many riots and di≈øorders in the ≈øoul of a man: Rea≈øon hates a bad Guide, and our Appetites tho≈øe are evil in≈øtruments, and ≈øo many times hurry Rea≈øon from its regular actings. But,
4. much more if you con≈øider Spiritual Peace, that peace doth not only import an Agreement of a man within him≈øelf, but the Agreement of the ≈øoul with God. This is the fruit of the Spirit, and it is only God that is able to convey this peace to us. And upon a particular account this Title is given to him, by way of eminency and property: as,

1. He is alone able to allow and di≈øpence this peace unto us, for all our ≈øins are injuries committed again≈øt him, again≈øt the Crown and Dignity; all the Arre≈øts of Con≈øcience are made in the Name of God, and therefore 'tis only he that can ≈øpeak peace. As in the civil ≈øtate, it is an Act of Supremacy to give a pardon: only he that can condemn is able to ≈øpeak pardon; ≈øo it is our God that is our Judge, provoked and incen≈øed by us, he hath a judicial power to ca≈øt Body and Soul into Hell fire: is alone able to ≈øpeak peace, and pa≈øs a pardon for us in the Court of Heaven, and this is experienced by a wounded ≈øpirit: It is ju≈øt with ≈øuch a per≈øon as with a Malefactour, who ≈øtands condemned at the Bar, he cannot receive encouragement from any of his ≈øpectators, till the Judge ≈øpeak peace unto him: So if an Angel from Heaven ≈øhould come and ≈øpeak to a wounded Spirit: it were impo≈ø≈øible, unle≈øs God did order, command, and di≈øpence it, that the Spirit ≈øhould receive any peace, becau≈øe our ≈øins are immediately committed again≈øt him.

2. He is alone able to reveal and di≈øcover it; there is nothing harder in the World, than to calm and quiet a di≈øturbed Con≈øcience? it mu≈øt be the ≈øame power that makes light to ≈øpring out of darkne≈øs that mu≈øt cau≈øe a chearful ≈øerenity in a dark and di≈øcon≈øolate Soul. I know there is nothing more ea≈øie than that fal≈øe peace which is ≈øo univer≈øal in the world; for the mo≈øt among≈øt us cheat them≈øelves with pre≈øumption, in≈øtead of peace with God, and ≈øecurity in≈øtead of peace with Con≈øcience, but that peace which is ≈øolid and true, can only be revealed by God him≈øelf. We have an in≈øtance of this in David, P≈øal. 51. although Nathan had told him from God, Thy ≈øin is pardoned; yet notwith≈øtanding he ≈øaith, Make thou me to hear joy and gladne≈øs, that the bones which thou ha≈øt broken may rejoyce. He ≈øtill addre≈ø≈øes him≈øelf to God, that he would cau≈øe him to hear the voice of pardon and reconciliation: for his ≈øoul could not be quiet by the voice of the Prophet. There is ≈øo much infidelity in the ≈øoul of a man, that when he comes to take a view of his ≈øins in all their bloody aggravations, only the Spirit of God him≈øelf, is able to allay the terrors of the Con≈øcience: And this he doth by an over-powering Light, when he doth in an imperative and commanding manner, ≈øilence all the doubts of the ≈øoul, and re≈øtabli≈øh it in peace with God. Certainly, he that ≈øhall but con≈øider the terrors, the faintings, the palene≈øs of a wounded Con≈øcience, when you ≈øhall ≈øee a per≈øon di≈ø-reli≈øh all the things of this World upon this account, fearing le≈øt God is his enemy, when all di≈øcour≈øes that are addre≈øsed to him are ineffectual, and but like warm cloaths, to a dead carka≈ø≈øe,
cannot in≈øpire any heat into him. This ≈øhews, only God is able to reveal peace. So Job, If he hide his face, who is able to be at peace? There needs no other fury to compleat the mi≈øery of a man than his own accu≈øing Con≈øcience: Con≈øcience is a verier Devil than the Devil him≈øelf, and able more to torment and la≈øh the creature. Therefore, if that be once awakened, 'tis only God, to who≈øe Tribunal Con≈øcience is liable, which is able to ≈øpeak peace to the ≈øoul. Now you ≈øee in what re≈øpect this Title [The God of Peace] is attributed to him as he is the Author and Worker of it.

2. As he loves and delights in peace. This is that which is ≈øo plea≈øing to him, that he adopts tho≈øe into the Line of Heaven, who are Peacemakers, for they ≈øhall be called the children of God, Mat. 5.6. This characterizes per≈øons to be his Children, to be allied to him. God he only delights in the reflection of his own Image; for tho≈øe things that we admire in the World, and delight in, do not affect his heart: He delights not in the ≈øtrength of the Hor≈øe, he takes no plea≈øure in the legs of a man: the Lord taketh plea≈øure in them that fear him, in th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe that hope in his mercy. Nothing attracts his eye and heart, but his own ≈øimilitude and re≈øemblance; and therefore where he ≈øees peaceable di≈øpo≈øitions, that is that which endears the ≈øoul to him, and makes it amiable in his eyes. You may judge of his delight in peace by this: It is that grace which in an e≈øpecial manner prepares us for communion with him: for we can never really honour or enjoy him, unle≈øs we bring to him tho≈øe di≈øpo≈øitions which (if I may ≈øo ≈øpeak) are in him≈øelf. And therefore it is no wonder that tho≈øe have little peace of Con≈øcience, who make ≈øo little Con≈øcience of Peace. You know when God appeared to Elijah, he did not appear in the ≈øtorm, nor in the fire, but in the ≈ømall ≈øtill voice, and when Eli≈øha was tran≈øported with anger, he was fain to allay that pa≈ø≈øion by Mu≈øick, that ≈øo he might be prepared for the holy motions of the Spirit, he called for an In≈øtrument, and then the Spirit moved in him; I bring it for this end, to ≈øhew, how God delights in Peace, and he will only maintain communion with tho≈øe that are of calm and peaceable ≈øpirits. So much way as we give to anger, ≈øo much proportionably do we let in the Devil, and ca≈øt out the God of peace.

Now, the rea≈øon why this Title is given to God, is upon a double account, partly with re≈øpect to the Bloud of the everla≈øting Covenant, which made peace between God and us; partly with re≈øpect to the Covenant it it ≈øelf, which is founded in that Bloud.

1. In re≈øpect of the Bloud of the everla≈øting Covenant. For it was the bloud of Chri≈øt that hath ≈øprinkled Gods Throne, and made peace in
Heaven. You ≈øhall read therefore when Chri≈øt came into the World, 'tis ≈øaid, (Luke 2.14.) that the Heavenly ho≈øt appeared and ≈øang, Glory to God in the highe≈øt, and on earth peace, &c. Since the fall God and man are enemies, there is a reciprocal enmity between God and man: God hates the creature as it is unholy, and man hates God as he is ju≈øt, the avenger of ≈øin, the Author of the Law: Now Chri≈øt was the Umpire that compo≈øed this difference, he was God and man in one per≈øon, and ≈øo being allyed to both, he was a fit per≈øon to reconcile both. He was (as Job ≈øpeaks) a days-man between us. He hath paid every farthing that was due; for he did not compound with God, but paid the utmo≈øt that was due to him; He it is that hath reconciled us to God by the power of his ≈øpirit, in changing and renewing our Natures, and Creating in us tho≈øe di≈øpo≈øitions which are like to God; ≈øo that his bloud is the foundation of this peace. And now, God appears to us not as a Con≈øuming Fire, but as a Refre≈øhing Light, full of calmne≈øs, ≈øerenity, and peace towards us. Chri≈øt hath brought more honour to God by his obedience, than we brought di≈øhonor by our tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion; and therefore without any injury to God, he might be at peace with us. You know all our ≈øins were but the acts of finite Creatures, and only infinite in regard of the object again≈øt whom they were committed. But the Bloud of Chri≈øt was of infinite value in regard of the Subject; for, he was God, and the enriching union of the Deity conveyed ≈øuch worth and value to his bloud, that he was able to appea≈øe God, and not only to free us from condemnation, but to make us the favorites of God. We are not only pardoned, but preferred upon the account of his Bloud.

2. He is the God of peace, as with re≈øpect to the bloud of Chri≈øt, which is the purcha≈øe of peace; ≈øo with re≈øpect to the Covenant which is made between God and us, [Through the bloud of the everla≈øting Covenant,] there are three ≈øorts of Covenants among≈øt men; ≈øome are Covenants of Friend≈øhip and Amity, ≈øome are Covenants of Trade and Commerce, and ≈øome are Covenants of A≈ø≈øi≈øtance and Help. It is the Covenant of Trade, there is now a way opened ‚Ä¢ o Heaven, we may now a≈øcend to God in duties of holine≈øs, and God de≈øcends to us by the excitations of his grace and influences „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ And it is a Covenant of A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, for he promi≈øes nor only to
give us the reward of the Covenant, but to ≈øecure unto us the condition, he promi≈øes to enable us to di≈øcharge the condition of Faith and Repentance. Now upon this account of that Covenant which is founded in the bloud of Chri≈øt, he is the God of Peace to his people.

1. ∆≤≈øe is by way of Conviction. This may di≈øcover to us how di≈øtant their temper is from God, who are enemies to peace. We un-man our ≈øelves; We unchri≈øtian our ≈øelves ≈øo far as we are oppo≈øite to this ble≈ø≈øed temper of peace. Certainly as di≈øturbed Water cannot make any reflection unto us of that face that looks into it; ≈øo when our ≈øpirits are di≈øturbed by animo≈øities, exa≈øperations, heats and divi≈øions, 'tis impo≈ø≈øible for us to ≈øee the Image of God, as he is the God of Peace. And certainly there is no more doleful con≈øideration in the World than this, That man whom God made ≈øo ≈øociable a creature, who hath all the engagements and endearments laid upon him, which may cau≈øe him to live in Peace and gentlene≈øs towards tho≈øe who are of the ≈øame nature with him; yet that in fiercene≈øs of our hearts, ≈øhould exceed tho≈øe of the mo≈øt Savage creatures. Man comes into the World naked, and altogether unarmed, as if he were de≈øigned for the picture of Peace; but could you look into the hearts of men, you would find there ≈øuch tumults, ≈øuch divi≈øions, ≈øuch ≈øeeds of enmity again≈øt their fellow-creatures, that Tygers and Lyons are Calm and peaceable in compari≈øon of them. Now how is this di≈øtant from the temper of the God of peace? The≈øe to promote divi≈øions and di≈øturbances among≈øt us, clothe their enemies with the Livery of ≈øhame and reproach, that ≈øo they may be baited by their Fury, that make it their de≈øign to repre≈øent that Party which they think is di≈ø≈øonant from them, with the mo≈øt odious appearances (you know this is the old Art) and tho≈øe ≈øhowres of Calumnies which are in the World, they u≈øually precede the ≈øtorm of per≈øecution. 2. If onely Peace come from God, you may from hence take a tryal of that peace that is within you, (for hither to I have been only di≈øcour≈øing of civil peace) whether it be an effect of this God of Peace. I know nothing more common in the world than pre≈øumption; there is a fal≈øe Peace which doth not ari≈øe from the knowledge of a mans happine≈øs, but from the ignorance of this mi≈øery: Peace, which is only like a Torch to ≈øhine in the night, or like Players that glitter only by Torch-light: ≈øo is the fal≈øe peace men cheri≈øh in their bo≈øom, meerly upon this account, becau≈øe they do not bring their ≈øouls to the light of the Word, they never had it from this God of peace, becau≈øe,
1. God never ≈øpeaks peace to a ≈øoul, but in the way of holine≈øs and obedience: And therefore you ≈øhall find 'tis the coun≈øel of the Scripture, Acquaint thy ≈øelf with God, and be at peace.

2. That peace that comes from God, always cau≈øes in us a war with ≈øin, for Gods Covenant with us is Offen≈øive and Defen≈øive; and therefore it is impo≈ø≈øible any per≈øon ≈øhould have true and ≈øolid peace, that waking tranquility of ≈øoul, which is the reward of holine≈øs and obedience, that entertains ≈øin; for every ≈øin thou do≈øt wilfully commit, 'tis an act of ho≈øtility again≈øt God, 'tis that which makes him thine enemy, and makes thee an enemy to him, As Jehu ≈øaid, What peace, ≈øo long as the whoredom of thy mother Jezabel and her witcherafts are ≈øo many? ∆≤≈øe. 2. By way of exhortation; let me pre≈øs you all to follow peace, it is a duty which the Go≈øpel injoyns with the greate≈øt force of words and expre≈ø≈øions.
