Is not God of infinite power, of infinite love? then it ≈øhould quicken us to pur≈øue peace. 1. By prayer to him, becau≈øe he is able to effect it; certainly that God that was able to bring Order into the World, when it was a meer lump and ma≈øs of confu≈øion, is able to bring peace, and to unite our ≈øpirits.

And it is ob≈øervable, the greater our differences and divi≈øions are, the more will the power of this God appear in reconciling them. 'Tis ≈øaid in the P≈øalms, that Gods throne is in darkne≈øs; that is, his ways of Providence are very difficult for us to trace and find out; and therefore when our divi≈øions are at the highe≈øt, he is able by one word to allay the ≈øtorm. This ≈øhould encourage us in Prayer. This is the cour≈øe of God to glorifie him≈øelf, by putting a ≈øtop to the greate≈øt troubles when neare≈øt to us, and to work out one contrary by another. To give you ≈øome in≈øtances, that ≈øo we may encourage our Faith, and quicken our Prayer to God for this ble≈ø≈øing, con≈øider how ≈øtill God hath made difficulties the way for enjoyment: For in≈øtance, the promi≈øe that Sarah ≈øhould be the Mother of a child; but he made way for that by her dead Womb, for all that numerous Progeny which like the Stars of the Skie de≈øcended from her. That he fir≈øt maimed Jacob, and then gave him the ble≈ø≈øing. He brought Jo≈øeph from the Pri≈øon to a Princely Palace. Fir≈øt David was hara≈ø≈øed with troubles, and then his head was deckt with the Imperial Crown. So if you look into the Kingdom of Chri≈øt, who would have thought that a few Fi≈øhermen-men ≈øhould have advanced the Empire of Chri≈øt in the World? Had you lived to have ≈øeen tho≈øe de≈øpicable beginnings, when a few unlearned men were the Heraulds and Preachers of Chri≈øt, how would this have cau≈øed you to fail and ≈øink in your ≈øpirits! and yet the Go≈øpel hath been Preached in all parts of the World, and that by a few Fi≈øher-men. The Providences of God are like tho≈øe plated Pictures, if you look one way upon them, there is the appearance of a Serpent; if you look on the other ≈øide, there is the appearance of an Angel. So here, many times God is plea≈øed to ≈øuffer exa≈øperations
to go very high, that ≈øo his power may appear more eminent in the compo≈øure of them. He it is that enables the faith of his people to draw Water out of the Rock, when the Fountain is dry; that makes meat to come out of the Eater (as in Samp≈øon's Riddle) that is able to bring a peaceable harmony out of devouring differences; and therefore it ≈øhould quicken our prayers to him.

2. To make us more ≈øerious in our endeavours after peace. Con≈øider what a di≈øhonour it is to the Go≈øpel, that tho≈øe that profe≈øs them≈øelves Sons of the ≈øame God, Members of the ≈øame Chri≈øt, Temples of the ≈øame Spirit, ≈øhould be at deadly jarrs one with another; It is ≈øtrange and unnatural that Lillies ≈øhould prove Thorns to one another; that tho≈øe who are Saints in pretence, ≈øhould be Devils in practice to one another; that Gods Diamonds ≈øhould cut one another; this is very ≈øtrange; yet thus it is. But now e≈øpecially it is mo≈øt ≈øad, when Religion which ≈øhould re≈øtrain and bridle our pa≈ø≈øions, is made fuel and incentives of them: How farre di≈øtant is it from the coun≈øel of the Apo≈øtle, Rom. 14.10. where he ≈øpeaks concerning their le≈ø≈øer differences, one values one day above another, another e≈øteems every day alike? what's His coun≈øel? he ≈øpeaks as a per≈øon that was fill'd with bowels and compa≈ø≈øion: Oh, ≈øaith he, let not him that doth not e≈øteem the day, judge him that doth: For we ≈øhall all ≈øtand before the judgement≈øeat of Chri≈øt, there we ≈øhall appear all upon a level, ≈øtand upon equal ground, and receive our final doom from him: This therefore ≈øhould calm our Spirit. Why may there not be ≈øome differences in judgement, without divi≈øion in affection? for it is as impo≈ø≈øible that all judgements ≈øhould be of the ≈øame extent, as all our faces to be of the ≈øame colour and figure. Therefore con≈øider what an injury it is to our Profe≈ø≈øion, how doth it ob≈øcure the glory of God, and lu≈øtre of our Religion?

3. Doth not the publick enemy rejoyce over us, I mean the Papi≈øts? do they not warm them≈øelves at the ≈øparks of our Divi≈øions? For you know the old Maxim of Divide and Reign: therefore it ≈øhould compo≈øe our ≈øpirits, and quicken us to labour after union. ∆≤nmortified lu≈øts are thence, whence all Wars and Enmities ≈øprings in the World. The Apo≈øtle Paul when he would compo≈øe their differences, he doth not lay, down Rules to decide their controver≈øies, but to correct their ≈øecret pa≈ø≈øions, pride, ≈øelf-≈øeeking, revenge, &c. This being the ≈øeed of all di≈øturbances in the Church: And although the≈øe Lu≈øts may not be con≈øpicuous and vi≈øible to the eyes of men, yet they are certainly the fuel of our di≈øtempers.

The ≈øum of all is this, tho≈øe that have the Spirit of God, they cannot
but mourn and be ≈øen≈øible of the≈øe divi≈øions, I know a great part among us are unconcerned: ≈øome rejoyce, tho≈øe that are rather buried in the affairs of the World, and incumbred with much bu≈øine≈øs, or tho≈øe that are ≈øteeped in the plea≈øures of ≈øen≈øe, are altogether unaffected with the≈øe things, ≈øtand as Newters, di≈øregarding all events: But the Saints of God cannot but mourn over them, when our divi≈øions hinder the progre≈øs of the Go≈øpel, & are ≈øerviceable to nothing but to the Kingdom of darkne≈øs. Therefore I be≈øeech you, let what hath been ≈øpoken quicken you in your prayers to God, to pray for the peace of Jecu≈øalem, (that's the lea≈øt effect of our love and de≈øires after peace) and by all endeavours to labour to bring back peace to us, that we may ≈øee that prophe≈øie fulfilled in our time, that the Lord ≈øhould be one, and his Name one among≈øt us.

div.head: Dr. Bates's Afternoon Sermon.

epigraph.q: Now the God of peace that brought again from the dead our Lord Je≈øus, that great Shepherd of the Sheep, through the bloud of the everla≈øting Covenant, make you perfect in every good work to do his will, working in you that which is well plea≈øing in his ≈øight, through Je≈øus Chri≈øt: to whom be glory for ever and ever.

div.p: THe Apo≈øtle de≈øcribes God by the effects of his power and love, [That brought again from the dead our Lord Je≈øus] The Re≈øurrection of Chri≈øt from the dead is one of the mo≈øt tran≈øcendent te≈øtimonies of Gods love and power towards us.

1. Of his Love, becau≈øe as the Anger of God was that which crucified our Saviour, ≈øo on the contrary, it mu≈øt be his Love that ≈øhould rai≈øe and re≈øtore him. Chri≈øt when he died, he looked upon God as an Enemy, as a Judge; and as tho≈øe colours which we ≈øee conveyed to us, are an≈øwerable to the Medium through which we ≈øee them; as, if we look through a coloured gla≈øs, we ≈øee the object of that colour: So the Lord Je≈øus, when he was upon the Cro≈øs, looked upon God through the black-cloud of our ≈øins, and through the red cloud of his Fathers wrath, and ≈øo dyed as a Sacrifice to Divine Ju≈øtice. But when he was rai≈øed from the Grave, that was the te≈øtimony of Gods love to him, and of his love to us; for he died as our Surety, he was arre≈øted for our Debt, he was ca≈øt into
the Grave, as into a Pri≈øon: But by his Re≈øurrection he was redeemed from Pri≈øon and Judgement. And therefore you ≈øhall find, when Chri≈øt was: ri≈øen, he ≈øalutes his Di≈øciples with this, Peace be unto you, Luk. 24.31. There was the dawning of peace at the Incarnation of Chri≈øt, for then the Angels ≈øung, Peace upon earth; but the compleat Sun-≈øhine of peace was at his Re≈øurrection, when he had made full and compleat ≈øatisfaction to Gods Ju≈øtice: for this was a clearing of him before all the World, when God rai≈øed him from the Grave. And in this re≈øpect it was very agreeable for the Apo≈øtle to ≈øay, The God of peace, that brought again from the dead our Lord Je≈øus.

2. It was the eflect of Infinite power. You know it is naturally impo≈ø≈øible for a dead body to quicken him≈øelf, to revive; but for the Lord Je≈øus, who had the load of the ≈øins of all the Elect upon him, who was, as it were ≈øecured in the Grave by Gods Ju≈øtice and Power, for him to ri≈øe again: This mu≈øt be an effect of In≈øinite Power in the Great God. Thus rai≈øing of Chri≈øt, ≈øometimes 'tis attributed to the Son, being God equal with the Father: But here 'tis attributed to God: and therefore when the Scripture would ≈øpeak with the greate≈øt magnificence of the Power of God, it expre≈ø≈øes it thus, That power which rai≈øed Je≈øus Chri≈øt from the dead. When Chri≈øt wrought deliverance for the lo≈øt world, (all tho≈øe who were commited to his charge.) This could be no le≈øs then the work of an infinite Power. And upon this account al≈øo it is very proportionable to the de≈øign of the Apo≈øtle, for that prayer he makes to God is for that which onely can be accompli≈øhed by Infinite Love, and Infinite Power, i.e. to make the Chri≈øtian Hebrews perfect in every good work to do his will.

I come to a further de≈øcription. He that brought again from the dead [our Lord Je≈øus.] the Title of the Lord Je≈øus was onely given to our Saviour after his Re≈øurrection, he was called Lord before, and Je≈øus before: but the≈øe two Titles were ever united till after his Re≈øurrection; hey came to ≈øee the place where the body of the Lord Je≈øus lay; the rea≈øon was this, becau≈øe the Re≈øurrection of Chri≈øt was a ≈øolemn Proclamation to the World, that Chri≈øt was the Son of God. 'Tis true, this Title was given him immediately upon his conception, but it was never compleatly declared to the World, till after his Re≈øurrection; for before, Chri≈øt was a Prince in di≈øgui≈øe; the beams of the Divinity was abated by the vail of his Humanity; but then he was declared by power to be the Son of God.
It followes [That great Shepherd of the Sheep] for the opening of this;
1. We will con≈øider this Title of Chri≈øt.
2. The Per≈øon for whom this Title relates.

Fir≈øt, This Title [The great Shepherd] 'Tis a wonderful conde≈øcention in Chri≈øt, that he will take upon him the Title of a Shepherd, that which rather expre≈ø≈øes Love and Care, than Power and Dominion; yet he is plea≈øed to a≈ø≈øume this Title to expre≈øs his affection to us. For the opening of it, wherein he appears to be the great Shepherd, I ≈øhall lay down the≈øe particulars.

1. He is great in the Dignity of his Per≈øon; for, he that is Lord of Angels, is become the Shepherd of the Sheep; and the humiliation of his per≈øon in this re≈øpect, is the exaltation of his Office: It is looked upon in the World as a mean and low employment, to have the care and in≈øpection of a Flock; but now herein appears the love of Chri≈øt, he was plea≈øed to become our Shepherd, that ≈øo he might ≈øecure and bring us to the Fold of Heaven, and there make us to feed upon tho≈øe Pa≈øtures, and to drink of tho≈øe Rivers of plea≈øures which flow from the pre≈øence of God.

2. In the derivation of his Authority: That Authority which is communicated to him, whereby he is our Shepherd: and that is originally from God him≈øelf; It is not by any mediate deputation, but from God him≈øelf. He is our Shepherd, and hath a Title to his Flock upon a double account.
1. They are committed to him as his charge and cu≈øtody, John 6.37, &c. All the Elect of the world were given by God the Father to Chri≈øt, not by way of Alienation, but by way of Opigneration, as ≈øo many pledges which he was to bring to grace and glory: And this charge he doth mo≈øt fully execute, for there is none mi≈ø≈øing of tho≈øe committed to him.
2. They are given to him by way of Reward and Recompen≈øe for all his Bloud and Sufferings, I≈øai. 53.10. The Lord put ≈øuch a value on ≈øouls, that he purcha≈øed an intere≈øt in them by his own bloud; and he thinks him≈øelf exceedingly recompen≈øed for all his pains on the Cro≈øs, Agonies in the Garden, Temptations in the Wilderne≈øs, &c. if ≈øouls will ≈øubmit to his care. And here ob≈øerve the cour≈øe of Heaven, God would endear ≈øouls to Chri≈øt upon all Rea≈øons, by vertue of his command, and that charge he gives to them, and by vertue of his own purcha≈øe.

3. If you confider, the extent of his care and affection, For all the Saints of the World, tho≈øe who are di≈øper≈øed in all places, in all ages, they are all his Flock; and therefore 'tis the Royalty of his Admini≈øtration, John 10.16. There ≈øhall be one Fold, and one Shepherd. As Chri≈øt is the onely Catholick King, ≈øo he is the onely ∆≤niver≈øal Bi≈øhop; For all other Shepherds have but particular Portions of his Flock committed to their charge, and they ≈øhould be ≈øuch portions as they have regard
to, and are under their in≈øpection, And at the la≈øt day, all his ≈øheep ≈øhall congregate together, and ≈øtand at his right hand. All the Saints of God that are now ≈øcattered, as ≈øo many Stars in the Firmament, ≈øhall be united in one con≈øtellation, when they ≈øhall appear in glory before him.

4. In re≈øpect of his endowments and qualifications, which fit him for the di≈øcharge of his Office. And
1. Take notice of his affection and love to us, and that is the wonder of Heaven and Earth, Chri≈øt laid down his life for his ≈øheep. Joh. 10.11. This is ≈øtrange, that Chri≈øt ≈øhould be a ≈øheep for the ≈ølaughter, that he might become our Shepherd, that he ≈øhould be a ≈øacrifice before he could take his Office upon him: Other ≈øheep lay down their lives for the Shepherd, but Chri≈øt laid down his life for the Sheep. So great was his love, that it brought him from Heaven to ≈øeek and find tho≈øe that were lo≈øt; he left a Palace to come to a Wilderne≈øs; a Throne of Heaven to come to a Fold here upon Earth. We read of David that he exchanged a Sheephook for a Scepter; but Chri≈øt quite contrary, he exchang'd a Scepter for the Rod and Staff of a Shepherd. It was ≈øaid by one, There is nothing ≈øo con≈øpicuous in Chri≈øt, as the prodigality of his love to us. Oh! do but con≈øider how great love that was that ≈øhould make him to die for us, that he might bring us home to his Fold. We were all of us like erring ≈øheep, who had ≈øtrayed from him, and fell to the Lord of the Soil, as ≈øtrange Cattel; we were gotten into the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the God of this World; the Lord Chri≈øt would buy us off from thence; though we forfeited our right in him, vet he would not lo≈øe his right in us, but he laid down his life that he might reduce us to his Fold, that of Wolves he might make us Lambs, and ≈øit us for the comforts of his Pre≈øence.
2. In re≈øpect of his exact diligence and in≈øpection over them. When but one Sheep went a≈øtray from his Fold, we read, he left the ninety and nine, and went and ≈øought for that One, Luke 15. where we have that Parable, to expre≈øs the diligence and watchfulne≈øs of Chri≈øt over his Sheep. There is no per≈øon, be he never ≈øo mean, never ≈øo ob≈øcure, though lo≈øt in the number and account of the World, if he be one of Chri≈øts Sheep, he is always under his in≈øpection and watchfulne≈øs. We read of the High-Prie≈øt, that he carried the names of the Tribes upon his Bre≈øt-plate; the Lord Chri≈øt carries the names of all his Sheep in his heart: therefore, Rev. 13. ≈øpeaking concerning the Saints, all that dwell upon Earth, Who≈øe names are written in the book of Life. His diligence and care is ≈øo exact, that he hath all their names writ in his Book. He that tells the Stars, counts their hairs, and always exerci≈øes the mo≈øt watchful providence over them for good. You know
Sheep are either liable to rage, or erring, and wandring; Chri≈øt's diligence is ≈øuch that he protects them from the rage of Satan, reduces them from all their wandrings, and brings them home to him≈øelf.
3. In making proportional all their ≈øervices and ≈øufferings, to tho≈øe degrees of ≈øtrength which he gives to them, I≈øai. 40.11. He ≈øhall feed his Flock like a Shepherd, he ≈øhall gather his Lambs with his Arms, and carry them in his bo≈øome, and ≈øhall gently lead tho≈øe that are with young. Chri≈øt always makes a proportion between the Services, Sufferings, and ≈øtrength he calls them to. He it is that with that tenderne≈øs ≈øpeaks to Peter, Peter love≈øt thou me? feed my Lambs. He hath provided for them the mo≈øt ample, and mo≈øt ≈øatisfying nouri≈øhment, the Ordinances of the Go≈øpel, the Word, the Promi≈øes, which are the brea≈øt of Con≈øolation; the≈øe are all provided by him for his people. And in this re≈øpect he is the great Shepheard, for he doth not onely allow them means, but ble≈ø≈øes the me ans to them: he is able to enlighten the dark mind, he can make pliable the ≈øtubborn Will, and he can ≈øpiritualize drouzie affection, which all other Shepherds in the World are not able to effect.
4. He is the great Shepherd, if you con≈øider his power to pre≈øerve them from danger; not onely tho≈øe dangers which re≈øpect Satan (for that fell under his care before) but tho≈øe di≈øea≈øes to which they are liable, which threaten ruine: Other Shepherds po≈ø≈øibly may cure di≈øea≈øes, but not defend them from danger. Chri≈øt it is that gives eternal life to his ≈øheep, he begins the life of holine≈øs, which though at pre≈øent is but a ≈øpark in the Sea, yet he keeps it alive till it ≈øhall break forth into a triumphant flame. That life that is encompa≈ø≈øed with ≈øo many enemies, and liable to ≈øo many weakne≈ø≈øes, the Lord Je≈øus will bring forth judgement to victory, and will make them to be powerful over ≈øpiritual and eternal enemies.

The ≈øumme is this: the Lord Chri≈øt is ≈øo perfect a Shepherd, ≈øo compleat, as to all the qualifications of that office, that the Prophet David breaks forth into exultation, P≈øal. 23. The Lord is my Shepherd, &c. and then afterwards expre≈ø≈øes all tho≈øe provi≈øions which are made for him by God as a Shepherd, He makes me to lie down in green pa≈øtures, he leadeth me be≈øide the ≈øtill waters. So that you ≈øee, Chri≈øt, whether for diligence, love, tenderne≈øs, for pre≈øerving us from danger, for ≈øecuring us to life eternal, he is only the great Shepherd, he is the God of Shepherds as well as the God of Sheep, and all other Shepherds are but inferiour to him, and mu≈øt be accountable to him for the Souls of his Sheep, which are more valuable then all the world.
It follows, The great Shepherd [of the ≈øheep] I ≈øhall not ≈øpend any time in making any re≈øemblance between the People of God and the Sheep; Only,

list.item: 1. They are Sheep in re≈øpect of their Innocency. You know, of all creatures the Sheep are unarmed: other creatures, either they are armed with ≈øtrength, or skin, or ≈øwiftne≈øs to guard them≈øelves, and offend others; but the Sheep hath neither the ≈øtrength of the Lion, the craft of the Fox, nor the ≈øwiftne≈øs of the Deer, and of all creatures is mo≈øt weak, inoffen≈øive, and mo≈øt liable to dangers and injuries. Of all per≈øons, Gods people are mo≈øt liable to danger, and when out of Chri≈øts protection, the weake≈øt per≈øons in the world.

2. In re≈øpect of their Meekne≈øs. A Sheep is an Emblem of Meekne≈øs, that's their temper, and therein they imitate Chri≈øt, who hath propounded him≈øelf to be their pattern, Learn of me, for I am meek and lowly; both the≈øe qualities are expre≈øt by the Prophet, I≈øa. 11. where ≈øpeaking concerning the times of the Go≈øpel, he ≈øaith, The Lamb ≈øhall lie down with the Wolf; Now, where the Prophet expre≈ø≈øes their ≈øafety, there he expre≈ø≈øes their Innocency and Meekne≈øs. This is the rea≈øon why the Prophet ≈øaith, For thy ≈øake we are killed all the day long, we are counted as ≈øheep for the ≈ølaughter; becau≈øe of all creatures mo≈øt liable to injuries, that which doth lea≈øt re≈øent them: And where-ever the grace of Chri≈øt comes, it ≈øweetens the mo≈øt cruel nature, and poli≈øhes the mo≈øt rough di≈øpo≈øition, and makes them to be like Chri≈øt, meek and lowly.

3. In regard of their Profitablene≈øs; for of all creatures, they are mo≈øt profitable, the food as to their fle≈øh, the cloath as to their fleece. And the people of God, however they are expo≈øed to the contempts and injuries of the world, they are the mo≈øt profitable: for were it not for them, the whole frame of Nature would fall into pieces, the Stars would fall like leaves in Autumn, and all the Elements would fall into confu≈øion; we ≈øee it by one Lot, who kept ≈øhowres of fire and brim≈øtome from falling on Sodom, till he was got out of it. And it is the people of God, for whom this frame of Nature is continued, and when they are brought into the fold of Chri≈øt, the Ju≈øtice of God will have a ≈øolemn triumph over all the world.

4. As they are liable to wandring; ≈øheep are wandring creatures, and when ≈øtrayed, not able to reduce them≈øelves. And in this re≈øpect the people of God are ≈øheep, they have a thou≈øand allurements to draw them from the ways of God: and if God ≈øhould not guide them by his eye, 'tis impo≈ø≈øible they ≈øhould go in the way that leads to Heaven. Therefore David ≈øaith, I have gone a≈øtray like a lo≈øt Sheep, ≈øeek thy Servant;
P≈øal. 119.176. This ≈øhall ≈øuffice to make the Parallel and Re≈øemblance of the people of God to ≈øheep.

div.p: The ≈øecond Argument is this, That he hath de≈øign'd Chri≈øt to be the Shepherd of the Church, The great Shepherd of the Sheep; this is another argument and evidence that he is reconciled to us, and that he is the God of Peace: For when God gave Chri≈øt to be our Sacrifice, and rai≈øed him up to be our Shepherd; the≈øe are the mo≈øt clear Te≈øtimonies of his Love: For, although Chri≈øt now ≈øits in Heaven, and all the Angels of God wor≈øhip him, yet he doth not di≈ødain to exerci≈øe the ≈øame care, and to expre≈øs the ≈øame Love to his People, that he did when he was upon the Earth. All the Offices of Chri≈øt expre≈øs Gods love to us, for he feeds us as a Prophet, died for us as a Prie≈øt, Governs and defends us as he is a King; and all the≈øe meet together in this Title, feeding of us, dying for us, de≈øending of us; as he was God, he loved us; as he was Man he died for us. This doth expre≈øs the effects of his two Natures in this Title; and therefore an admirable evidence that God is at peace with us.

It follows, [Through the bloud of the everla≈øting Covenant.] The bloud of Chri≈øt is that which cements God and us together: For you mu≈øt remember, our original peace with God was broken; that peace we have with him now, is called Reconciliation; it is as a broken bone, which well ≈øet, is ≈øtronger then before, becau≈øe Nature conveys mo≈øt liberal ≈øupplies to the weake≈øt part: ≈øo now being reconciled to God, through the bloud of his Son, we ≈øtand upon ≈øurer terms with him, than we did in Innocency; The Bloud of Chri≈øt ≈øpeaks better things for us, than all our Sins ≈øpeak again≈øt us; it ≈øpeaks peace to our ≈øouls, & that in Heaven purcha≈øed by his death. Chri≈øt died as a Te≈øtator, and bequeathed to the Church a Legacy of Peace; he lives as the Executor of that Covenant, and now in Heaven conveys to us that ble≈ø≈øing of Peace, which he bequeath'd in his death. And as our Peace was founded in his Bloud, ≈øo it is con≈øerv'd by his Interce≈ø≈øion; he appears in the Court of Heaven as our Emba≈ø≈øadour, to make up all tho≈øe differences which fall out between God and us; for you know, Amity and Friend≈øhip is kept between Forraign States, by their Re≈øidents and Agents, that are kept in their ≈øeveral Courts; ≈øo we have an Agent in the Court of Heaven, the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, that was rai≈øed from the dead: And as a Believer falls into ≈øin, which is a breach of Peace between God and us, ≈øo that Peace is made up by the exerci≈øe of repentance on our part, and by ≈øprinkling of Chri≈øts bloud upon us, on Gods part. The renewed exerci≈øe of Repentance, and application of Chri≈øts bloud, pre≈øeryes that peace that is
between God and Believers. And (to ≈øum up the force of the Argument) when we had fallen from God, and it did not con≈øi≈øt with the Maje≈øty of God to make peace with us, without ≈øatisfaction, then was he plea≈øed to pay our Ran≈øom out of his own Trea≈øury, and Redeem us by the bloud of his Sonne; So that all his Attributes might ≈øhine forth in their Lu≈øtre, and glory in our Salvation, and that upon ≈øure terms we might be able to challenge an Intere≈øt in his Favour and Love.
It follows, Through the bloud of the [Everla≈øting Covenant.] It is called an Everla≈øting Covenant in two re≈øpects.

list.item: 1. In oppo≈øition to the Old Covenant, which was made with Adam in Innocency; but that Covenant which ≈øecures to us the reward of that Life Eternal, did not ≈øecure to us the Condition, that was perfect Obedience; and in reference to this Old Covenant, ≈øometimes the Go≈øpel is called a New Covenant, ≈øometimes a Better Covenant, becau≈øe it ≈øupplies all weakne≈ø≈øe in the fir≈øt Covenant; not as if the Law of God was weak and faulty in re≈øpect of its ≈øelf, for the Law is Holy, Ju≈øt, and Good, but weak in re≈øpect of us; for it is impo≈ø≈øible that that Covenant, by the breach of which Sin and Death came in to us, ≈øhould reconcile us to God, and appea≈øe his anger; and therefore God contrived another Covenant for us, a Covenant in the Go≈øpel, that was made with us in Chri≈øt, and this is called an Everla≈øting Covenant, becau≈øe it remains for ever, the tenor of it ≈øhall not be changed; for, the Fr≈øt Covenant is onely abrogated and made null, while fru≈øtrated as to the intent it was fir≈øt given.

2. It's called an Everla≈øting Covenant, as it brings to tho≈øe that are parties in it an everla≈øting Glory: ≈øo the Lord Je≈øus his blood is called an Everla≈øting Redemption, for it ran≈øoms the ≈øouls of men from that Eternal Death to which they were liable, and gives them a Title to Everla≈øting Life; for this Covenant which now God hath made with us, it not onely ≈øecures the Reward, but the Conditions to which the Reward is made; for God ≈øaith, I will plant my fear in your hearts, that you ≈øhall not depart from me.

div.p:
I have now gone over the Title, and that in order to the Prayer which follows, [Make you perfect to do his will, working in you that which is well-plea≈øing in his ≈øight,] the general ≈øum of it is this: That God of Peace who is reconciled to us in his Son, as he is the Father of mercies to us, ≈øo he is the Fountain of Holine≈øs to us; and in this re≈øpect we can onely expect from him the trea≈øures of Grace, as he is the God of Peace; for God, as he is our Judge, di≈øpences to Sinners nothing
but revenge; there is nothing to be expected but the cur≈øe of his Law, the Execution of that ≈øentence of death from him. For, although the World de≈øpi≈øe holine≈øs as a ba≈øe and contemptible thing, they had rather be ungracious, than inglorious in the eyes of men, and upon this account they are afraid to be Holy, le≈øt they ≈øhould be the publick ≈øcorn and contempt of the place wherein they live: although holine≈øs is of ≈øo low a price in the world, yet in Heaven, next to God, Chri≈øt, and the Spirit, Holine≈øs is the mo≈øt rich Jewel, that God can be≈øtow upon us; and therefore we mu≈øt fir≈øt look upon him as the God of Peace, before we can beg any grace from him. And this is the Rea≈øon why the Apo≈øtle repre≈øents God by the≈øe Titles, that he might encourage the Hebrews to believe God would grant this reque≈øt. When Chri≈øt dyed for us, it was not his de≈øign only to quiet our con≈øciences, but to quicken our ≈øouls, not onely to free us from Damnation, but from the Domination of ≈øin: And therefore you ≈øhall find the≈øe two are joyned together, Tit. 2.14 Who gave him≈øelf for us that he might Redeem us from all iniquity, and purifie unto him≈øelf a peculiar people, zealous of good works. The death of Chri≈øt, as there was a value in it to purcha≈øe Gods favour, ≈øo there was a vertue in it to re≈øtore to us Gods Image. And the account of his dying for us is it, that we mu≈øt expect the lea≈øt degree of Grace and Holine≈øs from God. And this is the rea≈øon why the Apo≈øtle prefaces this, Now the God of Peace, &c.

I know you expect I ≈øhould ≈øay ≈øomething as to my non-conformity, I ≈øhall onely ≈øay thus much, It is neither fancy, faction, nor humour, that makes me not to comply, but meerly for fear of offending God. And if after the be≈øt means u≈øed for my illumination; as prayer to God, di≈øcour≈øe, ≈øtudy, I am not able to be ≈øatisfied concerning the lawfulne≈øs of what is required; if it be my unhappine≈øs to be in error, ≈øurely men wil have no rea≈øon to be angry with me in this world, and I hope God will pardon me in the next.

epigraph.q: A New Commandment give I unto you, that ye love one another, as I have loved you.

div.p: VVE are this day called to a Love-fea≈øt; and nothing can be more ≈øuitable than to treat of Chri≈øtian Love; Je≈øus Chri≈øt hath given us a great evidence of his Love to us, he bled Love at every vein; therefore we are to imitate him, and as becometh Chri≈øtians, to Love one another. 'Tis a general complaint, how true I know not, That this is the great Grace that is defective among Chri≈øtians. Although they pretend much Love to Chri≈øt, yet they have little Love one to another.

I have in former Sermons di≈øcour≈øed concerning Faith, how that by Faith we mu≈øt receive Chri≈øt in the Sacrament; and now I ≈øhall ≈øpeak ≈øomething of Love; Love is needful at a fea≈øt, it is requi≈øite when we ≈øit down at our own Table. I remember it is ≈øaid of Augu≈øtin, He would not ≈øuffer any to fea≈øt at his Table that came in a Spirit of Rancor, and ≈øate down in pa≈ø≈øion. Sure I am, they are not fit to be Gue≈øts at Chri≈øts Table, that come not in a Spirit of Meekne≈øs and Love. It is true, we are to eat the Pa≈ø≈øover with bitter herbs, but they mu≈øt be the bitter Herbs of Repentance, not the bitter Herbs of Malice, Wrath, and Fury; we mu≈øt come here with bitter Tears, not with bitter Hearts: hear what the Text ≈øaith, A New Command I give unto you, &c.
Wherein, Fir≈øt, you have the Command, A New Command I give unto you; It is not left to our di≈øcretion, but, we are bound to it by vertue of a Command, A New Command I give unto you.

Secondly, This Command is enforced by Gods own example, as I have loved you. It is called a new Command, but Love is an old Command, this Law is written in the Nature of Man. It is engraven in every mans heart by Nature, and it is an old Command, becau≈øe found among Gods antient Statutes, the antient Records of his Law; I, but
'tis a new Command too, becau≈øe pre≈ø≈øed by a new Example of Chri≈øt, As I have loved you, ≈øo do ye love one another.

Doct. Chri≈øtians ought to make Con≈øcience of this duty of loving one another. Confident I am, We ≈øhall never ≈øee Religion thrive in the World, until we ≈øee this Grace of Love flouri≈øh in the heart of Chri≈øtians.

Fir≈øt, Truth of this Love; If you love one another, ≈øaith Chri≈øt, ≈øee you do it purely, not di≈ø≈øembling, but from the heart. 1 John 3.18. My little Children, let us not love in word, neither in tongue, but in deed and in truth; di≈ø≈øembling love is like painted fire that will never warm; we mu≈øt not be like the Bee, that hath honey in her mouth, but withal hath a ≈øting in her tail; we mu≈øt not pretend to love, to have honey in the mouth, but withal have the ≈øting of malice in the heart; no, ≈øaid the Apo≈øtle, Let us love in deed and in truth.
Secondly, Extent of our Love; this Fountain of Love mu≈øt run in three ≈øtreams.

1. We mu≈øt love all men, love their per≈øons, although we mu≈øt not love their ≈øins, we have all the ≈øame make, the ≈øame lump and mould, and therefore mu≈øt love; there is a natural Love, that every creature bears to his own ≈øpecies and kind.

2. Our love mu≈øt e≈øpecially ≈øtream out to the Saints of God the hou≈øhold of Faith. It is with our love, as it is with our fire, you keep fire all the day upon the Hearth, but upon ≈øpecial occa≈øions you draw it out larger, ≈øo our Love mu≈øt always burn to all: I but to the Saints you mu≈øt draw out the fire, inlarge your affections, we mu≈øt love as God loves, he doth e≈øpecially love the Saints: love every creature with a common love, but e≈øpecially the New Creature; and indeed there is that in every true Saint, that may excite and allure our Love. What are the Graces of the Spirit, but ≈øo many pearls to adorn the Bride of Chri≈øt? What is holine≈øs in the heart, „Äà‚óä„Äâ the imbroidery and curious Workman≈øhip of the Holy Gho≈øt? here is enough to entice and draw out our Love: and Beloved, if we love the Saints for their Graces, then we love all the Saints.
And here I be≈øeech you con≈øider the≈øe ≈øix pariculars.

Fir≈øt, We ought to love the Saints in what condition ≈øoever they are, although they be poor in the world, low in their condition, for commonly ≈øo it is. They that have the lowe≈øt hearts, have the lowe≈øt
condition too. I read of the King of the Moors, that he was offended at the Chri≈øtians becau≈øe of their poverty: and truly when wicked men do fleece the Saints, it is no wonder if they be poor: methinks grace in a poor man, is like a Pearl that lies in the du≈øt, or like a cloath of Gold that is hid under Rags; you mu≈øt love the Gold, that is, the Grace, notwith≈øtanding the Rags. The poore≈øt Saint alive hath the Angels riches; the poore≈øt Believer is a Member of Chri≈øt, and ≈øhall we not love him? we love the picture of a friend although it be hung in a mean frame: we mu≈øt love a rich Chri≈øt in a poor man.

Secondly, We are to love the people of God although they have many weak infirmities: ≈øhew me the man that is perfect, and let him throw the fir≈øt ≈øtone, even the be≈øt. Saints like the Starrs they have their twinkling, they have their blemi≈øhes and their failings: in ≈øome there's too much pride, in others too much cen≈øoriou≈øne≈øs, in others too much ra≈øh anger and pa≈ø≈øion, but we mu≈øt love the Grace that is in them, notwith≈øtanding the infirmities that are in them: you love Gold though in the oar, and mixed with much impurity; a Saint on earth, is like a Diamond that hath its flaw, like to the Ro≈øe that is ≈øweet and perfumed, but yet hath its pricks. The be≈øt Saints have ≈øome mixture and infirmity, and we mu≈øt love them for the good that is in them: this is our great fault, we are apt to over-look all the good, and ≈øo take notice of the ≈øtain and blemi≈øhes in them; as tho≈øe that ≈øee a little ≈øtain in a piece of Scarlet, de≈øpi≈øe the cloath for the ≈øtains ≈øake; ≈øo do we. But God doth not do ≈øo by us, he is plea≈øed to over-look many ≈øad failings, he ≈øeeth the Faith, and winks at the failings of his people; you that cannot love a Brother becau≈øe you ≈øee an imperfection in him, would you have God do ≈øo by you, would you have him damn you for every blemi≈øh of ≈øin?

Thirdly, We mu≈øt love the Children of God, though weak in parts; all are not born Politicians; But though the Saints of God have not always ≈øo good intellectuals as others, yet if they have good Vitals, and the life of Faith in them, love them for that Grace; you do not de≈øpi≈øe your Children becau≈øe they are weak, but you love them becau≈øe they are your Children. Oh! do not de≈øpi≈øe a Saint becau≈øe he is of low parts, but love him as he is a Child of your Heavenly Fathers.

Fourthly, We are to love the Saints of God though in ≈øome le≈ø≈øer things they differ from us, if they keep the foundations of Religion, and hold the Head, Chri≈øt; yet we are to bear other things: one Chri≈øtian hath more light than another, and ≈øhall we un-≈øaint all that cannot come up to our light? Its great wi≈ødom to ≈øeparate between the precious
and the vile: O what a ble≈ø≈øed place will Heaven be, becau≈øe there our light ≈øhall be clear, and our love ≈øhall be perfect. And that is the fourth.

Fifthly, Love the Saints of God when reviled and per≈øecuted; a bleeding Saint ≈øhould be the object of our love. Oni≈øiphorus, ≈øaith Paul, was not a≈øhamed of my chain; a ≈øign he loved Chri≈øts Graces in Paul. Chri≈øt Je≈øus loveth no Saints more than his per≈øecuted Saints, his Martyrs have the highe≈øt Thrones re≈øerved in Heaven for them: we mu≈øt love to ≈øee Chri≈øts Livery upon a man, though ≈øprinkled with bloud: he that is a≈øhamed of a per≈øecuted Saint, will never ≈øuffer for a crucified Je≈øus.

Sixthly, We mu≈øt love the Saints of God, though their Graces may eclip≈øe and out-≈øhine our Graces. Beloved, in the ≈øweete≈øt fruits worms are apt to breed, and in the be≈øt heart, the worm of pride is apt to be breeding; if God doth not keep us, we ≈øhall not onely envy anothers Graces, if they out-≈øhine us, but their per≈øons too. What though anothers Graces do out-≈øhine yours? yet love him, becau≈øe the eminency of his Graces bringeth much honor to the Go≈øpel of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

And thus my Beloved, I have ≈øhewn you how you mu≈øt love all the Saints, 1 Pet. 2.17. Love the Brother-hood, love the whole Fraternity of Beleevers. Oh! that this ≈øweet ≈øpice of love might ≈øend forth its perfume among Chri≈øtians, that we could turn all our heart-burnings into heart-breakings, and quench the fire of Divi≈øions and Contentions, and keep the fire of love burning upon the Altar of our hearts. And my Beloved, as we mu≈øt love all the Saints, ≈øo we mu≈øt ≈øhew this love by the fruit of it, for God doth not value that love that is invi≈øible; the fruits of our love to the Saints mu≈øt be the≈øe four.

list.head: Four Fruits of Love to the Saints.
list.item: 1. We mu≈øt ≈øhew love to them by pri≈øing their per≈øons above others, P≈øal. 15.4. ≈øpoken of a man that ≈øhall go to Heaven, In who≈øe eyes a vile per≈øon is contemned, but he honoureth them that fear the Lord: the wicked are ≈øo much rubbi≈øh and lumber, but the Saints are called the Jewels, Mal. 3.1. and we mu≈øt prize the≈øe Jewels above all the Lumber in the World; as they ≈øaid of King David, thy life is worth ten thou≈øand of ours, 2 Sam. 18.3. ≈øo is a Godly man above a wicked man; God he will give Kingdons to ran≈øom his Saints, I≈øa. 43.3. I gave Egypt for thy ran≈øom, Aethiopia and Sheba for thee: and thus ≈øhould we ≈øet the highe≈øt rate upon the Saints of God, for that is to love them.

2. We mu≈øt ≈øhew love to all the Saints of God, by vindicating of them, when they are traduced and ≈ølandered; its a great ≈øin to ≈ølander
a Chri≈øtian, its to go to pollute Chri≈øts Image, the wicked their throats are open Sepulchres, to bury the names of the Righteous in; now you that are Chri≈øtians mu≈øt not be ready to receive a fal≈øe and groundle≈øs report of a Saint, but rather vindicate them, for that is to love them.

2. We ≈øhew our love to the Saints, by praying for them; you know not what good your prayers may do them: Mini≈øters mu≈øt pray for their People, and the People mu≈øt pray for their Mini≈øters; for prayer commands God him≈øelf, I≈øa. 45.11. Prayer is the golden Key that unlocks the Heavenly trea≈øure of Gods bowels. Oh pray one for another; we ≈øhould not ≈øtrive one with another (as is too frequent) but pray one for another.

4. Shew your love by being ready according to your abilities to relieve their wants; to love one another is to be a well-wi≈øher to him, and to do all the friendly Offices we can one for another; there are, my Beloved, many of the dear Servants of God in the Mini≈øtry, that have been already reduced to mi≈øery and want, and abundance more are like to be reduced to great nece≈ø≈øities; Now I be≈øeech you to ≈øhow your love to the hou≈øhold of Faith, for that is a ≈øign of your true love to God, and to the Brother-hood, that when as myrrh drops freely from the Tree, ≈øo works of mercy drops freely from the heart. If Je≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øhould ≈øtand in the mid≈øt of the congregation, and ≈øay, ≈øhew your Love to me by your good works; I believe no heart here would be ≈øo hard as to deny Je≈øus Chri≈øt; Why, remember what≈øoever you give Mini≈øters, and to his Members, he takes it as given to him≈øelf.

div.p: That is the ≈øecond, Our Love mu≈øt extend to all Saints.

3. Our Love mu≈øt reach to our enemies, we mu≈øt love them that do not love us, Luke 6.1. Love your enemies, do good to them that hate you. I confe≈ø≈øe, a mortal enemy, I would be loath to make a bo≈øom friend. But though policy teach us not to tru≈øt our enemies, yet piety teacheth us to love them: Chri≈øt, he did pray for his enemies, and he ≈øhed tears of compa≈ø≈øion for them that afterwards ≈øhed his bloud. So much for the Doctrinal part. Now for a word of Application, and I have done.

div.p:
And fir≈øt, this may ≈øerve to reprove tho≈øe, who ≈øeem in other things to be excellent, and profe≈øs much love toward Chri≈øt and his Go≈øpel, but have no love to the Saints of God: there are ≈øome that upon this very account, have for the≈øe great many years ab≈øented them≈øelves from the Lords Supper, becau≈øe they pretend not to be in charity. This is a double-dyed ≈øin, a ≈øin with a witne≈øs; its a ≈øin not to come, and its a ≈øin not to be in charity. But let me ≈øay this to them, ≈øurely ≈øuch kind
of Chri≈øtians are a ≈øhame to their profe≈ø≈øion. What, doth not the Go≈øpel teach you charity and love, as well as faith? Surely that Chri≈øtian hath no grace in his heart, that liveth out of charity with his Brother; for as the Philo≈øopher ≈øaith, All the vertues are linked together, and tyed as with a≈øtring, and where there is one, there is all: and where one is wanting, there is no vertue: ≈øo I ≈øay of the graces, they are linked together, and where there is one, there is all: and where one is wanting, there is none at all. Saith Augu≈øtine, Thou bragge≈øt of thy faith in Chri≈øt, but ≈øhew me thy faith by thy love to Chri≈øt, for Faith and love cannot be ≈øeparated: For as in the Sun, there is light and heat, and the≈øe cannot be ≈øeparated one from the other, ≈øo faith and love is twi≈øted together, and where there is one waning, the other is wanting: as he that did ≈øo engrave his name on the Buckler of Minerva, that who ever went about to take out his name, ≈øpoiled the Buckler: ≈øo Faith and love are ≈øo in≈øeparable, that if you go to take away the one, you ≈øpoyl the other. Oh! remember and mourn for it, thou that ≈øaye≈øt thou art not in charity: it's a ≈øad ≈øymptom thou art not in a ≈øtate of Grace, Titus 3. v. 5. For me our ≈øelves al≈øo were ≈øometimes fooli≈øh, di≈øobedient, deceived, ≈øerving divers Lu≈øts and plea≈øures, living in malice, envy, hateful, and hating one another, that is, before conver≈øion we were ≈øwelled with poy≈øon of malice and wrath; but when once the grace of God came, then it was otherwi≈øe; that man that hath not Love and Charity in his heart, ≈øurely he hath nothing of God in him, for God is Love; he knoweth nothing of the Go≈øpel ≈øavingly, for the Go≈øpel is a Go≈øpel of peace; he hath none of the wi≈ødom which cometh from Heaven, for that is meek and gentle, and ea≈øie to be entreated.

If there be any on the other ≈øide, that are not in charity, and yet will come to the Lords Table, remember this, you get no good by the Ordinance, you do but defile the Ordinance. The Apo≈øtle calls it, the leaven of malice; it doth ≈øower all your Holy Duties, Sermons, Prayers, and Sacraments; it is a little gall imbitters a great deal of honey: So where there is a little of this Gall of malice and hatred, it imbittereth and ≈øpoileth all the honey of your Graces and Duties. The Apo≈øtle bids us in prayer to lift up pure hands without wrath, 1 Tim. 1.2. I will therefore that men pray every where, lifting up pure hands without wrath and doubting. What the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaketh of the duty of Prayer, I may ≈øay of the Lords Supper; when you come to ≈øee the Body and Blood of the Lord, Lift up pure hands without malice bitterne≈øs and wrath. That is a ≈øad ≈øpeech of Augu≈øtine, He that is full of rancor and malice, he is a man-≈ølayer: Nay: the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith it in the fir≈øt Epi≈øtle of John 3.15. Who≈øoever hateth his Brother is a murderer, and ye know no murderer hath Eternal life abiding in
him; Do not think this Ordinance will profit you, if you do not come in love to the Saints; ≈øuppo≈øe a man drinketh down poi≈øon, and afterwards taketh down a Cordial, ≈øurely this Cordial will do him but little good; ≈øo thou that drinke≈øt down the poi≈øon of wrath and maliceÃÑ into thy ≈øoul, and come≈øt afterward to drink down the Cordial of Chri≈øts bloud in the Sacrament, why certainly this Cordial will do thee but little good.

p.hi: EXHORTATION.

div.p: Therefore to conclude by way of Exhortation; I be≈øeech you in the Lord, that you would remember this Text this day, when you come to the Lords Table, read over this Le≈ø≈øon, A new Commandment I give unto you, that you love one another as I have loved you; come to the Sacrament in love to Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and in love one to another, be not full of bitterne≈øs, but full of bowels; the primitive Saints were of one heart; you all expect I know one Heaven, and will you not be of one heart? this I believe is a great rea≈øon, why the Sacrament hath no more profited many receivers; you know if there be a ≈øtopping at the ≈øtomack, the meat taken in will never concoct and nouri≈øh; why thou that ha≈øt wrath and anger, and malice at thy heart, there is an ob≈øtruction as it were at the ≈øtomach, and therefore it is that the bread of life doth not nouri≈øh thy Soul. Why Chri≈øtians, are not we all Souldiers under one Regiment, under Je≈øus Chri≈øt, the Lyon of the Tribe of Judah, and Captain of our ≈øalvation? Are not we all Branches of the ≈øame Vine? and are we not all Members of the ≈øame Body? and ≈øhall there be a ≈øchi≈øm or rent in the Body?

I ≈øhall only ≈øay this, we ≈øhould do all as the Serpent: Naturali≈øts ob≈øerve the Serpent, that before he goes to drink at the waters, he ca≈øts up his poi≈øon; ≈øo before you come to the Table of the Lords Supper, ca≈øt up your poi≈øon of bitterne≈øs, wrath, and malice, and then Chri≈øts bloud will be both a Medicine to heal you, and a Julip to refre≈øh you.

epigraph.q: Grace be unto you, and peace from God the Father, and from our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

div.p: YOu will wonder, po≈ø≈øibly, that I ≈øhould pitch on the Apo≈øtles Salutation for my valediction, and make that the conclu≈øion of my Preaching, which he made the beginning of his Writing, and therefore I have made a double Plea for it. I find that this was a Form of Ble≈ø≈øing peculiar to this Apo≈øtle, both in the beginning and end of this Epi≈øtle; for as there is ≈øcarcely one Epi≈øtle but begins with it, ≈øo many end with it likewi≈øe; as in Eph. 6.24. The grace of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt be with your ≈øpirit. So in 2 The≈ø. 3.18. The grace of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt be with your all. So that I find the Apo≈øtle to u≈øe it frequently at the beginning and end of his writing; I thought as I made it the matter of my prayer for you in the beginning, ≈øo I might make it my farewel to you in the ending, and therefore Grace be unto you, & peace from God our Father, & from our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

Be≈øides this, as Jacob ≈øaid to his Benjamin concerning his Veni≈øon, when his Father asked him, how he found it ≈øo quickly? he an≈øwered, becau≈øe the Lord thy God brought it to me: The ≈øame I may ≈øay of this Scripture; for con≈øidering of what ≈øubject I ≈øhould ≈øpeak in my la≈øt labours here among you, the Scripture came to my thoughts, and opening the Book came immediately to my ≈øight; and therefore I may ≈øay God brought it to me; which I no ≈øooner looked upon, but methinks I ≈øaw the Apo≈øtle on Mount Gerizim, and his mouth filled with ble≈ø≈øings; for what greater ble≈ø≈øings can a man wi≈øh, than that which comprehends all ble≈ø≈øings, and that is grace and peace. Being therefore now to part, I thought to go to the top of the Mount, and leave with you grace and peace from God our Father, and from our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt. In which words there are two generals.

div.p: The Order of the words is worth nothing, Grace be to you and Peace; Fir≈øt grace, then peace, for there can be no peace without grace, nor grace, but there will be peace: but there can be no true peace but from God, not from God, but as he is a Father, not from God as a Father, but as our Father, and he cannot be ≈øaid to be our Father, but through our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt: and therefore he ≈øaid, Grace be unto you, and Peace from God our Father, through our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt: both are manife≈øted as a golden Chain linked together, not grace without peace, nor peace without grace, but both enjoyned together, to cram the believers Souls with grace and peace. div.p:
But before we draw any thing from the Text by way of Ob≈øervation, we will ≈øpeak to the terms by way of Explication. Grace be unto you: What is here meant by Grace? This is a ≈øweet word, it perfumes the Breath, it cheri≈øhes the Con≈øcience, it warms the heart, it ravi≈øhes the Soul; as the Spou≈øe was ravi≈øhed with ‚Ä¢ ayes of Chri≈øts glory, ≈øo Chri≈øt revives the Soul with one of his gracious rayes di≈øcovered to the heart: Grace is the life of the Soul, thou art dead till Grace quickens thee, thou art lo≈øt till Grace find thee, undone till Grace ≈øaves thee; Grace is the Manna of Angels, the ≈øpiritual Bread which tho≈øe that are holy in being are nouri≈øhed with, and ≈øub≈øi≈øt by: Angels live on Grace, and ≈øtand by Grace; Man that ≈øhares in the Grace of God is made fellow Commoner with Angels, eats Angels food, and ≈øhares in Angels ble≈ø≈øings: Grace is the ≈øub≈øtance of the Scripture, the end of the Law, the fulne≈øs of the Go≈øpel: Gregory calls it the Heart and Soul of God, I am ≈øure Grace is the Heart and Soul of the Word; 'tis a little Word, but it comprehends all good: here is more than Homers Iliads in a Nut-≈øhell, 'tis the Epitome of all the good in Heaven an Earth; name any Word that ≈øignifies good in the Soul here, or hereafter, but it is found in the Index, in this little word Grace: Grace comprehends Gods love to us, and our love to God, and as Gods love to us is the ≈øum of all Mercy; ≈øo
our love to God, is the ≈øumme of all Duty; Grace is the new birth of the Soul, whereby it takes up another nature, a new nature, a ≈øpiritual Godlike nature; as Chri≈øt was born and thereby took on him the nature of man, and was made fle≈øh; ≈øo man is born by grace, and thereby takes upon him the nature of God, and is made Spirit: and here you have at once the great my≈øtery of Grace in the lowe≈øt deba≈øement of a Saviour, and the highe≈øt advancement of a Sinner, for the Lord Chri≈øt could not be more deba≈øed, than to be born; it was nothing ≈øo great an aba≈øement for Chri≈øt to dye, as for him to be born, for being once made man, it is no wonder for to die, but being the great God, it is a wonder that ever he ≈øhould be made man. Lo here is the deba≈øement of Chri≈øt; yet if he had been born to a Crown, to Honour, it had been ≈øomething, but he was born to ≈øhame, to ≈øorrow, and death; but man by grace is born to a Crown, to a Kingdom, he hath a title to all the glory and ble≈ø≈øedne≈øs of heaven, from the fir≈øt moment of his new birth; So it is in the Text, Grace be unto you and Peace.

Peace, in Scripture, is a very comprehen≈øive term, it carries in it all happine≈øs. It was the common greeting of the Jews, Peace be unto you. Thus David by his Proxy ≈øalutes Nabal, peace be to thee, and thy hou≈øe; and the Apo≈øtle here alludes to this form of ≈øalutation, that he might mix new Te≈øtament mercy to old Te≈øtament manners; he fir≈øt ≈øtiles Grace, before peace; as Jacob did with his Veni≈øon, he made it a ≈øavory meat, ≈øuch as I≈øaac loved. Peace is the glory of Heaven, in the bo≈øom of God, and brought into the world in the arms of Angels; the fir≈øt peace you read of in the Go≈øpel, was peace by the Admini≈øtration of Angels, Luke 2.3‚ñ™ 4. And ≈øuddenly there was with the Angels a multitude of the heavenly Ho≈øt, prai≈øing & ≈øaying, glory be to God in the highe≈øt, and on earth peace, good will towards men. And when our Lord Chri≈øt fir≈øt ≈øent out his Di≈øciples, this was the Doctrine that he bid them preach, Mat. 10.12, 13. When you come into a hou≈øe, ≈øalute it, and if it be worthy, let grace and peace come upon it. Mark here by the way, our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt is no enemy to good manners, he would not have Chri≈øtians to be Clowns, which is the u≈øe of ≈øome among us, who would have their Religion quarrel with good manners; no, but In what≈øoever city or town you enter, ≈øalute it, and let grace, peace come upon it: that is, wi≈øh peace to them, ≈øaying, the peace of God be upon this place, upon the head and hearts of all in it. So that peace is both a Go≈øpel-≈øalutation when Mini≈øters and people meet, and it's a Go≈øpel-valediction, when the Mini≈øter and the People parts. So did the Apo≈øtle, and ≈øo do I now, Grace be with you and Peace.

I ob≈øerve in Mat. 10.13, 14. our Lord bids his Di≈øciples when they enter
into a hou≈øe, If the hou≈øe be worthy, to let their peace come upon it, but if they be not worthy, let grace, peace return unto you. In≈øtead of leaving peace with them, to ≈øhake off the du≈øt of their feet again≈øt them: that is, to ≈øhew that God will ≈øhake them off as du≈øt, and tread them under feet as fuel. My Brethren, your diligent attendance on the Word at this place hath comfortably prevented that part of my charge, to ≈øhake off the du≈øt of my feet; for, how beautiful have the feet of a poor worm been unto you, being ≈øhod with the preparation of the Go≈øpel of Chri≈øt? div.p: 1. It is a common fin, and therefore it is ≈øet down in the greate≈øt latitude, the righteous peri≈øheth, and no man layeth it to heart; that is, very few: And merciful men are taken away, no man con≈øidering; that is, very few.

If a man ≈øhould always live on earth, always be young, rich, and healthful, it would be unwelcome news, for while we are in the body, we are ab≈øent from the Lord, and ≈øubject to ≈øin; and therefore when Peter asked Chri≈øt what ≈øhould be done with John, Chri≈øt tells him, If I will that he tarry till I come, what is that to thee? from henceforth there went a report abroad that John ≈øhould not dye; Now the Apo≈øtle him≈øelf was much di≈øplea≈øed with this report, and looked upon it as a great affliction that he ≈øhould not dye, and therefore he him≈øelf confutes it; But yet Je≈øus (≈øaid he) ≈øaid not that he ≈øhould not dye; as if he had ≈øaid, God forbid that I ≈øhould not dye.
Before I come to Application of this point, give me leave to ≈øpeak ≈øomthing to the ≈øecond point, and ≈øo I ≈øhall apply them both together.
The ≈øecond Doctrine is this, That the peri≈øhing of a righteous man, is nothing but a gathering him to God, Chri≈øt, and the ble≈ø≈øed ≈øociety of Saints and Angels in Heaven.

Fir≈øt, That the righteous are in a ≈øcattered condition while they are in this world, and that three ways.

The godly are ≈øcattered in this life from the glorious pre≈øence of God in Heaven, indeed they are never ≈øcattered from the gracious pre≈øence of God, but ≈øometimes they are ≈øcattered from the comfortable pre≈øence of God; as long as we live in the world, we ≈øhall be ≈øcattered from the glorious pre≈øence of God: for while we are in the body, we are ab≈øent from the Lord.

div.p: Secondly, This implies a bringing of Gods people out of this ≈øcattered condition; it is a gathering of the Righteous out of this world into another, from a ≈øinful per≈øecuted world, into a ≈øinle≈øs glorious world; from diver≈øity of dwellings on earth, to dwell altogether in one Heaven; it is a gathering out of the reach of Men and Devils, and a gathering them not only to the gracious, but to the glorious pre≈øence of God and Chri≈øt, and to the ≈øouls of ju≈øt men made perfect, and to the general a≈ø≈øembly of the fir≈øt born, and to the City of the living God, the Heavenly Jeru≈øalem, where they ≈øhall live together, never to be ≈øcattered again. To under≈øtand this the better, let me offer three things to you, ≈øhewing you that the Godly are gathered to God three ways: in this life, at death, and at the day of Judgment.

Fir≈øt, The Righteous are gathered to God in this life, and that is at their fir≈øt conver≈øion, for by nature we are Aliens and ≈øtrangers to God, ≈øcattered from any union or communion with God, not only ≈øcattered from the glorious, but from the gracious pre≈øence of God. La≈øtly, We ≈øhall be gathered to God at the day of judgment, it is called the day of the gathering of the Saints together: a day when all the Saints that are, have been, or ≈øhall be, ≈øhall be gathered together, 2 The≈ø. 2.1.
