Fir≈øt, learn hence the preciou≈øne≈øs of every righteous man, the great God will not gather things of no value; great men do not u≈øe to gather chaff and ≈øtraw; and therefore, when Chri≈øt ≈øaid of Jo≈øiah, I will gather thee to thy Fathers, it was a ≈øign he was a precious Pearl worth the gathering, and of a high value and account in the ≈øight of God, and ≈øo is every true Child of God, right dear and precious are they in the ≈øight of God, both living, and dying; they are bought with a great price, not with Gold and Silver, and other corruptible things, but they are bought with the precious blood of the Son of God: they are as precious to God as thee Apple of his eye: ≈øo precious that he hath given Chri≈øt for them, and to them; ≈øo precious that he called them his Jewels, his peculiar trea≈øure, his Jedidiahs, and therefore God will not ≈øuffer them to peri≈øh, but gather them to him≈øelf before the evil day come, as the Husbandman gathers in the Corn, before the Bea≈øt go out into the field.

Secondly, Learn hear what rea≈øon we have to be comforted in the death of a righteous man or woman, becau≈øe their death is not a peri≈øhing, but a gathering to God and Chri≈øt, and the ≈øociety of Saints and Angels. The death of a righteous man is no more than if a Merchant that hath abundance of Jewels in a far Countrey, he ≈øhould ≈øend for the ‚Ä¢ home. Why death to a righteous man is nothing but God ≈øending for his Jewels home. Such a phra≈øe there is in Mal. 3.17. In the day that I make up my Jewels, they ≈øhall be mine. In this life they are imperfect Jewels; they are like Gold in the Oare mingled with a great deal of dro≈øs; and death is nothing but a perfection of the Jewels; death is nothing more; and God doth nothing by death, but as a Gold-≈øiner gathers up all his ends of Gold and Silver; it is nothing but ju≈øt as if a Father ≈øhould ≈øend for his Son home, that had been a long time ab≈øent from him, to his own hou≈øe: it is a carrying us to our Fathers hou≈øe. And therefore let us be comforted when our Righteous Friends dye, though their death be
matter of ≈øorrow to us, in regard of the lo≈øs, that we ≈øu≈øtain by their death, and becau≈øe their death is a warning-piece of evil to come: yet in regard of them we have no cau≈øe to mourn. I ≈øpeak this of tho≈øe that are related to the righteous, when they dye; did you ever here of a Husbandman that mourned for the carrying in of his Corn into the Barn? or a Jeweller mourn for making up of his Jewels? Let us mourn rather that we are le≈øt ≈øcattered among the wicked of the earth, and from the glorious pre≈øence of God and Chri≈øt: and let us morn for tho≈øe that are ≈øcattered from Chri≈øt, and from grace: and for tho≈øe that whil≈øt they live are ≈øcattered, and when they dye are gathered to the Devil and his Angels. Let us not mourn for tho≈øe that dye in Chri≈øt, but let us mourn for tho≈øe that live out of Chri≈øt; let us not mourn over the body the ≈øoul hath left, but let us mourn over the ≈øoul God hath left.

The third u≈øe is of Con≈øolation to all the people of God, in reference to evil times that are coming upon us, or to the evil of times. Whatever befalls a Child of God in this life, though he be ≈øcattered by wicked men, from England into forreign Countries, though he wanders up and down in De≈øarts and Wilderne≈ø≈øes, though he be ≈øcattered from hou≈øe to pri≈øon, yet there ≈øhall be a gathering time ≈øhortly: there will a time come when all the Saints ≈øhall be gathered to Chri≈øt, and to one another, never to part any more. The death of Gods people is not a peri≈øhing, but a gathering: comfort your ≈øelves therefore with the≈øe words again≈øt the fear of death: look upon death as a gathering, as a gathering to Chri≈øt: you are here as Daniel in the Lyons Den, as Jeremiah in the dungeon; yet there will come a gathering, and if you dye in a good cau≈øe, you ≈øhall not peri≈øh, but be gathered to Chri≈øt, to his Saints and Angels.

But you will ≈øay, If I were ≈øure when I dye, that I ≈øhould be gathered to Chri≈øt, to live for ever with him, this would be matter of great con≈øolation to me: but you told me, the wicked are gathered by death, as well as the Godly: how ≈øhall I know whether (when I come to dye) I ≈øhall be gathered to the Devil and his Angels, or to Chri≈øt and his Angels? How ≈øhall I know whether I ≈øhall be gathered at death, as a bundle of tears to be burned in Hell, or a bundle of Wheat to be carryed up into the Barn of Heaven?
I an≈øwer, You may know it by four things.

list.item:
1. If you are righteous, then you ≈øhall be gathered to Chri≈øt at death; For the Righteous ≈øhall go into everla≈øting life: Heaven is entailed upon righteous men; by Righteou≈øne≈øs I mean the imputed Righteou≈øne≈øs, and imparted Righteou≈øne≈øs of Je≈øus Chri≈øt: I wave the explication of them, becau≈øe time will not give leave. Know you not (≈øaith the Apo≈øtle) that no
unrighteous man ≈øhall inherit the Kingdom of God? Damnation is entailed upon unrighteous men.

2. If you are merciful, you ≈øhall be gathered to Chri≈øt: if you are one that is full of bowels of compa≈ø≈øion to the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed members of Chri≈øt Je≈øus, for Chri≈øt hath ≈øaid it, Ble≈ø≈øed are the merciful, for they ≈øhall obtain mercy, now if you are hard-hearted, covetous, worldly minded, remember that Text, He ≈øhall have judgement without mercy, that ≈øhews no mercy.

3. He that is gathered to the ≈øecond Adam by faith in this world, ≈øhall certainly be gathered unto Chri≈øt by vi≈øion in the other world; Chri≈øt Je≈øus will ≈øave all his members, and you mu≈øt know that faith is a tran≈øplanting grace, it is not only a heart-purifying, but a world-overcoming grace: It takes a man out of the old Adam, and puts him into a new Adam; it takes a man out of the root of ≈øcattering, and puts him into the root of union and conjunction: Wherefore you that are now joyned to Chri≈øt by faith here, ≈øhall be joyned to Chri≈øt in glory hereafter. But now, you that are vagabonds, Cains, and aliens from the life of God, and from the life of grace: You that are wooden members, wooden legs in Chri≈øts body, that have no real conjunction with Chri≈øt, you ≈øhall not be gathered to him in glory.

div.p: La≈øtly, If you are gathered here to the Saints by love, then you ≈øhall be gathered to the Saints in Heaven, and to the everla≈øting injoyment of God with them to all eternity. Confider this, every man ≈øhall be gathered (when he dies) to tho≈øe whom he delights, and choo≈øeth to keep pany with while he lives in this world. If you are gathered to the wicked in love and affection here, you ≈øhall be gathered to them at death in hell and de≈øtruction, for it is pity companions ≈øhould be parted, wheat mu≈øt to wheat, and tares to tares, for wheat and tares ≈øhall not be bound together at the la≈øt day.
The la≈øt u≈øe is of exhortation: If the righteous mu≈øt peri≈øh, and if their death be nothing but a gathering, then take this threefold Exhortation.

Fir≈øt, Let us labor to make the be≈øt u≈øe we can of our godly friends and Mini≈øters before they be gathered; let us do as Eli≈øha did, he was told that his Ma≈øter Elijah was to be taken up to Heaven, and therefore he would never leave him till he had got the ≈øpirit of Elijah doubled upon him: If Eli≈øha had not thought that Elijah would have been taken up that day, he would never have followed him ≈øo punctually and in≈øeparably as he did. O beloved! did you believe that Text, Zach. 1.5. of which we have often had experience, Your fathers, where are they? and the prophets, do they live for ever? Indeed if they did live for ever, we might get good from them when we plea≈øe, becau≈øe we are ≈øure never to lo≈øe
them; but they live not for ever, but mu≈øt peri≈øh, and be taken up to heaven: And therefore whil≈øt we have them, let us make what u≈øe we can of them, before they be taken away from us. It is a great fault among the people of God, that they make no more u≈øe of their Godly friends and Mini≈øters. I have known many that have godly relations that have died, that it hath been the greate≈øt burden on their con≈øciences, that they got no more good by tho≈øe Godly Relations while they lived. Many of us deal with our Mini≈øters, as we do with a ≈øtrange ≈øight that is to be ≈øeen near our doors; we are not ≈øo much ≈øolicitous when we ≈øee it, but a ≈øtranger that comes from a far Country, is curious, and very careful pre≈øently to ≈øee it. So do we in this City e≈øpecially; I have had experience of it by being here many years; ≈øtrangers that come out of the Country, many times get that good by a Mini≈øter, that his own people do not, becau≈øe they think their Mini≈øter is continually with them: but a ≈øtranger knows he is there but for a day, and he hears ≈øo, that he carries Chri≈øt home with him, and a great deal of con≈øolation al≈øo. Beloved, this is a great fault; I be≈øeech you remember, the Righteous mu≈øt be gathered: let us therefore do with them as we do with Books that are borrowed: if a man borrows a Book, he knows he mu≈øt keep it but for a day or two, and therefore he will be ≈øure to read it over, whereas if the Book be a mans own, he laies it a≈øide, becau≈øe he knows he can read it at any time. Remember, your Mini≈øters are but lent you, they are not your own, and you know not but that God may take away your El ‚Ä¢ jahs from you this night: Therefore make what u≈øe you can of them, while you have them.

Secondly, Mu≈øt the Righteous be taken away? Then let the Righteous make con≈øcience of doing what good they can before they are taken away. Beloved, if it were po≈ø≈øible for the Godly to grieve in Heaven, this would be their greate≈øt ≈øorrow, that they have done God no more ≈øervice here upon earth. Be wi≈øe for God, O ye Righteous! do as old men that have rich places & offices, they labour to buy the rever≈øion of their places for their Children: So mu≈øt you to whom God hath given great gifts and graces, labor to propagate your gifts & graces, that there may be no lo≈øs by your death. Ob≈øerve the cares of St. Paul the aged in his exhortation to Timothy, 2 Tim. 3.4, 5, Watch thou all things, endure afflictions, do the work of an Evangeli≈øt, make full proof of thy Mini≈øtry, why ≈øo? for I am now ready to be offered, and the time of my departure is at hand, and therefore work thou, ≈øee that thou endure affliction, preach the Go≈øpel as becomes a Mini≈øter of the Go≈øpel, that there may be no lo≈øs by my departure. So in 2 Tim. 2.2. The things that thou ha≈øt heard of me among many witne≈ø≈øes, the ≈øame commit thou to faithful men that ≈øhall be able to teach others
al≈øo. Hath God committed any thing to you, a trea≈øure of Learning or Grace? commit it to young Mini≈øters that they may commit it to others, that ≈øo there may be a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of Gifts and Graces: Do as Phy≈øitians do, that labour to communicate their skill to their Children, and to others; ≈øo ≈øhould we, that there may be a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of Godly ones, that Godline≈øs may be entailed upon us, and our Relations.

Thirdly and la≈øtly, let us all labour to be ≈øuch, that when we dye, when we come to be gathered, we may be gathered to Chri≈øt and his Angels; not to the Devil and his angels; And for that purpo≈øe let us labour to be merciful and righteous, and let us be gathered to Chri≈øt by Faith, and to one another by love and dear affection: and then we ≈øhall be gathered at the great day to Chri≈øt, and the ble≈ø≈øed company of the Saints & Angels.
There are 4 ob≈øervations yet behind, but I mu≈øt wave them at this time.

I have now another Sermon to preach, and I cannot without injury to you that are alive, and without wrong to the memory of my dearly beloved Brother, but ≈øpeak ≈øomething of him, at who≈øe Funeral we are met this Evening, not ≈øo much for his commendation, he needs not, but for our imitation; it is pity, great pity ≈øomething ≈øhould not be ≈øaid, that this Reverend Mini≈øter, though dead, may yet preach this night; and I have ≈øo much to ≈øay of him, that I know not where to begin, and when I have begun, I hardly know how to make an end: I mu≈øt confe≈øs, the little time alloted me for the providing this ≈øolemn work, and the nece≈ø≈øary avocations in this little time, have hindred me from enforming my ≈øelf about his Breeding and manner of Education at Emanuel Colledge, under Mr. Steaker, and his excellent carriage and conver≈øe with Mr. Hilder≈øham, Mr. Dod, Mr. Ball, Mr. Langly, and other Mini≈øters famous in their generations; and the many pre≈ø≈øures and hard≈øhips that he ≈øuffered in tho≈øe parts and times, for the keeping of his con≈øcience pure from that which he counted ≈øin, and therefore I mu≈øt draw a vail over that part of his life, and confine my di≈øcour≈øe only to the time ≈øince his coming to live with us in London, which is about the ≈øpace of twenty two, or twenty three years, all which time I have had the happine≈øs to be intimately acquainted with him, in≈øomuch as that I can freely and clearly profe≈øs, and that with a ≈øad heart, that I, and many others, have lo≈øt a real, wi≈øe, and Godly friend, brother, and fellow-labourer in the Lord; the Church hath lo≈øt an eminent Member, and choice pillar; and this City hath lo≈øt an antient faithful, and painful Mini≈øter; who by his Prayers and Holy life, did ≈øeek to keep off the judgements of God from falling on us; and the le≈øs ≈øen≈øible the City is of this lo≈øs, the greater is the lo≈øs. I fear we may too truly repeat the words in the Text, The righteouus peri≈øheth, and no man lays it to
heart: and mereiful men are taken away, none con≈øidering that the righteous are taken away from the evil to come. I have read of Philo the Jew, and by chance met with the ≈øame in the life of St. Ambro≈øe, that when they came to any City or Town, and heard of the death of any Godly man, though never ≈øo poor, they would both of them mourn exceedingly, becau≈øe of the great lo≈øs that place had by the death of that Godly man, and becau≈øe it was a warning-piece from God of evil approaching. But we have had many Godly men, and Godly Mini≈øters taken away of late, and yet I fear me, but few lay it to heart; and therefore as I ≈øaid, the lo≈øs is the greater to this City, becau≈øe it is ≈øo little ≈øen≈øible of it. It is a great lo≈øs al≈øo to his relations; his Wife hath lo≈øt a dear and loving Husband, his Si≈øter a brother, his Pari≈øh and Congregation a faithful Pa≈øtor.

The Mini≈øterial excellencies of many Mini≈øters were collected and concentred in one Simeon A≈øh, he was a Bazalcel in Gods Tabernacle, a Ma≈øter-builder, an old Di≈øciple, a Polycarp, a Chri≈øtian of long ≈øtanding in the School of Chri≈øt, a burning and a ≈øhining light, one whom many Mini≈øters and other good Chri≈øtians called Father, in≈øomuch that it was a common proverb in this City, Father A≈øh; and I believe many experimentally weep over him, as the King did over the Prophet Eli≈øha, My Father, my Father, the chariots of I≈ørael, and the hor≈øemen thereof! for he lived de≈øired, and died lamented; not only in the City, but I believe in many places in the Country where he was known. But more particulary, there were twelve excellencies I ob≈øerved in this reverend Mini≈øter, and my dear Brother, that were as 12 Jewels or precious Pearls in that Crown with which God had crowned him: I ≈øhall name them for your imitation and benefit; He needs them not, for he is above our Eulogy.

The fir≈øt and chief Jewel that did beautifie & adorn this our Brother, was his ≈øincerity and uprightne≈øs in heart; which indeed is not a ≈øingle Grace, but the ≈øoul of all Grace, and the interlineary that mu≈øt run through all Grace; what is faith if it be not unfeigned? what will love to God profit you if it be not without di≈ø≈øimulation? what is repentance worth if it be not in truth? as the body without the ≈øoul is a rotten carka≈øs, ≈øo is all grace without ≈øincerity; this is the ≈øoul of all grace, this is the girdle of truth. Sincerity is that which girts all our ≈øpiritual armor together, and makes them u≈øeful: what advantage is it to have the brea≈øtplate of Righteou≈øne≈øs, the ≈øhield of Faith, the helmet of Hope, if they be but painted things? it is the girdle of ≈øincerity that makes all the other parts of our armor u≈øeful. Now this excellent grace of ≈øincerity was eminent in our dear Brother; he was a true Nathaniel in whom there was no guile; I mean no allowed hypocri≈øie, this was that which carried
him through the pangs of death with a great deal of comfort; for he was able to ≈øay with Hezekiah, Remember, O Lord, how I have walked before thee in truth, and with a perfect heart. He could ≈øay with Paul, this is my rejoycing, the te≈øtimony of my con≈øcience, that in ≈øimplicity and godly ≈øincerity, I have had my conver≈øation in this world.

2. Another grace was his humilicy, this is a grace that he was cloathed withal, and it is a rare grace: for God dwells with the humble he re≈øi≈øts the proud; but he gives grace to the humble. This Reverend Mini≈øter was low in his own eyes, and therefore very high in Gods eyes; he had a mean e≈øteem of him≈øelf, and therefore he was high in e≈øteem with God. He was as Jacob ≈øaid of him≈øelf, le≈øs than the lea≈øt of Gods mercies, and therefore he was made partaker of the be≈øt of Gods mercies. He was like an ear of Corn full of fruit, bowing down in thankfulne≈øs to God.

3. Another Jewel was the fruitfulne≈øs of his di≈øcour≈øe; for it may be ≈øaid of him as it was of Chri≈øt, he went about doing good: where ever he went, he ≈øcattered his goodne≈øs, this all that knew him, knew to be true. He was full of good di≈øcour≈øe where ever he came; when I was with him in his ≈øickne≈øs, he took occa≈øion to complain much, and not without ju≈øt cau≈øe; (God grant his complaint may make impre≈ø≈øion upon our hearts) he complained that it was a great fault of Mini≈øters, that when they met together, they di≈øcour≈øed no more of Chri≈øt, of Heaven, and of the concernments of the other world, and profe≈ø≈øed that if GOD ≈øhould re≈øtore him, he would be more careful in his di≈øcour≈øe, and more fruitful than ever yet he had been.

3. Another Jewel that beautified this Righteous man, was his mercifulne≈øs; he was a merciful man, which he manife≈øted not onely in his charity to the members of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, but in his frequent vi≈øiting of ≈øick per≈øons, and per≈øons that needed Spiritual phy≈øick. I know not any Mini≈øter in this City more careful in vi≈øiting the ≈øick than he was.

5. Another Jewel was his Prudence and Spiritual wi≈ødom; he was not onely a Pious and Godly, but a Wi≈øe and Prudent Mini≈øter: that had zeal for God, but knew how to mingle his zeal with di≈øcretion; di≈øcretion is nothing but frantick fury; di≈øcretion without zeal will quickly eat out the heart of Religion, and eat Religion out of the heart. Zeal without di≈øcretion is not a coal from the Altar, but a coal kindled by the wild-fire of pa≈ø≈øion, that is able to ≈øet a Nation on fire; but this Reverend Mini≈øter had zeal ≈øweetly tempered with di≈øcretion.

9. Another Jewel was his Patience; God was plea≈øed to exerci≈øe
him with long and great afflictions, by rea≈øon of the Gout, that did often, e≈øpecially of late years, affix him to his bed, and afflict him with great pain; but God was plea≈øed to put his everla≈øting Arms underneath him, ≈øupporting him under all his pains, and giving him a great mea≈øure of patience, in≈øomuch, that in patience he did po≈ø≈øe≈øs his ≈øoul, and patience had its perfect work in him.

The 7 Jewel was his high valuation of Je≈øus Chri≈øt; a written coppy for us to follow, and for you his people al≈øo. Being with him in his la≈øt ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, he exhorted me, and other Mini≈øters with him, to preach much of Je≈øus Chri≈øt; and to ≈øpeak to him of Je≈øus Chri≈øt; and he ≈øaid, When I con≈øider my be≈øt duties, I ≈øink, I dye, I de≈øpair; but when I think of Chri≈øt, I have enough, he is all, and in all. I think the≈øe were his very words. I de≈øire (≈øaid he) to know nothing but Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and him Crucified: I account all things dung and dro≈øs, that I may be found in Chri≈øt: To this effect he ≈øpake in the morning before the evening in which he dyed, ≈øpeaking much of Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

1. Another Jewel was, his diligence in preaching the Go≈øpel in ≈øea≈øon, and out of ≈øea≈øon; in the time of his health he was a painful, laborious Preacher; one that did not preach to tickle the ear, but to wound the heart; not to plea≈øe, but to profit; not ≈øeeking the applau≈øe of the People, but the ≈øalvation of their ≈øouls: This you all know to be true.

2. Another Jewel that did beautifie and adorn this Reverend Mini≈øter, was his excellent gift in Prayer; and herein he was very eminent, and did exceed many, nay I may ≈øay, mo≈øt of his Brethren: As Apolies was mighty in the Scriptures, ≈øo was he (as you all know) mighty in Prayer; he was a Jacob, very skilful in wre≈øtling with God; like Mo≈øes he often ≈øtood in the Gap, and at mo≈øt Fa≈øts, all the time of his health, he was a Mini≈øter that was cho≈øen to conclude with Prayer: and this heightens the lo≈øs that we ≈øu≈øtein by the death of this Godly Mini≈øter; becau≈øe we have lo≈øt the benefit of his Prayers, which is an invaluable lo≈ø≈øe; for though I doubt not but he prays in Heaven for the Church in general, yet I believe he prays not for any in particular; as not knowing what our condition is, For Abraham knows us not, for the Saints in Heaven know not what is done upon earth. The lo≈ø≈øe therefore is the greater, becau≈øe we have lo≈øt not only a preaching, but a praying Mini≈øter: And give me leave to add, that this excellency in this Mini≈øter is ≈øufficient to prove,
1. That there is a gift of Prayer, which ≈øome again≈øt all rea≈øon do denie.
2. That conceived prayers, when uttered by one that hath the gift of prayer, are not vain tautologies, or empty repetitions, and a rate of non-≈øence, as ≈øome unju≈øtly charge men with, but they are the bleatings
of Gods Spirit, that pierce not onely into the ears and hearts of the hearers, but into the ears and heart of God him≈øelf.

10. The next Jewel was, he had great acquaintance and communion with God; for he was of a long ≈øtanding in the School of Chri≈øt, and a good Proficient in that School. Much acquaintance he had with God, he was often in the Mount with God, and came down with his face ≈øhining, though he in his mode≈øty did not ≈øee it; and when he came to dye, he was able to ≈øay as Dr. Pre≈øton did when he lay a dying, I ≈øhall change my place, but not my company.

11. Another Jewel was, his comfortable pa≈ø≈øage out of this world, dying with a great deal of calmne≈øs and ≈øerenity upon his Con≈øcience: The morning before he dyed, I heard him ≈øay the≈øe words. It is one thing to ≈øpeak of Chri≈øt, and of Heaven, and another thing to feel the con≈øolation of Chri≈øt, and of Heaven, as I do, clapping his hand on his brea≈øt. Another time I heard him ≈øay, The comforts of a holy Life are real, ≈øoul-≈øupporting; and that he felt the reality of tho≈øe comforts, and that by him we might know it was not in vain to ≈øerve God. And I cannot forget this ≈øpeech the morning before he dyed, I am a little ≈øtraitened, but I care no more for my life than I do for this phillip. That which was ≈øaid of old Simeon, Luke 2. may be ≈øaid of this reverend Mr. Simeon A≈øh, who was a Simeon, a ju≈øt and devout man, an old ≈øervant of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, one that waited for the con≈øolation of I≈ørael; one that dyed, though not with Chri≈øt in his bodily Arm, yet with Chri≈øt in the Arms of his faith; and when he dyed, could ≈øay, as it is there, Now Lord, lette≈øt thou thy ≈øervant depart in peace, for mine eyes have ≈øeen thy ≈øalvation.

La≈øtly, Another Jewel was his con≈øtancy and per≈øeverance; he was not a Reed ≈øhaken with every wind, but as firm as a Rock, an immoveable pillar in Gods hou≈øe, he was unchangeable in changeable times: in Religion he was a hou≈øe built upon a Rock, not on the Sand; and as he lived, ≈øo he dyed holily, even as the ancient Patriarchs that dyed in the faith, and endured faithfully unto the death.

Now this excellent Mini≈øter of Chri≈øt thus beautified with the≈øe Jewels, is now peri≈øhed as to his outward man, gathered to God, to Chri≈øt, and the ble≈ø≈øed company of Saints and Angels. The Application that I ≈øhall make of this di≈øcour≈øe, is this:

list.item: 1. To us Mini≈øters.
2. To you of this Pari≈øh and Congregation.

div.p:
Fir≈øt, to us Mini≈øters. God hath of late years taken to him≈øelf many famous men: ≈øeven of the Lecturers of Cornhil are dead, Mr. Burroughs, Dr. Bolton, Mr. Sedgwick. Mr, Whitakers, Mr. Cranford, Mr. Vines, and now Mr. A≈øh. I might name many other excellent Mini≈øters that are
dead, as Dr. Gouge, Mr. Walker, Mr. Gataker, Mr. Mar≈øhal, Mr. Robin≈øon, and lately Mr. Cook, with many more: Now all the≈øe are warning-pieces from Heaven of Judgements approaching; For the righteous peri≈øh, and no man lays it to heart; and merciful men are taken away, none con≈øidering that the righteous are taken away from the evil to come. Thus Methu≈øelah dyed a year before the Flood: Now Methu≈øelah in Hebrew ≈øignifies a me≈ø≈øenger of death. Thus Au≈øtin dyed a little before Hippo was taken; and Pareus a little before Hiddleburg was taken, and
‚Ä¢ uther a little before the wars in Germany began. The death of the Godly is like the ≈øeparating the I≈øraelites from the Tents of Corah and his company, like the taking of Lot out of Sodom. When the I≈øraelites departed from Corah and his company, the earth ≈øwallowed them up; and when Lot departed out of Sodom, God rained down fire and brim≈øtone upon them. Let the thoughts of the≈øe things cau≈øe us to provide our Arks, to get our Zoars. Let it teach young Samuels to ri≈øe up in the room of old Elies; young Eli≈øha's in the room of old Elijahs; and young Timothies in the room of Paul the aged; that there may be a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of Go≈øpel-mini≈øters to hold forth the Word of life to the Nation. And let us labour to be Inheritors of the Twelve Excellencies, that beautified this our Reverend Brother.

Secondly, Let me ≈øpeak a few words to you of this Pari≈øh, the Auditors of this worthy Mini≈øter. There is ≈øcarce one man of an hundred, that under≈øtands the tye and obligation that is betwixt a Mini≈øter and his People. Oh the Love and Affection that ought to be betwixt them! Paul tells the Galatians, that they could have plucked out their eyes for him if need were. Chry≈øo≈øtom tells us, that when Miletus was taken away by death from his People, their hearts ≈øunk with ≈øorrow; and ≈øuch love had they to him, that they called all their Children by his name, and got his picture engraven on their Rings. And I have read of Chry≈øo≈øtom, that when he was bani≈øhed from his People there was not a corner in the City, but was full of People weeping and lamenting. The lo≈øs of a Godly Mini≈øter is a publick lo≈øs, and therefore there ought to be a publick mourning: it is a ≈øoul lo≈øs, and therefore methinks every one of you ≈øhould weep and mourn; you have lo≈øt your common Father: you of this Congregation have lo≈øt your ≈øpiritual Father, your ≈øpiritual Shepheard: you have lo≈øt your eyes, your guide: and indeed it is you that are his Flock, that mu≈øt commend your Mini≈øter by practi≈øing that which he preached; ≈øaith the Apo≈øtle, 2 Cor. 3.1. Do we again begin to commend our ≈øelves, or need we, as ≈øome others, Epi≈øtles of Commendations to you, or Letters of commendation from you? Ye are our Epi≈øtle written in our bearts, known and
read all men. As if the Apo≈øtle ≈øhould ≈øay, do we need Letters of commendation? is it nece≈ø≈øary that we ≈øhould ≈øpend time in commending our Mini≈øtry? you are our Letters of commendation: your holine≈øs & piety commends a Mini≈øter above all other things. As when a man comes into an Orchard, or Vineyard, (≈øaith Chry≈øo≈øtom) and ≈øees every thing skilfully handled, and neatly trimmed, he need not ≈øpend time in commending the Vine-dre≈ø≈øer, or Carpenter, the work its ≈øelf commends them. So ought it to be among you. When we preach the Funeral Sermons of Mini≈øters, we mu≈øt look into the Pari≈øh or Congregation and ≈øee what Letters of commendation there are: whether the proficiency of the Auditors commend their Mini≈øters, I grant, it is not always true: God doth not always give ≈øucee≈øs to a godly Mini≈øter, but the wor≈øt is yours, I had almo≈øt ≈øaid, the cur≈øe is yours: but I will ≈øpeak mode≈øtly, the wor≈øt is yours. Tell me, how many of you are able to ≈øay, I ble≈øs God that ever ≈øuch a Mini≈øter was ≈øent among us: ble≈ø≈øed be God that ever we heard him preach? what ≈øeal of his mini≈øtry is there here among you? he was in another, and another place of this City, it may be here are people from all places that have been his Auditors, what ≈øeal of his Mini≈øtry is there now to be found among you? how many Souls hath he pluck'd out of the ≈ønares of the Devil? how many of you have gone weeping from a Sermon, knocking your brea≈øts, and pricked at the heart of ≈øin, crying out, Men and Brethren what ≈øhall we do to be ≈øaved? your tears and mourning for ≈øin, the≈øe are the Auditors that commend your Mini≈øters. Go home now and think with your ≈øelves, what can I remember of all the Sermons that I have heard from Mr. A≈øh? and give me leave to tell you, woe be to you, if as your Mini≈øter be dead, ≈øo all the Sermons he made die with him: for as Abel being dead, yet ≈øpeaketh, ≈øo ≈øhall the Sermons of this worthy Mini≈øter, at the great day, ≈øpeak for you, or again≈øt you: for they are ≈øpiritual Talents that God hath be-tru≈øted you with, and you mu≈øt be accountable: both he and you ≈øhall appear before the Tribunal of God; your Mini≈øter ≈øhall be examined, how he can free him≈øelf from the guilt of Soul-blood? and you ≈øhall be examined, what fruit you brought forth an≈øwerable to the means you have enjoyed? and if it appear you have been unprofitable and unfruitful hearers, Chri≈øt will ≈øay, Ca≈øt the unprofitable ≈øervants into utter darkne≈øs. But I hope better things of you, and things that accompany ≈øalvation. What ever was good in this reverend Mini≈øter, let i ‚Ä¢ live in you: and though he be dead, yet let not his Sermons that he preached die with you, but let them be in you: that at the great day, when he and you appear before God, he may be able to ≈øay, here am I, and the Children that thou ha≈øt given me.

div.head: Dr. Seaman's Farewel-Sermon.

epigraph.q: Now the God of Peace, that brought again from the dead our Lord Je≈øus, that great Shepheard of the ≈øheep, through the blood of the Everla≈øting Covenant, make you perfect in every good work, to do his will, working in you that which is well-plea≈øing in his ≈øight, through Je≈øus Chri≈øt; to whom be Glory for ever and ever, Amen.

div.p: THe Apo≈øtle, being now upon the conclu≈øion of this Epi≈øtle, after a very large di≈øcovery of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, in all tho≈øe things that belong to his Per≈øon, concerning his Nature, as God, as Man, and concerning his Offices, e≈øpecially concerning his Prie≈øtly; and concerning the ble≈ø≈øings and benefits, e≈øpecially in matters of Sacrifice, doth in this la≈øt Chapter in≈øi≈øt on matters Hortatory; and in the words, draws near to a conclu≈øion, which contains a Prayer, wi≈øh, or de≈øire, which he puts up unto God, in the behalf of them, in order to their good and benefit. Now the God of peace, &c.
In which words, there are two things con≈øiderable.

list.item: 1. The matter, of the Apo≈øtles Prayer.
2. The grounds, which he doth in≈øinuate for Audience.

div.p: In the things he de≈øires, the Matter of the Prayer is laid down in v. 21 and is ≈øummarily and generally propounded in ≈øeveral expre≈ø≈øions; yet neverthele≈øs, ≈øo as they have their Specialities belonging to them. In the beginning he ≈øhews what he aims at, make you perfect, &c. In general it refers to their Sanctification, and that they be throughly ≈øanctified, as to their inward man, and outward conver≈øation, as to tho≈øe things that belong to them, in the habits of their minds, and Eternal carriage.

The Grounds which the Apo≈øtle u≈øes, by way of in≈øinuation for Audience, are contained in the words of the 20. ver≈øe, wherein we have a very large de≈øcription of the Per≈øon prayed unto; The God of peace, that brought again from the dead our Lord Je≈øus, &c. He de≈øcribes him under ≈øuch notes and marks, as ≈øerve much for enlargment, and enforcement, in the matter of prayer.

But here a Que≈øtion may ari≈øe; Seeing Grace is the thing the Apo≈øtle principally de≈øires, and 'tis u≈øual with holy men, both under the Old and New Te≈øtament, to chu≈øe out ≈øuch Attributes, as ≈øure mo≈øt with their particular occa≈øions, and are mo≈øt agreeable to tho≈øe reque≈øts they have, why he doth not apply him≈øelf to God, as the God of all grace, but rather, the God of Peace?

Therein fir≈øt, the Apo≈øtle ≈øeems to make u≈øe of that ≈øame liberty which belongs to holy men. As there is in the General, a Liberty left to Gods
People from God him≈øelf: Paul in this place makes u≈øe of that liberty he had, as to the manner of prayer, u≈øing ≈øuch a de≈øcription of God, as ≈øeemed good to him at pre≈øent. But ≈øecondly, if he be the God of Peace, it follows, he is the God of Grace. If God hath glorified him≈øelf ≈øo far among the Hebrews, as to reconcile them to him≈øelf, by the blood of Chri≈øt, then there is no que≈øtion, God will proceed further; and having provided for tho≈øe things which appertain to their Ju≈øtification, no que≈øtion but he will for tho≈øe things that are nece≈ø≈øary to their Sanctification. Therefore, the Apo≈øtle argues plainly from Ju≈øtification, to Sanctification; He that ju≈øtifies his people through the Blood of Chri≈øt, Sanctifie you by the ≈øpirit of Chri≈øt, make you perfect to do his will, working in you that which is wel-plea≈øing in his ≈øight, &c. So de≈øires we ≈øhould be Sanctified, on the con≈øideration of our Ju≈øtification; having provided for Ju≈øtification, by the blood of Chri≈øt, followes Sanctification by the ≈øpirit of Chri≈øt, 1 The≈ø. 5.23. And the very God of peace ≈øanctifie you wholly, &c. that God who is ally'd to you, the God of peace, and hath provided for you Peace, I de≈øire he would further provide Sanctification; for Sanctification is nothing el≈øe, but the effect of that grace, which is procured for Believers through the blood of Chri≈øt. There is no acce≈øs to God, for Sanctification of our Natures, until we prevail with him for the Ju≈øtification of our per≈øons, and he fir≈øt ≈øhews him≈øelf to be a God of peace, by way of Ju≈øtification, before a God of Grace and Sanctification: But to proceed.
Fir≈øt, for the de≈øcription of the per≈øon; wherein take notice of him.

list.item: 1. By one of his Attributes.
2. By one of his ≈øpecial works, whereby he hath manife≈øted that Attribute.

div.p: 1. The Attribute of God, is implyed, under tho≈øe words, that he is called the God of peace. The Gracious God that provides for reconciliation between him≈øelf and ≈øinners; that finds out ways and means to win tho≈øe who are by nature Children of wrath, to be the Children of God. There is no peace, but God is Author of, whether natural peace, or civil peace, or political peace, he is plea≈øed to provide for them: but there is a tran≈øcendent kind of peace, which doth with a peculiarity belong to Gods people, i.e. Spiritual peace between God and ≈øinners, and that inward peace that we enjoy, if our con≈øcience hath been troubled with terrour of ≈øin, Wrath, &c. Peace belongs ≈øo to God; as none of the Creatures can have any Glory of it, P≈øal. 4.7. The peace, is Gods peace: none can effect it, or devi≈øe it, but God; and with re≈øpect to this, he is more e≈øpecially called the God of peace; becau≈øe he hath found out a way to make reconciliation between God and his ≈øinful peri≈øhing Creatures, 2 Cor. 5.19. Ephe≈ø. 2.14. &c. Col. 1.13.

2. There is a ≈øpecial Work of God attributed to him, that the Apo≈øtle takes into con≈øideration, i.e. That he brought again from the dead our Lord Je≈øus, that Great Shepherd of the ≈øheep, through the blood of the everla≈øting Covenant; wherein we have many words, and every word its weight; and we ≈øhall ≈øcarce be able to weigh every one ≈øo, as to take the full ≈øen≈øe and empha≈øis of them. In the words there is,

list.item: 1. Something implyed.
2. Something expre≈ø≈øed.

div.p: 1. Something implyed; namely, That the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt was ≈øometimes in the ≈øtate of death; and that being in the ≈øtate of death, it was not any ordinary power, way, or means, could ran≈øom him. He was in the ≈øtate and condition of the dead: he was, for a while, under the power and dominion of Death: his body, for the ≈øpace of three dayes, lay in the Grave, and in that ≈øen≈øe, he was under the dominion of death, as all dead men are. The Great Shepherd of the ≈øheep could not have his own life, in ≈øome ≈øen≈øe: no intere≈øt he had in God, by vertue of Son≈øhip or any of his Offices, could ≈øave him from death, though the Son of God, and Head of the Church; and Chri≈øt looked upon it ≈øo far from being below him, as he thought it nece≈ø≈øary for him, and it was his glory, J ‚Ä¢ . 10.11, 12. I am the good Shepherd; the good Shepherd gives his life for the ≈øheep: but he that is an Hireling, and not the Shepherd: who≈øe own the ≈øheep are not, ≈øeeth the Wolf coming, and leaveth the ≈øheep and fleeth, &c. And herein the Church of God ≈øeems to have a deadly kind of wound, to be at a deadly lo≈øs, Zach. 13.7. I will ≈ømite the Shepherd, and the ≈øheep ≈øhall be ≈øcattered. But herein lies the wonderful goodne≈øs and wi≈ødom of God, he is plea≈øed to improve, as the life, ≈øo the death of Chri≈øt, for the good of his Church, Luk. 24.16. Ought not Chri≈øt to have ≈øuffered the≈øe things? it was very expedient that ≈øeeing the ≈øheep could not otherwi≈øe be ≈øaved but by the Shepherds dying, that the Shepherd ≈øhould lay down his life for the ≈øheep: and ≈øeeing no other way to make reconciliation to God, it was very expedient Chri≈øt ≈øhould die. Therefore 'tis to be taken notice of, that it doth not mi≈ø-become the Head, therefore not the members of the body. They mu≈øt be content to lay down their lives for the Flock, for ≈øo did the great Shepherd.

2. Something expre≈ø≈øed. Where, take notice,
Fir≈øt of the per≈øon ≈øpoken of.
Secondly, of that which is given us to be taken notice of in particular.
1. The Per≈øon to be taken notice of, is, our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt. That which we have con≈øiderable, is,

Fir≈øt, The Title that belongs to him in his Church: in this regard, called, The Great Shepherd of his ≈øheep; The Shepherd of the ≈øheep, yea, the great Shepherd of the ≈øheep. What≈øoever glory was to be communicated to any Member of the Church, it was fir≈øt put into the head, before they were to be made partakers of it. Some were to be made inferior ranks, Ephe. 4.11. but it was not fit any ≈øhould have ≈øuch glory, to be called Shepherds, before he had that honour of him. Therefore 'tis the Great Shepherd, he that is Shepherd not of a particular Congregation, but of the whole Church of God, he is the Saviour of all his body, he hath the full number of all the Elect, both among the Jews and Gentiles, committed to his charge to ≈øave.

2. What betides this great Shepherd, through Gods grace towards him, that is, that he is brought again from the dead, i. e. that he doth attain to a ≈øtate of Re≈øurrection, and here take notice of this by the way, for con≈øolation; The great Shepherd of the Sheep doth dye, but the great Shepherd of the Sheep ri≈øes again. Herein argues Gods love, that though he would ≈øuffer him to dye, yet not to ≈øee corruption, P≈øal. 16.10. becau≈øe he is the great Shepherd, therefore he mu≈øt dye; but becau≈øe he is the great Shepherd, therefore he cannot continue in the ≈øtate of the Dead; Death mu≈øt not triumph over the great Shepherd of the ≈øheep, no, not by any means. As it was nece≈ø≈øary that he ≈øhould dye, much more that he ≈øhould ri≈øe again. We read Rev. 11. concerning two Prophets: when they had fini≈øhed their cour≈øe they dye, and their dead bodies are ca≈øt into the ≈øtreets, &c. but we read al≈øo of their re≈øurrection. There is a twofold ≈øtate incident to tho≈øe per≈øons, one ≈øtate of dying, another ≈øtate of ri≈øing; and ≈øo it is not peculiar to Chri≈øt only, but to others with him. The great Shepherd of the Sheep dies; no wonder if the little Shepherds dye too. But the great Shepherd is rai≈øed, ≈øo ≈øhall the little ones in their order, and in their time, 1 Pet. 5.6. When the chief Shepherd ≈øhall appear, ye ≈øhall receive a crown of glory that fadeth not away. Re≈øurrection is that which Chri≈øt exemplifies fir≈øt in his own Per≈øon, in order to a≈ø≈øure all his members, they ≈øhall attain to the ≈øame ≈øtate with him; and God is as ea≈øily able to provide, when he ≈øees expedient, to rai≈øe them from the dead, as to ≈øuffer them to dye. Chri≈øt he brought again by a high hand, and in a tryumphant manner; he did not with ≈øo much ≈øorrow and trouble to him≈øelf, and his Di≈øciples, go to, but as triumphantly come from the grave: So can God, with a word, in a moment bring them to life again.

2. By what means the great Shepherd comes to have this honor conferred upon him, that he ≈øhould be rai≈øed from the dead? There was worth enough in his per≈øon, but 'tis not altogether a≈øcribed to this; but (through
the blood of the everla≈øting Covenant) i.e. by, and in, the virtue and efficacy of it: he had died as a Prie≈øt, and his blood was a blood of ≈øacrifice, and it was ≈øhed for the remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øins, and ≈øalvation of ≈øouls; becau≈øe Chri≈øt did die for ≈øo noble an end as this, and in ≈øuch a manner as that his death became a ≈øacrifice, and did ≈øeal the everla≈øting Covenant, wherefore Chri≈øt is the Mediator; therefore with con≈øideration of this blood of Chri≈øt and of the ends, u≈øes, and benefits of it: hereupon it is that Chri≈øt is rai≈øed from the dead. In Zac. 9. the re≈øurrection of Chri≈øt was prophe≈øied of, but by vertue of his blood-≈øhed, ≈øo that Chri≈øt was more fit to be rai≈øed, who dyed for ≈øuch noble and honourable ends, as the glory of God, and ≈øalvation of his people, in the vertue of that Covenant God hath made, and in the vertue of the blood of Chri≈øt, ≈øhed for the ≈øealing of that Covenant.

Now, what this Covenant is, is worthy to be con≈øidered, becau≈øe of its Epithets, called here Everla≈øting Covenant: There was a Temporal Covenant God made with the people of I≈ørael, and that was ≈øealed and confirmed by the blood of Bullocks, &c. Chri≈øt took not on him this Covenant, he did not bind men to ≈øtand by tho≈øe terms contained in the Covenant; for indeed, Chri≈øt came to make void. There is an Eternal Covenant, and that is nothing el≈øe but tho≈øe terms of grace and favour, which are propo≈øed to us in the Doctrine of the Go≈øpel, which amounts to this, who ever repents ≈øhall be ≈øaved: he that repents and for≈øakes his ≈øin ≈øhall find mercy; and that he will be merciful to all on the≈øe conditions in all parts of the world; for the≈øe terms God will not repent of. If men repent they ≈øhall have the benefit of it, and whoever believes ≈øhall be ≈øaved. 'Tis called [Everla≈øting] becau≈øe God will abide by it, both here & hereafter: the ≈øtates of all ≈øhall be determined according to the terms of this Covenant. Now Chri≈øt ≈øhed his blood to procure tho≈øe terms contained in that Covenant: for the ca≈øe of poor ≈øinners was ≈øo mi≈øerable, that they could never come to have all their ≈øins pardoned, and their Souls certainly ≈øaved, unle≈øs Chri≈øt had died and ≈øhed his blood, and ≈øo to ≈øatisfie Gods ju≈øtice, that it might be free for him to be merciful, where he would be merciful. The Covenant is founded in the blood of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, that blood being the blood of the Everla≈øting Covenant; therefore the Apo≈øtle ≈øo magnifies it, of all the great and Go≈øpel-ble≈ø≈øings that belong to the New Te≈øtament, to the condition of a child of God, there is not any like unto this, the blood of the Everla≈øting Covenant; they that come to this, and have the benefit of this, they ≈øhall be ≈øurely ju≈øtified, and eternally ≈øaved in the vertue of this blood. In the bu≈øine≈øs of being ≈øaved by Faith, it contributes nothing more, but as 'tis an In≈øtrument to bring us to be made partakers of the benefit of this blood: we are ≈øaved not by vertue
of our believing, but by the vertue of his blood; ≈øo that, 'tis not ≈øo much the Act, as the object of Faith that ≈øaves, Chri≈øt ro≈øe in the vertue of his blood; & all our comforts and hopes are founded in his blood. The blood of Chri≈øt was of ≈øo much value with God, as that he will rai≈øe him from the dead, and 'tis of ≈øo much vertue to us, that through it we ≈øhall have Ju≈øtification, and Sanctification, and Salvation, God being ≈øo good and gracious a God to Je≈øus Chri≈øt and his Church; hereupon the Apo≈øtle emboldens him≈øelf to de≈øire his further manife≈øtation of his love, that where he hath ≈øo bountifully provided for the ju≈øtification of ≈øinners through the blood of Chri≈øt, that he would provide for their ≈øanctifying by his Spirit. Hence ob≈øerve,

list.item: 1. God is with ≈øome fingularity, the God of Peace.

2. To the end that God might ≈øhew him≈øelf to be the God of Peace, he hath provided an all-≈øufficient Saviour for his people, here called the Great Shepheard of the flock; and God being of a gracious di≈øpo≈øition towards them, provides to that end Chri≈øt ≈øhall take care of them, and to all tho≈øe things that pertain to their eternal welfare.

4. It was as nece≈ø≈øary that Chri≈øt ≈øhould be rai≈øed from the dead, as that he ≈øhould dye. Therefore his continuance was but a temporary, nay a momentary time to him. God put him≈øelf into a Covenant, Chri≈øt was Mediator of it, and in vertue of that Covenant ≈øinners mu≈øt be ≈øaved; but the Saviour mu≈øt fir≈øt ≈øave him≈øelf, rai≈øe him≈øelf from the dead, and then hath all power committed to his hand, &c. There are two things that I would have you further ob≈øerve and carry away.

div.p:
1. That Chri≈øt is indeed the only Great Shepherd of the ≈øheep. What≈øoever others there are, they make to his own intere≈øt, who≈øoever there be that may po≈ø≈øibly intitle them≈øelves under the name and notion, yet this is undeniable, that Chri≈øt is the only Great Shepherd of the Sheep: therefore in the concernments of the Church, there is none Chri≈øtians ≈øhould honour as Chri≈øt; and who≈øe voice they ought to hear before his, or by whom they ≈øhould be ruled and governed, but by him. If Chri≈øt be

We are by believing, the Children of God, Gal. 3.26. 3. Let us con≈øider what we ≈øhall be at the end of Faith: why, we ≈øhall be ≈øaved, 1 Pet. 1.4, 5. and 9. ver≈øes compared, He hath begotten us to an Inheritance incorruptible and undefiled, that fades not away, re≈øerved in Heaven for you, who are kept by the power of God through faith unto ≈øalvation, ready to be revealed in the la≈øt times; and in the ninth ver≈øe, ≈øaith he, receiving the end of your Faith, even the ≈øalvation of your ≈øouls; ≈øo that, it ≈øeems, to be weary of believing, it is to be weary of being ≈øaved; not to hold fa≈øt Faith, is not to hold fa≈øt Salvation; for, ≈øaith he, you are ≈øaved by Faith, and the end of your Faith is the Salvation of your ≈øouls. Now this mo≈øt holy God is the Author of this Faith, and ≈øo it is a mo≈øt holy faith, it being the Word of the mo≈øt holy God; and will you leave, and not hold fa≈øt this mo≈øt holy Faith?

But then be≈øides, It may be ‚Ä¢ aid to be the mo≈øt holy faith in this ≈øence too, that it is its nature where ever it comes to make the ≈øubject in whom it is, mo≈øt holy: ≈øaith the Apo≈øtle, you hath God cho≈øen, to wit, by Faith, to be a peculiar people, a holy Nation, Acts 15.2. it is ≈øaid, He hath purified their hearts by faith, and he will give them an ‚Ä¢ nheritance

Fir≈øt, Con≈øidering the operation and effects it hath upon the hearts and lives of them in whom it is: it makes them a holy People, beyond all the people in the world: And then upon this account too, as to the uhimate effects of it, that it admits us into the mo≈øt holy places. Shall we leave ≈øuch a Faith as this? ≈øhall we not hold fa≈øt the mo≈øt holy Faith, that is from the mo≈øt holy God, that makes the mo≈øt holy people, and that admits us into the mo≈øt holy place? That if thou ≈øhalt with thy mouth confe≈øs thy Lord Je≈øus, and ≈øhalt believe in thy heart that God hath rai≈øed him from the dead, thou ≈øhalt be ≈øaved; for with the heart man believeth unto righteou≈øne≈øs, and with the mouth confe≈ø≈øion is made unto ≈øalvation: An unprofe≈ø≈øed Faith hath no ≈øalvation annexed to it; you ≈øee the Scripture maketh it as nece≈ø≈øary to our ≈øalvation, to profe≈øs our believing, as to believe. Thirdly, A third Argument is drawn from the act with the qualifications, let's hold fa≈øt without wavering; Now there are two things, to name no more, that are hugely obliging in this very act, with its qualification; fir≈øt, it is a manly act to hold fa≈øt that which is good: and it is a childi≈øh act to let it go. Secondly, It is not only a manly act to hold fa≈øt that which is good, and childi≈øh to let it go: but it is a Chri≈øtian act, a proper Chri≈øtian act, a right Chri≈øtian act, it is that which doth di≈øtingui≈øh a true Chri≈øtian from a hypocrite and a counterfeit; you know it is a character of a Godly man, he is a praying man: there went up two men into the Temple to pray, the one was a hypocrite, the other a Publican; now, what is there then in prayer, that doth di≈øtingui≈øh the≈øe two men? why faith Job, will the hypocrite pray

Fir≈øt, Would you hold fa≈øt? (I cannot but believe it to be all your de≈øires) well then, if you would hold fa≈øt, let me be≈øeech this of you, take heed of all, and every ≈øort of men, that make Religion a Trade to get mony, by which perhaps you will ≈øay, are there any ≈øuch in the world? Secondly, Take heed of the error of the wicked, le≈øt you fall from your own ≈øtedfa≈øtne≈øs: this advice you have from the Apo≈øtle Peter, 2 Pet. 3.17. Ye therefore Beloved, ≈øeeing ye know the≈øe things before, beware, le≈øt you al≈øo being led away by the error of the wicked, fall from your own ≈øtedfa≈øtne≈øs; the error of the wicked, is like to make one as wicked as they: pray, what was this error of the wicked? It was this; there were a generation of wicked men, that ≈øaid, It was in vain to ≈øerve God, for, ≈øay they, Where is the promi≈øe of his coming? Only, Beloved, it was as much as to ≈øay, there was no reward for godline≈øs, nor no wages for ungodline≈øs. Oh! take heed of this error of the wicked‚ñ™ it is a wicked error, and none but wicked ones hold it, to wit, That it is in vain to ≈øerve God: therefore keep this ≈øtill in your hearts, that, Verily in keeping his Commandments there is great reward; if there were no more but the very work, it is great honour to us, that we may be ≈øervants to ≈øuch a God; but, Beloved, Be ≈øtedfa≈øt and unmoveable, knowing that your labour ≈øhall not be in vain in the Lord. Mal. 3.13. there is the like in≈øtance: Your words have been ≈øtout again≈øt me, ≈øaith the Lord, yet ye ≈øay, what have we ≈øpoken ≈øo much again≈øt thee? this God is always quarrelling with us, and laying things to our charge; what have we ≈øaid? in the 14 ver≈øe, Ye ≈øaid it is in vain to ≈øerve God, and what pro≈øit is it that we have kept his Ordinances? we have walked mournfully before the Lord of ho≈øts, and now we call the proud happy, yea, they that work wickedne≈øs are ≈øet up, yea, they that tempt God are even delivered: well now, what follows? They they that feared the Lord, ≈øpake often one to another: as if they had ≈øaid, let not the≈øe things take any thing off the edge of our affections, or quench any flame of our love: did God take any notice of this now, that he had any ≈øuch friends in the world? yes, ≈øaith he, God hearkned, and heard, and a book of remembrance was written before him, for them that feared the Lord, and that thought upon his Name, and they ≈øhall be mine, ≈øaith the Lord of ho≈øts, in that day when I make up my Jewels, and I will ≈øpare them, as a man ≈øpares his own ≈øon that ≈øerves him: there is a time coming
the day will declare, whether it be ≈øerving God or the Devil: well then beloved, as ever you would hold fa≈øt the profe≈ø≈øion of your Faith, take heed of the error of the wicked, never think it vain to ≈øerve God, though you may lo≈øe b ‚Ä¢ it; for, if ye lo≈øe for him, ye ≈øhall never lo≈øe by him.

Thirdly, Would you hold fa≈øt the Profe≈ø≈øion of your Faith? then lay up the word of Faith in a good and hone≈øt heart, Luke 8.15. It is ≈øaid there of the good ground; they are they which have heard the Word, kept it, or hold it fa≈øt: where do they lay it up now? in a good and hone≈øt heart: ≈øo that you mu≈øt pull out his heart, before that you can pull out the Word, and will any man ≈øuffer his heart to be torn from him? you never hold it fa≈øt till you lay it up in a good and hone≈øt heart; if it be only in the hands, as a Bible in your hands, or in the head, it will be gone; but if it be in your hearts, you will never let it go: therefore ob≈øerve, ≈øaith he, Having heard it, they keep it, and hold it fa≈øt in an hone≈øt and good heart, and bring forth fruit with patience: they had a great deal of ≈øufferings to bring with patience; for, if they were not under ≈øuffering, what need were there of patience?? Well, beloved, con≈øider a little further, as to this, the Connection between the ver≈øe preceding the Text, and the Text, ≈øaith he; Let us draw near with a true heart, in full a≈ø≈øurance of faith, having our hearts ≈øprinkled with a pure con≈øcience, and our bodies wa≈øhed with pure water. La≈øtly, Would you hold fa≈øt the profe≈ø≈øion of your Faith? then look much to, and often con≈øider Je≈øus Chri≈øt, the Author and fini≈øher of your Faith. Saith the Apo≈øtle, having a high Prie≈øt over the Hou≈øe of God, let us draw near, and let us hold fa≈øt; a high Prie≈øt, that is Je≈øus Chri≈øt, our great high Prie≈øt, Heb. 3.1. Seeing then that ye have a great high Prie≈øt, that is pa≈ø≈øed into the Heavens, Je≈øus the Son of God, let us hold fa≈øt our Profe≈ø≈øion, Heb. 12.2. Looking unto Je≈øus, the Author and Fini≈øher of our Faith, who for the joy that was ≈øet before him, endured the Cro≈øs, de≈øpi≈øed the Shame, and is ≈øet down at the right hand of the Throne of God!. Oh! let us be thinking of, and looking to this Je≈øus. You will ≈øay, what ≈øhall we think of him? Oh! think of this conde≈øcen≈øion
in the world, of that vouch≈øafement, which, as was never the like of his; how he humbled him≈øelf, and ≈øuffered being God for man: Think how he became poor that was rich, that we that were poor might become rich; think how he became a cur≈øe, think how he became ≈øin for us, think what a good Confe≈ø≈øion he made before Pontius Pilate, even to death, and was obedient to the death: Think how he conquered death by dying, and how he ro≈øe again by his Almighty power, and a≈øcended into Heaven, and ever lives to make interce≈ø≈øion for tho≈øe that come to the Father through him: Think how he lived here on earth in a ≈øad condition, and joyed in it, ≈øo that it might be for our good, and ≈øhall we leave ≈øuch a Chri≈øt as this? Oh! can you look upon Chri≈øt, and leave the Profe≈ø≈øion of your Faith? It cannot be: keep Chri≈øt before your eyes, make him your pattern, and you will not, you cannot do ami≈øs. He that ≈øaith he abides in him, ought to walk as he walked: he walked in obedience all his days, and was obedient to the death: So mu≈øt we, we mu≈øt walk in all obedience all our days, though we dye for being obedient. Now unto him that is able to keep you from falling, and pre≈øent you faultle≈øs before the pre≈øence of his glory with exceeding joy, to the only wi≈øe God and Saviour, be Glory and Maje≈øty, Dominion and Power, now and for ever. div.p: I Began this Scripture the la≈øt Lords day in this Congregation. I told you then, there were three Doctrines obvious in the Text; the fir≈øt was,
Doct. 1. That it is the Duty of Chri≈øtians, to remember tho≈øe Truths that: they have heard and received.
Doct. 2. That it is the Duty of Chri≈øtians, to hold fa≈øt the Truth that they have heard and received.
Doct. 3. That continued repentance, is the Duty of Chri≈øtians, as well as initial Repentance. Remember therefore how thou ha≈øt received, and heard, and hold fa≈øt, and repent.

The fir≈øt of the≈øe Doctrines, I applied my ≈øelf to, and applied to the people la≈øt Lords-Day, and ≈øhall not now ≈øay any thing of it; but proceed to the next Doctrine, that it is the Duty of Chri≈øtians, To hold fa≈øt the Truths that they have heard and received. div.p: Fir≈øt, What Chri≈øtians are to hold fa≈øt: the Doctrine ≈øays, they are to hold fa≈øt the Truths they have received. Now Truths are of two ≈øorts.

div.p: 2. Now, though it is true, it is good for a man to be right in Moral things, and to know, and cleave to that which is Truth in Morality; yet the Truths that we are here called upon to hold fa≈øt, they are Divine Truths, Supernatural Truths, Truths in Religion, Truths in the things of God.

Thirdly, Scripture-Truths, Truths that are grounded, and warranted in the Word of God, they are either ≈øuch as are immediately and expre≈øly laid down in the Scripture, or ≈øuch as are mediately contained in Scripture, and by deduction drawn thence. that are of le≈øs weight than Religion, and yet Truths of God. Now we are not onely to hold fa≈øt tho≈øe Truths of God, that are the Fundamental-Truths; as that there is a God, and but one God; and that there is a Trinity of Per≈øons in Unity of E≈ø≈øence, Father, Son, and Holy-Gho≈øt; and that there is but one Mediator between God and Man, the Man Chri≈øt Je≈øus, and that he is both God and Man in one Per≈øon, and that he hath given full ≈øatisfaction to Divine Ju≈øtice, for all that by faith clo≈øe with him, and the like.

Thus you ≈øee what we mu≈øt hold fa≈øt, Divine Truths, Scripture Truths, whether greater or le≈ø≈øer: we mu≈øt hold fa≈øt what we have received. Fir≈øt, For the excellency of Divine Truth; it is more precious than Gold, better than Rubies, and all that you can de≈øire cannot be compared with Truth. p.hi: Exhortation.

div.p: THe≈øe words contain two parts:

list.item: 1. A Duty exhorted to.
2. The manner of the management of Duty.

div.p: The duty exhorted to, is, to retain the faith delivered to the Saints:
The manner of its management is, that we ≈øhould earne≈øtly contend to keep it.
I opened the terms, What's meant by Faith.

It is not ≈øo much the grace of faith, but the Doctrine of faith; not ≈øpecial faith, whereby we apprehend ≈øpecial mercy upon a promi≈øe made to the Elect, but the Fides quae creditur, the whole ≈øub≈øtance of the Doctrine of Chri≈øt, as to things that are to be believed, and duties that are to be practi≈øed.

But why is it ≈øaid, The faith that was once delivered? (that is) invariably, irrevocably, once for all. To the Saints, re≈øpects the priviledge the Saints of God had in the faith that God had left: 'tis the faith of the Go≈øpel, committed as a Trea≈øure: And the Church is called a Candle≈øtick, not only to hold out the light, but to hold the light: whence the Church is called the Pillar, or the ground of truth: not that they are to make Doctrines, but to hold forth the Doctrines of Chri≈øt, even as Tables and Pillars, upon which Proclamations are hung and held forth to be made publick: ≈øo is the Church of Chri≈øt, 'tis that in which the Truths of the Lord Je≈øus are kept, and will be kept from one age to another.

But what's the import of the word [Earne≈øtly contend?] It's a word u≈øed only once in the New Te≈øtament in the Compo≈øition: The word in the root is frequently u≈øed, and imports a ≈øtruggling with might and main, as tho≈øe that u≈øe to run at games. It is u≈øed for Je≈øus Chri≈øt in his ≈øufferings, He was in an Agony; the ≈øame word from whence this word is compounded. The Apo≈øtle would imply ≈øuch a contention, ≈øuch a ≈øtrugling to keep the faith of the Go≈øpel, as one word in the Engli≈øh is not able to expre≈øs it, and Interpreters very much differ what's the import: The be≈øt do centre in this, that we ≈øhould contend for the Faith, as men that would contend to keep their very lives.

The Propo≈øition is this, That it is the duty of the Saints of God to maintain an earne≈øt contention, to ≈øtruggle for, and to keep the Faith that was betru≈øted with them: Wherein doth this contention con≈øi≈øt?

1. It is not a carnal contention; the weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but ≈øpiritual, the Saints are not called to contend for the Faith with carnal weapons, with carnal power and force: (not by might and power, but by the Spirit of God) force and power, and a fle≈øhly Arm, Pri≈øon, Pillors, and Chains, and taking away of mens comforts and E≈øtates upon the account of the Faith of the Go≈øpel, hath been the u≈øual way of Error's detending it ≈øelf: Prayers and Tears are the Churches Weapons.

2. 'Tis not a contention of uncharitablene≈øs. This Contention allows no murthering, either of the bodies or ≈øouls of men: Chri≈øtians are ≈øo to contend again≈øt Error and ≈øinful Practices, as to love their per≈øons, and pitty tho≈øe they contend with. There are ≈øome opinions, that there is no way to ≈øhew a holy way of zeal again≈øt, nor to be able to de≈øtroy them, but by a holy ≈øeparating from the per≈øons: there were ≈øuch to whom it was not lawlul to ≈øay God ≈øpeed, or receive them into their hou≈øes: but yet this in order to the ≈øaving their ≈øouls: Saving ≈øome, plucking them as brands out of the fire.
But po≈øitively, this holy contention it con≈øi≈øts in the≈øe four things.

list.item: 1. In managing the Sword of the Spirit, the Word of God, again≈øt Errors and ≈øinful Practices, to be able to confute them mightily, as Apollos did, out of the Scriptures, ≈øhewing the Jews that Je≈øus is the Chri≈øt.

2. By Prayer: for to pray down ≈øinful opinions and practi≈øes. That we mean when we pray, Thy Kingdom come, that the Go≈øpel may run on and be glorified: that the≈øe nights of darkne≈øs may be di≈øpelled: that Truth may ≈øhine to the perfect day.

3. By holy practi≈øing again≈øt them: by holding forth the Word o ‚Ä¢ Life in your Conver≈øations: by ≈øtriving together by a mutual provocation for the Faith of the Go≈øpel, in re≈øpect of holy walking.
4. By being able to ≈øuffer for them.

div.p: The rea≈øons of the Point I gave you.

I ≈øhall now ≈øum up all in a word of Exhortation, to pre≈øs every one that bears the name of a Saint, to take up this Exhortation of the Apo≈øtle, Earne≈øtly to contend for the faith that was once delivered to the Saints. The ≈øum of all is, to beg that you would be valiant for the Truth of Chri≈øt; that whatever hath been delivered to you con≈øonant to the truth, agreeable to the faith delivered to us, that you would ≈øtruggle might and main, by all Chri≈øtian courage, by argument, practice, prayer, by ≈øuffering, rather than let go tho≈øe truths that God hath taught you by his faithful Mini≈øters: that Chri≈øt hath been preached to you: tho≈øe Scriptures you have in your hands; tho≈øe Doctrines you have learned by experience, by prayer, by ≈øearching the Word: tho≈øe ways of Wor≈øhip God hath taught you; tho≈øe patterns of his hou≈øe, and out-goings and returnings there, that he hath taught you; be exhorted to hold them fa≈øt, and not let them go: (Contend earne≈øtly for the faith, &c.)

It is to be lamented, that there is ≈øo ≈øad a ≈øpirit of indifferency among Chri≈øtians, as we find at this day. Many do ≈øo carry it, as if there were nothing in the Go≈øpel of Chri≈øt that were worthy the owning by practi≈øing, or worthy owning by ≈øuffering. This luke-warm indifferent temper hath done the Church of God a great deal of mi≈øchief formerly; and if admitted now, will do you as much mi≈øchief again. It hath been one of the ≈øins which the Lord at this day is judging and puni≈øhing his poor people for, that our zeal hath been ≈øo hot again≈øt one another for meer circum≈øtances, and ≈øo cold when we are like to lo≈øe the ≈øub≈øtance: that our contentions ri≈øe ≈øo high in matters hardly of any moment, and our ≈øpirits work ≈øo low when they are to gain the great things for which Chri≈øt ≈øuffered, & which he delivered to us. It is my work therefore to beg you, that you would put on a holy re≈øolution, that there may be no contention among us (for we are Brethren) but only that contention, who may mo≈øt retain, & evidently witne≈øs the Faith that is delivered to us: It is the tru≈øt God hath committed, and he doth expect and look how we will manage it with courage and confidence, to keep the Faith of the Go≈øpel. There are very great oppo≈øitions again≈øt you, and there ought to be great re≈øolutions of Chri≈øtians to maintain them≈øelves again≈øt ≈øuch oppo≈øitions. It is a very ≈øad thing that Chri≈øtians ≈øhould ≈øee the Faith and the ways of the Go≈øpel of God, as it were taken from them at any time „Äà1 page missing„Äâ
and they have not one word to ≈øpeak, nor any thing at all for to venture in ≈øuffering for the wayes and truths of Je≈øus Chri≈øt: Mo≈øes had ≈øuch a holy zeal, that when Aaron was an example to the people to lead them to Idolatry, he contended with him earne≈øtly to his face. The zeal of Gods ≈øervants is ≈øo ≈ømall now, that though Balaam be about the work, we have not a word to ≈øpeak; Though the ≈ømall Prophets of Antichri≈øt be about the bu≈øine≈øs, yet no Chri≈øtian hath courage to ≈øpeak. The holy Apo≈øtle Paul, when Peter walked with an uneven foot, and began to Judai≈øe, he tells us, he did re≈øi≈øt him to his face. Shall Paul re≈øi≈øt Simon Peter, and ≈øhall not the Saints of God re≈øi≈øt Simon-Magus? ≈øhall they re≈øi≈øt Hymenaeus and Philetus, and ≈øhall not we contend with Alexander the Copper-≈ømith? 'tis but ≈øuitable to what God expects; and the Exhortation here given us, That we ≈øhould maintain with might and main, as that which is our trea≈øure, which we will not let go, the Faith once delivered to the Saints.
To put you upon this, I might encourage you with ≈øeveral things. All the Rea≈øons mentioned are as ≈øo many Motives to this holy ≈øpiritual contention: Shall I tell you of three words further?

1. The mercy of God delivering the truth to you, ≈øhould engage you to this holy contention: 'tis ≈øuch a mercy as is a Non-≈øuch mercy, P≈øal. 147. the two la≈øt ver≈øes, He hath given his Judgments to Jacob, and his Statutes to I≈ørael; He hath not dealt ≈øo with any Nation. How many of the greate≈øt part of tho≈øe that we call Chri≈øtians in the world, are put like Samp≈øon to grind among the Phili≈øtinis? Super≈øtition, Popery, Idolatry, Will-wor≈øhip, ≈øuch things as Je≈øus Chri≈øt never delivered to his Saints, having both their eyes out, the Scripture light that ≈øhould have ≈øhewed them the truth, taken from them; and their Con≈øciences that ≈øhould teach them, carried in the pocket of ≈øome ba≈øe Prie≈øt, that dare not think any other than what he will tell them. How many are there, even of the very reformed of the world, who only get upon ≈øome broken plank of Ship-wrack'd truth, whereby they ≈øwim to the Lord Je≈øus? But God does not deal thus with us: you have had the whole Coun≈øel of God revealed to you, a glorious light ≈øet up in the Nation for a hundred of years pa≈øt, which hath been like the light of ≈øeven dayes: For the≈øe twenty years pa≈øt the running to and fro of men, hath increa≈øed knowledge: you have learned the truth from Gods faithful Mini≈øters: you have received it with much affliction, with many temptations: it hath co≈øt Je≈øus Chri≈øt dear to ≈øend it, it hath co≈øt you dear to receive it, and will you let it go? Your ≈øin above all others will be mo≈øt provoking to the Lord Je≈øus.

2. I might tell you that 'tis a time, wherein many let go the faith, and methinks the Lord Je≈øus does by his poor and unworthy me≈ø≈øenger ≈øpeak to this great Congregation, as ≈øometimes he did to his Apo≈øtles, Will ye al≈øo go away? There are many that have been forward and eminent Profe≈ø≈øors of the Faith delivered to the Saints, that have made Ship-wrack of Faith and a good Con≈øcience; will you ≈øplit upon the ≈øame rock? God hath kept the truth for you, and kept you in the truth hitherto, and is coming to ≈øee whether you will cleave to it, and keep it or no. We have been ≈øucking at the brea≈øts of the Ordinances, and dandled upon the knees of Providences, and gone on in a ≈ømooth way of Profe≈ø≈øion: but what will you do now, when you mu≈øt come po≈ø≈øibly to ≈øuffer per≈øecution for it? to keep the faith, you may lo≈øe your Liberty, Life, E≈øtate. And there's a great deal of hazard upon this account, becau≈øe it hath plea≈øed God ≈øo to di≈øpo≈øe it, as that tho≈øe that ≈øhould be your guides into truth, the Lord is removing them into corners. Po≈ø≈øibly while they have been with you, you have kept the faith; but what will you do when they are gone? While Mo≈øes was with the people they cleaved to the Lord; when once he was gone into the Mount, they fell into their Idolatry, and wor≈øhipped a Calf. While Paul was at Ephe≈øus the flock kept pure, but (≈øaith he) I know after my departure grievous Wolves ≈øhall break in, not ≈øparing the flock, &c. So while you have heard of God, who ≈øends voices and warnings to ≈øcare away the Wolves and Foxes from you, po≈ø≈øibly you may keep the Faith; but what will you do when God removes them?

3. God hath ever had in all ages of his Church, a word of his Patience to be kept, to try his Saints; and therefore it does concern you for to be valiant for the truth. In all the ≈øeries of Gods di≈øpen≈øations with his Church, there hath been ≈øomething or other of the faith of Chri≈øt, that hath co≈øt them re≈øi≈øting to bloud, to ≈øacrifice their lives, to lay down all that they have for it by ≈øuffering. Now even as they, ≈øo we; if not in the ≈øame thing, yet in the ≈øame faith: we have ≈øtill ≈øome word or other of Gods patience to keep, therefore we need to have on the Armour of Light; you mu≈øt wre≈øtle with the fiery Tryal, for there is ≈øome Jewel that Je≈øus Chri≈øt puts upon you to wear, that Per≈øecutors and Per≈øecutions, Here≈øies and Hereticks will ≈øcratch at, which you mu≈øt hold out with lo≈øs of life to keep; and this mu≈øt be till the latter part of the rage and reign of Antichri≈øt is out; and even as you keep that, ≈øo will God keep you, Rev. 3.10. As you honour the word of Gods patience, ≈øo God will honour you: As you are faithful
to him, ≈øo will he give you the Crown, and no otherwi≈øe: Hence therefore it concerns us all to be armed with a holy confidence and re≈øolution, as to this ≈øpiritual Warfare, in contending for the faith delivered to us.
But the great thing I ≈øhall ≈øpeak to, is; Wherein may Chri≈øtians be helped in this holy ≈øtrugling and contention?
I ≈øhall only mention five or ≈øix things, ≈øome to fit you for it, others to help you in the mannagement of it: I ≈øhall name them mixtly, and not di≈øtinct.

1. To di≈øcover what is right, and what is wrong; for the Scripture alone is the Touch-≈øtone of Doctrines, and the Trial of Spirits: The Scripture does di≈øcover it ≈øelf, and doth di≈øcover all things that are contrary to it: when you are bidden to try all things, 'tis not by practi≈øing all things, as ≈øome poor giddy-headed Chri≈øtians of late days have done; who have made the practi≈øing every opinion, to be their trying of it, till they have run them≈øelves into all Opinions: but 'tis the Scripture you are fir≈øt to trie, and then to practi≈øe; who are like the noble Bereans, that were more noble than tho≈øe of The≈ø≈øalonipa, becau≈øe they ≈øearched the Scripture. To bring the Truths that have or ≈øhall be taught you, or the Doctrines that ≈øhall be impo≈øed upon you, to the Word of God; to ≈øee whether they be according to the Truth, or no: for fal≈øe Doctrines and fal≈øe Wor≈øhip, of all things they hate the Scripture mo≈øt: they are alike fal≈øe coyn, or fal≈øe Jewels, which go be≈øt in the night: fal≈øe coyn will not endure the Touch-≈øtone, nor fal≈øe Jewels the day: no more will fal≈øe Doctrines the Scripture; therefore it will be a great way to di≈øcover them.

2. It will be a great way to vanqui≈øh them, Eph. 6. Above all, take the ≈øword of the Spirit: the Word of God is the ≈øword of the Spirit, by which we ≈ølay Heretical Doctrines; and by which we are to ≈ølay ≈øinful practi≈øes. All tho≈øe ≈øtones that the Davids of God have flung at the Goliahs of Errour, they have been taken out of the Brook of the Scriptures: therefore reduce all Doctrines offered you to believe, all Wor≈øhips that are taught you to practi≈øe, to the Word of God.

1. All Doctrines that are taught you to believe, reduce them thither;
there's no profe≈ø≈øion of Faith to be built, but the ≈øtones mu≈øt be fetched from that Mountain: If you believe Divine Truths, but not becau≈øe the Scripture propounds them, your faith is but humane: If you believe any thing the Scripture doth not ≈øpeak, your faith is Diabolical: the Word of God, and your faith, mu≈øt run parallel: All that is written, you mu≈øt believe, and you mu≈øt believe nothing but what is written: This was the Rule of the Old Te≈øtament, I≈øa. 8.20. To the Law and to the Te≈øtimony; to the Law, that is, to Mo≈øes; and to the Te≈øtimony, that is, to the Prophets: if they ≈øpeak not according to the≈øe, there's no light in them. When any thing was offered to Chri≈øt by way of enquiry, his common an≈øwer was, How reade≈øt thou? Luk. 10.26. How is it written? When the Apo≈øtle Paul would redre≈øs the abu≈øe of the Lords Supper, he does not carry the Corinthians to the≈øe and the≈øe Fathers, to this and that u≈øe and cu≈øtom, but brings that, How it was delivered from the Lord: he reduces them to the In≈øtitution; What I have received from the Lord, that I have delivered unto you. The Word of God is perfect, in re≈øpect of Doctrine, and in re≈øpect of Wor≈øhip. So that what≈øoever is offered you to believe, you mu≈øt try it by perfect rules; for 'tis given by Divine in≈øpiration, to make the man of God perfect and wi≈øe unto Salvation: it is ≈øuch a Canon about Doctrines to be received, as nothing mu≈øt be added nor taken from it, Rev. 22. Therefore it's called a Te≈øtament: Now no man dares adde to another mans la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament: Who ≈øhall dare to adde a faith to the Faith of Gods Elect, to that which Chri≈øt hath delivered? I will give you this as a certain Ob≈øervation, that there never was any thing of fal≈øe Doctrine brought into the Church, or any thing of fal≈øe Wor≈øhip impo≈øed upon the Church, but either it was by neglecting the Scripture, or by introducing ≈øomeehing above the Scripture.

2. Bring hither all practices of Wor≈øhip, as well as Doctrine, to be believed: try the wayes and forms of Chri≈øts hou≈øe, by the Word of Chri≈øt: he ≈øhews us the patterns thereof, the our-goings, and returnings thereof: he was faithful in all his hou≈øe, even as Mo≈øes was, who did not leave a pin of the Tabernacle, but did appoint it. There is nothing decent and comely in the Church, which is ≈øo much pleaded for, but what comes in by Chri≈øts in≈øtitution. with God: (for he is a Spirit, and ≈øeeks ≈øuch Wor≈øhippers:) it will never bring you to the enjoyment of God: therefore in point of Wor≈øhip, bring it to the Word of God; and as to Faith and Wor≈øhip, ≈øay, Hitherto, my Faith, and my Wor≈øhip, ≈øhalt thou go and no further. This rule rightly improved, will di≈ø-intangle you from the hooks, and take you off from the baits of tho≈øe cunning Fowlers (for to ≈øuch the Apo≈øtle doth compare them in the New Te≈øtament) who ≈øeek to betray ≈øouls from the ≈øimplicity of Go≈øpel-faith. Never any did invent fal≈øe Doctrine, but to put up them, they put down the Scripture, and they put out the eyes of Chri≈øtians to make them bend to it. Before they u≈øe other means to compel them, their great work is to darken the light, or the truth; and in the room of the Scripture to be your rule, they ≈øet up other Rules: which, becau≈øe there are three marvellous Popular, I de≈øire to mention them in oppo≈øition to this Rule I have given you.
There's a three-fold rule men would ≈øet up to deceive poor ≈øouls: The Name of a Church: Ancient Cu≈øtoms: The Generality of tho≈øe where they live.

1. The ≈øpecious Name of a Church, to make that a Rule to Doctrine and to Wor≈øhip. It was the plea of the Popi≈øh Party in the Marian dayes; What! will you not believe the Church? hath not the Church power to make In≈øtitutions and Canons about this, and that, and the other? will you not believe the Church? will will you go out from the true Church? div.p: Fifthly, With an humble acknowledgment of former barrenne≈øs, under Gods gracious pre≈øence with you, re≈øolve and endeavour to be more fruitful. Sixthly, If you would have the continual abode of God and Chri≈øt with you, Let God have all your thoughts, let him be your meditation; this is the way to have the be≈øt company when you be

div.p: Seventhly, If we will have God and Chri≈øt to make their con≈øtant abode with us, then let us walk humbly with God. div.p:
Eighthly, If you would have the con≈øtant abode of God and Chri≈øt with you, be ≈øure to look to your Hearts, that you walk in your uprightne≈øs: be true to the Word of God, be true to your profe≈ø≈øion. Fir≈øt, That which often perverts the ≈øoul from the truth, is the fear of troubles and wants; If I keep my integrity (≈øays the ≈øoul) I ≈øhall be undone, I ≈øhall lo≈øe my e≈øtate, embroyl my ≈øelf in many troubles; perhaps a Pri≈øon, Exile, or Death comes next. epigraph.q: Who≈øoever believeth that Je≈øus is the Chri≈øt, is born of God; and every one that loveth him that begat, loveth him al≈øo that is begotten of him. Little Children, keep your ≈øelves from Idols.

div.p:
THis general Doctrine I have already delivered unto you from this Text, which indeed is the marrow and ≈øub≈øtance of the whole Chapter; That Go≈øpel-believing is a duty, which they that really perform, are highly priviledged by, to their greate≈øt advantage. Why, but will you con≈øider now, this Text, and other Scriptures do ≈øpeak fully to the purpo≈øe; Who≈øoever doth believe this, that Je≈øus is the Chri≈øt, the Son of God, and that he is come in the fle≈øh, who≈øoever believes this, is of God, is born of God.
